  5975. This brush gives a shiny and soft look to the hair, which doesn't happen if you just blow dry it (if you have curly/wavy hair).
  5976. You still need to blow dry before you use it, and when you do spin your hair, the bristles get so soft
  5977. My hair didn't dry completely as I was styling
  5978. lots of volume, slightly curled ends, and SO much shine.
  5979. the first couple of uses I got impatient and aided with with my blow dryer on low.
  5980. But, if you're looking for a total replacement to your dryer and brush, do not buy this... or at least not at full price.
  5981. The first time I used it, I did as suggested in the reviews and dried my hair about 90% with my regular blow dryer.
  5982. The first one I bought stopped rotating after only a few uses
  5983. It took only a few minutes to learn how to use the tool, which I thought was pretty neat.
  5984. and it left my hair in these large slight waves.
  5985. , I think because the wattage is so much lower, my other hair dryer is1875 watts and this is I believe only 500, but it definitely provides that salon blow out bouncy moveable hair look, so if you don't mind the extra time then go for it!!!
  5986. I don't straighten my hair on my own very much because it's usually exhausting, frustrating
  5987. that after a head wash- without proper styling, its very cumbersome and unpretty to leave it down.
  5988. I look like I had a professional blow out every single morning.
  5989. My husband (the man of few compliments) even commented positively on it

  5991. Handle is a little too large for me.
  5992. I have medium length thin hair and it takes less than 10 minutes, after a thorough towel dry, to get a great all day hairstyle with minimal product.
  5993. It does take a little practice to get the hang of it and it can be a little heavy but for the results it's fantastic!!
  5994. , they straighten their very curly hair and this straightens but leaves body and waves instead of the sharp edges left by the flat iron.
  5995. I'm not sure if there are instructions on different curling techniques, but I'm sure if you spend a few minutes experimenting
  5996. When I first got the Infinitopro last week, I used it a few times, but I didn't notice a big difference.
  5997. I have long, thick hair, similar to the girl in the videos available for this product.
  5998. It is most definitely NOT able to be used with hair that is only towel dried.
  5999. When I broke my right arm recently, I couldn't style my hair with the usual blowdryer and brush.
  6000. The Infinitipro also seemed cheaply made, like it would fall apart or break apart if I held it just a little too tightly.
  6001. This makes it so much easier for to get the same effect with much less effort.
  6002. wouldn't necessarily recommend this for people with straight hair because they get less out of the product
  6003. At the rate that the air was coming out of this thing, I would have had to get up 3 hours early to have my hair dry by the time I left for work.
  6004. Over the years I've tried all types of dryers and Spin Styler is the only one that achieves a professional blow dry look at home for
  6005. Does not matter if hair is dry or wet, get ready for yanks.
  6006. (it takes me about 10-15 min to blow dry her hair straight from wet).
  6007. I have curly/frizzy hair, but not curly enough to let it dry naturally.
  6008. Also the air flow is not heavy enough to dry the hair.
  6009. Also I wish it would be less thick because it would create better waves then.
  6010. I came home, took a shower, and let my hair air dry for a bit, approximately 40 minutes, as suggested in many of the reviews I read.
  6011. It's so easy to use I'm surprised by the reviews saying it is difficult.
  6012. Finally, if you are using this on your ends, you could only flip it in or out, not just have the ends hang straight down.
  6013. Box was quite tightly packed, so no broken parts.
  6014. Hot curlers or a large curling iron work a little, but the style goes flat in a few hours.
  6015. I'm not ready to give up on it yet, and I might just need to get the right technique down.
  6016. The brush is too big for short hair, and the bristles are too soft for extra long hair.
  6017. This little tool cut my prep time in half and my hair looks better than when it takes me a long, long time.
  6018. The process is very simple: First I either let my hair air dry to around 80% or dry it with a traditional dryer until it is 80% dry.
  6019. I originally purchased the item to save some time from my normal blow dry-then-flat-iron routine, but unfortunately, it did not.<br
  6020. I found my hair can be no less than 90% dry for me to use this brush on it

  6022. Let me start by saying I have fine, thin, shoulder length hair.
  6023. My hair is thin and fine.
  6024. My hair is fine and thin so it does not give alot of body.
  6025. Mine is not quite shoulder length and quite thin and fine
  6026. and I wanted something to achieve volume without having to juggle a large round brush and a hair dryer.

  6028. but it is not new at all, the box was open and the the wire cord was not tight together.

  6030. so it is easier to turn, and the brush a little longer because if you take too much hair at one time it gets stuck in grooves.

All Reviews

  1. The styler works great! The only reason I gave 4 starts and not 5 is because of the brush size. I wish it came with different (smaller) diameter brushes as well to accommodate for shorter hair style users as well.<br />Another thing I noticed is that my hair is more freezy when I use this dryer/comb vs my regular blow dry and hand held brush. SO, I would like to see the bristles on the brush be more metallic.<br /><br />Great feature is that the brush rotates in both directions, so if some hair is caught on the brush, it is easily entangled.
  2. Great, does not hold your hair very tightly so the curl is loose, but you can do great things to your hair with it if you focus.
  3. If I could give a negative score I would . Huge waste of money.
  4. Love this thing, it takes a little getting used to (the spinning) but there are many ways it can be used. If I want a lot of curl I use the low spin, roll and hold it longer, for a straighter more volume look I use hi and no spin and just add a curl at the ends. Works well, would recommend it.
  5. Very convenient and wonderful for travel.
  6. I'm not capable of doing my hair at all! I got this little guy. Did my hair and literally the first person I saw asked if I had a blow out. Miracle do happen!
  7. My mom gave me this as a present and I like it for the most part. I have super thick and long hair so the first couple of times I tried it, it took forever. However, the learning curve was really easy for me to grasp. I like that it doesn't rotate automatically, and often times I do not rotate it at all. The bristles are really soft so I have to do thin sections to make sure that it grips my hair. My hair looks softer and shinier after using this product compared to my old blow drier. Make sure to keep the cover and don't throw it out with the box. Always put the cover on after use to prevent the bristles from flattening. I found that for my long hair, I let my hair air dry for a while or blow dry it quickly with a regular blow drier then style it with this brush. It ends up taking the same amount of time to only dry my hair 50%. That is my only complaint. Decent price, especially if you have never purchased one before.
  8. Leaves my hair silky and shiny!
  9. I loved the product but with less than a month of use has stopped spinning, but does not turn heats, having bought on amazon do not know where to complain.
  10. Dirty item. Do not want to even touch it
  11. it's way bigger than i expected
  12. This product style my hair very easy and fast, I Have a long hair and this is not a problem .. is big for a travel, but in home works very good
  13. This works great with straight hair. It's not as easy as explained at first but you get the hang of it. Gets really hot. My hair looks shiny when I use this. I don't get as much volume as I expected. I don't like how I have to first dry my hair before I use it though, because it doubles my styling time.
  14. Honestly, I like it. I just wouldn't buy it again given the chance. It has allot of power so when operating, you must have a strong grip, or the machine will pull your hair and you will get it all tangled. One thing I don't like is, it isn't as controlled as the woman in the videos make it seem. It just spins and I have to maneuver my hair all the time. Its okay, but you can do better with a blow dryer and a brush
  15. I like it a lot. I was so excited to use it. I have a long fine hair and it works wonderful. The styler is quite big but it doesn't bother me. However my hair got tangled a lot if I don't section my hair well. I love that it rotates.
  16. This tool is excellent and works very well for my fine, limp, chin length wavy hair. It adds volume and gives it a nice smooth finish. It's very easy to use. I highly recommend it.
  17. Brush cannot hold hair to swirl. The type of bristles and the position of buttons are worthless. Great idea but needs improvement

  25. A friend of my wife has one and highly recommended it, so I ordered one for her. Now she doesn't use it much, but I do (my hair is much longer than hers). The rotating brush has sufficient power but air flow seems to be lacking. I had to experiment with it but now I use it regularly.
  26. I bought this because I wanted a faster and easier way to dry and style my hair.<br />Three things:<br />1. I tried to use it to dry, it didnt work. I had to brush and dry all the hair with a regular blow drier before using the product.<br />2. After having the hair completely dry, I used this product to style and give a better finish to the edges, and it was a big frustration. The brush is so floppy that it folds when it touches the hair. And my hair is straight. I can only imagine how bad it is for those who have curly hair trying to straighten it.<br />3. I even tried to use it after coming back from the salon, just to keep the style they had done there but again it didnt work. Not even to keep what was already done.<br /><br />Its not hot enough, it is only 110V and its not powerfull enough.<br />The brush is floppy. Its really not portable. It is a big piece of junk.<br /><br />I returned mine after 3 days.<br /><br />Maybe if you have really really (did I say really?) short hair it will work for you.<br />:(

  30. I cannot express how amazing this product is. I have thick hair that can be very difficult to handle at time.   40. For the first time ever, I do not have to use a flat iron on my hair after drying. My hair has a tendency to be frizzy after blow drying.   42. After searching and searching for the perfect one-handed blow dryer for my hair, I found the Conair Infiniti Pro Spin Air Rotating Styler. I read some reviews before I bought it, and was initially put off by complaints about the anemic air flow, but decided to give it a try anyway. My hair is long and tends to frizz, so I've been searching for a one-handed dryer that will not only dry quickly without drying my hair to straw, but straighten at the same time. I've used the Conair Infiniti Pro Wet/Dry Hot Air Styler for a while now and am happy with it---I love Conair's products in general---but the rotating feature was the one thing that would really make styling my hair so much easier.<br /><br />I'm glad I finally did take a chance on it---the big 2\\" inch round barrel is perfect for the length of my hair, and the bi-directional spinning combined with more powerful air and faster spin on the high setting gets the job done. The only BIG complaint I have is that the bristles are WAY too soft---they need to be stiffer in order to pull the hair better to straighten it and not become useless in a short time, or at the very least there should be a replacement brush. Generally, it's a good product and reasonably priced, but tweak it with much stronger bristles and you've got a real winner!
  43. Pros:<br />1. Dual rotation, it there are two buttons to rotate the brush in both directions, making it convenient for lefties and righties.<br />2. Travel easy, so much easier to pack than the oblong hair dryer<br />3. The bristles are soft<br />4. Cord is long<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. YANKS on hair! I was told that when you spin the brush close to the roots (for volume) that it would not 'catch' your hair and yank.....it did. And it hurt a lot.<br />2. If you have thin hair, or are concerned about hair loss, you will find A LOT of hair in this brush<br />3. The COOL setting does not allow the brush to spin<br />4. The air doesn't blow out strong enough, therefore, you have to dry your hair with a traditional blow dryer first, and style with this.<br />5. Can't control how fast it spins, when you're on low -- it will spin slow. When you're on high heat -- it will spin fast. That's it.<br /><br />All in all, I like it and will continue to use it because it's easier than traditionally blow-drying my hair which I hate. But I have to be extremely careful so my hair doesn't get yanked. This may not happen with people who have shorter hair. My hair goes down to my mid back.
  44. This blowdryer is awesome! I have thin wavy hair and when I use this blow dryer I don't have to do anything else to it. It gives it body and style at the same time. Goodbye curling iron!!
  45. I have thin, lank hair that wants to do its own thing, which is to flip every possible direction except where I want it. This styler dries and smooths my hair at the same time, gives it body and shine, and leaves it easy to manage all day. The curve it gives my chin-length bob is perfect. It doesn't tangle even when I hit the wrong button and make the brush spin in the wrong direction. The more I've used it, the more intuitive the buttons have become so that finding the right one is just second nature now. This styler worked well for me when my hair was to my shoulders and it works well now that it's chin length. Couldn't ask for more!<br /><br />If you have thick or even medium hair, you will need to blow dry it to about 50-80% dry before using this spin air rotating styler. But for those of us with thin hair, this styler works to dry hair at the same time it styles it -- and that extra time on the spinning brush makes the style hold that much longer. PERFECT!

  77. I looked at a lot of these rotating brushes before trying this, and I am more than thrilled with the product. The key is to dry your hair 85% with a normal dryer first - you don't have to style it... just get the moisture out from the roots up. Then section off and finish with the spin brush. I have medium length hair that is fine. I have always dried my hair with a round brush. When my husband retired, I told him he should at least help me since I still have to get up and go to work. So for the longest time every morning he held the blow dryer on my round brush while I turned and turned and turned... My shoulders and arm would get so tired, but him working the blow dryer part helped tremendously. Plus, I got compliments on my hair all the time. But... since the day I brought the Infiniti Spin Air Brush a couple of months ago, I have not needed or even wanted his help one bit. This spin brush does just as good a job plus it's kinda fun to do. I still get compliements on my hair. I am ordering a second one to keep in my gym bag for post-workout smoothing. I know the girls in the locker room at the Y are gonna be asking me a million questions when they see it. Poor husband. Once again replaced by a small electrical appliance. :-)

  81. This product is really fantastic, and I get amazing results - it looks like I've just gone to get my hair blown dry when I use it. It makes my hair smooth and shiny, while giving it the little flair at the ends that I've never been able to achieve with just a blow dyer. It's also really simple to use. Before purchasing it, I was scared that the spinning brush plus the heat controls might be too much for my hair, but the brush is surprisingly soft, which makes the spinning pretty gentle. I've gotten my hair only slightly caught in it once, but it was very easy to undo. Also, the heat settings are not really that hot. (So if you have quite curly hair and want them to be straight, you might want to pull it straight with a round brush and blow dryer first.)<br /><br />This product, however, will not replace any products you currently have (straightener, curling iron, blow dryer, etc.) - I find that because I have curly/wavy, thick hair, I still have to use the straightener for some of my hair if I want to achieve a straight look, especially at the roots of my hair where the SpinAir brush is less effective. Also, you can't really use the SpinAir brush on wet or even damp hair. I find that it works best when I have already blow dried almost completely (so that it feels dry to the touch on the outside, but still feel very, very slightly wet in the under layers). Also, because I have thicker hair, I have to separate my hair into sections to use it, making it a little time consuming.

  99. I LOVE this styler! It's easy to use and makes my hair shiny and smooth. My hair is a little longer than shoulder length and is thick and FRIZZY. I still blow dry my hair before using this - just a rough blow dry to get my hair about 80-85% dry and then I use the spin brush to style it. It gives my hair volume but also keeps it smooth. The only downside is that if you accidentally put too much hair into the brush, it can get stuck in the crack at the very to or very bottom of the brush area where it spins. My recommendation is to make sure you are sectioning out your hair and don't place too much into the brush while spinning it. That's my only complaint - otherwise, this brush is WELL worth the $$! :)

  107. This tool works pretty well, but it doesn't really dry your hair. You will need yo pre-dry your hair first. Also, be careful not to make your hair sections too big, or your hair will get tangled in the barrel as it spins.
  108. I'm terrible at doing my hair - especially when it comes to straightening my hair. Either I straighten too much and there is no body/volume, or I can't get it straight enough and curls pop up everywhere. The infiniti made it really easy to straighten my hair and give volume. I still had to use the straightening iron in a couple spots, but overall this is the easiest thing I've ever used to straighten and volumize my hair. No waiting on hot curlers, no trying to use a curling brush and a hair dryer at the same time, this was just one simple, straightforward process. Saved me time and energy and made my hair look great. I expect even better results as I get more used to the device. Thank goodness there are products out there for us non-stylist types. This will save me from the constant pony tails or curly updo's I typically resort to out of frustration.

The rotating motion is easy to get the hang of ... but even if you press the \\"wrong\\" direction, it doesn't make a tangle of your hair! I LOVE IT!!!!

My hair is fairly thick and hangs below my shoulders, and it tends to be a litte frizzy. With this my hair is smooth and shiny. Because I am not very strong I was worried that it would be too heavy for me to manage. However I can actually hold it in one hand. I am delighted with the result, and am surprised (with my weakness) that it is so easy to use.

  114. I just gave myself a blow-out...and it looks great! I have long, thick hair, approximately to my bra strap. My hair is def more silky and smooth. This product was perfect for my needs. It is for someone who normally blows out their hair with a round brush and hair dryer and it takes forever and never looks as smooth as the salon does it. It took a very short time to learn how to use the brush if you are familiar with blowing out your own hair with a round brush / hair dryer.. This brush did not save me any time styling my hair, it just helped me to do a beautiful job. You still have to go section by section which takes the same amount of time. The placement of the spin buttons worked well for me. If you did accidentally spin the brush the wrong way it was easily reversed with no consequences. I love how you can dry both sides of each section by switching to the opposite side of the section you are working on and simply spin the brush in the opposite direction. I air dried my hair to about 80% dry as instructed, and then used the spin brush on small sections at a time. What's great is that you have one hand free to manipulate the hair, instead of having to set the hair dryer down every time you grab a new section or reposition the hair. It did tangle my hair a little bit if I took to large of a section, but it is easily untangled by pushing the button to release the hair in the opposite direction so it was really no problem. If you have long hair, do not allow the hair to wind up more than once around the brush because it will not pull through, if that makes sense. Keep the hair going up and over the brush and basically brush through it while it spins. When you get to the ends you can curl it around the brush a little more. I am so happy with this product! No more expensive salon blow-outs!

Before I opened it, just a few minutes ago, I decided to read amazon reviews. Many convinced me to go ahead and try it. Wow. The brush is nice and soft. My hair looks great. It took about 5 minutes, tops, to style. My hair is just to my shoulders, long layers, fine. My big concern was that my hair would become one with the brush. Not even one time did it pull my hair. As for the weight--think of it as a light workout. My hairdresser has well-toned arms. I'm happy with the weight. It doesn't spin on cool. I think it might be a nice feature to have a separate cool button that you can access while spinning. Just writing that is dizzying, so maybe not a good idea:)

Also the air intake is at the bottom so no fear of over heating which I've done by covering the intake with my hand.   126. I had some doubts on whether this would work well and I'm pleasently surprised that it does even on my thick past-shoulder length hair! FANTASTICALLY! I'm not a pro but I often get compliments on my hair and know my way around curling iron and straightner. I've always had trouble doing a round brush blow-out on my own. I've watched how-to videos of all kinds but manuvering a brush and a blow-dryer is too hard for me! If I wanted a bombshell look I always dried my hair completely and had to use a large barrel curling iron essentially doing damage every time! With this I air-dryed my hair until it was about 70% dry (because I had time today, I would blow-dry on an average day)and read the full directions and tips. I really got the hang of it quickly and had half my head done in ten minutes! I DID NOT USE ANY PRODUCTS on my hair so all the shine and body I got was strictly from this item!!! I recommend reading the tips, and starting from the ends and rotate while pulling up and down on the section using tension as you go...just as you would when using a round brush and blow-dryer. I smoothed each section and then held it spinning close to the roots after that. Then I pressed reverse as I pulled the item down and out of my hair making a sprial--mimicing the technique a stylist would use. Then I finger brushed the hair and WOW what a great look! I cannot believe how awesome my hair looks! I fully believe if you give this a try you won't be disappointed!
  127. I absolutely love this brush. I have thick, slightly coarse hair, that's layered and cut just below the chin. Since using this brush, my hair has been so smooth. I do dry my hair about 75% to 80% with my regular hair dryer before using the spin brush. I know with as thick as my hair is, it would never dry in a reasonable amount of time with this brush. While my hair is still damp, I rub a little bit of argan oil between the palms of my hands and work through to the ends. Then I use the spin brush. It's amazing how well this brush works. I do not have to use a flat iron. I've had many comments on how smooth and shiny my hair looks since using it. I would recommend it for anyone, especially if you have short to medium length hair. It does take some practice or at least it did for me. But it is well worth it.
  128. I am one of the cosmetically clueless. 30 years old, and since i mastered the ponytail at the age of 18 (yes that's right, it took me until age 18 to figure out how to do a decent ponytail!), I rarely do anything to my hair for the sole reason that I am no good at it at all. A few years back, I went to a very patient stylist who labored to teach me the hair dryer/round brush method of doing my hair, and I managed to learn how to use a straightener after to tame the fluffed up broken strands that resulted from this process. At the end of all that, I ended up with a passable head of hair that would look decent for about an hour until i touched it, came in contact with wind, rain, sleet, sun, snow or otherwise did anything other than sit with my head perfectly still.<br /><br />Then I got this bad boy. I will adnit it takes some getting used to (a 5 minute learning curve for something hair inept like myself). I was concerned at first with the width of the brush. It is easily the size of a full two inch round brush or iron. I first tested on dry hair as soon as I got it out of the box. It did nothing really for my dry hair, except make it big and static-y. I do NOT recommend it for dry hair unless you have some sort of tamer or prewet it. This morning I used it on my freshly showered, shampooed and conditioned hair. I was worried about it pulling out strands, or tangling in my hair, but they have designed it so in order for it to rotate, you have to hold a button down (you can also direct the rotation clockwise or counterclockwise by pushing different buttons-super useful when switching sides of hair). Even when holding down the button I did not manage to cause tangles, rips, or pain in anyway (which i ALWAYS manage when using a manual round brush.) It took about as much and maybe even a few minutes less time to dry may hair, but I didn't need the straightener step. My hair feels smooth, has a nicely contoured shape and looks as good (or better) than when it is freshly done from the salon. My husband (the man of few compliments) even commented positively on it (Okay, so he said \\"How much did that cost me?\\"....but that's glowing praise coming from him :-) )<br /><br />Now for the disclaimer. This is NOT for short hair. with this big of a brush, I would assume your hair would need to be shoulder length or better (mine is just around my shoulders).<br />I don't recommended using for touchups to dry hair, unless you're looking for that \\"Just touched a light socket\\" look.<br />Be careful at the roots. This is a BIG FAT brush. When you put it to your roots on spin, you will end up with BIG FAT hair if you overdo it.<br />Be careful just past the roots. This is a BIG FAT brush. If you put it under your hair towards the top of your head, you could end up with UFO shaped hair.<br />Take the time to get your manual dexterity into alignment. You have to hold the button and position the brush. You have to make sure you're pushing the right button so that it spins the direction you want.<br /><br />Once you get used it, you'll realize that this is a GODSEND and worth every penny you paid for it. Thanks for reading, I'm off to look in the mirror and pretend I'm in a shampoo commercial :-)it is freshly done from the salon. My husband (the man of few compliments) even commented positively on it (Okay, so he said \\"How much did that cost me?\\"....but that's glowing praise coming from him :-) )<br /><br />Now for the disclaimer. This is NOT for short hair. with this big of a brush, I would assume your hair would need to be shoulder length or better (mine is just around my shoulders).<br />I don't recommended using for touchups to dry hair, unless you're looking for that \\"Just touched a light socket\\" look.<br />Be careful at the roots. This is a BIG FAT brush. When you put it to your roots on spin, you will end up with BIG FAT hair if you overdo it.<br />Be careful just past the roots. This is a BIG FAT brush. If you put it under your hair towards the top of your head, you could end up with UFO shaped hair.<br />Take the time to get your manual dexterity into alignment. You have to hold the button and position the brush. You have to make sure you're pushing the right button so that it spins the direction you want.<br /><br />Once you get used it, you'll realize that this is a GODSEND and worth every penny you paid for it.   155. My sister bought the infinity airbrush and brought it to thanksgiving for my mom and I to try. I was very skeptical of the as seen on tv product, but when I saw my sister's hair I was stunned. You get the tension a hairdresser achieves that I am never able to get on my own, and the result is smooth shiny hair. I don't even have to break my hair up in layers, it just grabs the underlayers as I move it down my neck. The only suggestion I have is to partically dry your hair before using it so it is lightly damp. Not the best with just out of the shower wet hair.   156. I was a little skeptical about this tool, but after a lot of user review research I took a risk and ordered it and I'm so glad I did. I have med-long hair (just a few inches below shoulder), and prior to this tool I had given up blowing out my hair because it was too time consuming and difficult with a traditional dryer and brush as my hair grew longer. As the product guide recommends for longer hair, I dried my hair about 70% of the way with a normal dryer (about 5 min.). Then I used the Infiniti Styler to do the actual styling (about another 10 min). The movement takes a little getting used to but once I got the hang of it, my hair definitely was smoother/less frizzy. It was also easier to get it into the shape I wanted with volume. I think once I get used to the buttons and the feel of it, the styling time will be much quicker and with even better results. Now I wish I had known about this styler when I had a shorter bob cut for years. It would've been so much easier with shorter length hair, so I'd definitely recommend it if you do. My main complaints are the size of the handle and the placement of the controls. The handle is pretty big which makes it kind of awkward and difficult to get a good grip, and I have big hands. The placement of the directional buttons which is basically a toggle left and right, isn't very ergonomic. I found it difficult to press the button precisely enough for consistent rotation at certain angles. It would also be great if the cold temp. setting was a simple blast button rather than having to flip the switch up another notch above the high heat setting. It's hard to do when you're working the top back of your head and can't see or feel the switch well. If they could work out those issues this would revolutionize at home blowouts forever!
  157. My hair is really fine, and hardly ever has volume. I've tried every product out there and usually have to work to get what little volume I can. This product makes my life so much easier! Its very easy to use, and holds the volume in. The only reason I gave it 4, instead of 5 stars is because its not a powerful dryer and if you have really thick hair it might take you longer. However, I suppose in the long run I save more time because I'm not trying to use a dryer, comb, and then curling iron.<br /><br />My friend has the same product, and her hair is as opposite to mind as it can be. Her hair is curly, thick, and long. Her hair has never looked better, and it was on her recommendation that I got it. Even though our hair is different, this product did wonders for both of us. The only difference is that since her hair is so thick, she drys some of her hair before she uses it to save time. My hair is fine enough where I don't have to do that.
  158. I love this styler! I have thick curly hair and it works great. Would recommend to anyone needing a good styled.
  159. This styling brush works well with chin length to shoulder length hair. It will give hair a smooth finish and slight under curl. If you need more body, you have to use another blow dryer first to get lift at the roots. For anyone that struggles with using a styling brush and dryer in each hand. This is a nice, quick alternative.

I bought mine elsewhere (in large part for the return policy)... and also because I was able to get it in blue. I came home, took a shower, and let my hair air dry for a bit, approximately 40 minutes, as suggested in many of the reviews I read. I have medium-short length hair, thick as can be and just as coarse. I read the instructions, took the styler and went to work. 20 minutes later I emerged from the bathroom, sweat free, and with my hair pretty much resembling the way it looked when I left the salon the day I got it cut. That has never happened to me before!<br /><br />I was skeptical that this was going to work the way I was hoping, in fact, I figured I was setting myself up for major disappointment with the expectations I had for the product. I couldn't be more pleased. I have never mastered styling my hair. Even using a flat iron takes me forever.<br /><br />20 minutes. Twenty minutes and I was done! I will definitely be recommending this product to my friends and family.

  169. Both my wife and I use this product and we both like it for different reasons. I have short (2-3\\" on top, 1\\" on the sides) thick, coarse and straight hair. I like this brush because the spin function can be used to either volumize or flatten a section of my hair depending on whether I spin with the grain or against the growth of the hair. Some reviewers have claimed this brush doesn't work well on short hair due to the large barrel size, but my hair is very short and I find it works great, I guess it depends on what you are trying to do with it. I use it to volumize my hair up top and flatten the sides/back, then I use a small flatiron (HAI twig) in a random fashion to create a tousled look. For me, this gives better results in less time than the same method using our normal hairdryer. My wife has long (mid-back), thick, coarse, slightly wavy hair. She mostly uses this product to blow her hair straight rather than volumize it. She didn't like it when we first got it, but after I took a liking to it she gave it another shot and decided that she did like it after she got used to it, its a different process than blowing hair straight with a normal dryer and round brush. Although it is much less powerful than our regular dryer (500w vs 1800w), she found that she could dry her hair faster using this brush because having a free hand saves her from having to section things off as carefully as with the normal dryer. Also she likes that using less heat is better for her hair. The only qualm she has with this product is that it does not dry her roots very well, so if she is in a hurry she has to hit them with the normal dryer first and then use the spin brush.

  172. I had never heard of this before but saw all the amazing reviews for it here on Amazon so I figured why not give it a try? I got it in the mail within a few days and couldn't wait to try it out. Let me just say, I need to order 2 more of these in case they stop making them. Now, normally my hair is wavy, a little on the fine side, but I have a lot of hair, it is pretty long, and blow drying it usually consists of rough drying it by about 80% then using a round brush and then a flat iron bc I can never get it smooth with the blow dryer. Well those days are over!! I was able to figure it out right away. There are 3 heat settings low, high and cool. The brush doesn't spin on cool btw. But this worked amazing! I still had to rough dry it. Especially for someone with a lot of hair or thick hair, bc the dryer on this would take a lot longer to do from soaking wet hair. But this is still a million times easier. It totally cuts out the round brush, plus you can do your hair with one hand. I just clipped it up in sections and was able to do my whole head perfectly and very easily on the first try within about 15-20 min. I didn't really have any problem with tangles, which surprised me because my hair usually tangles easily but if you get one just spin the brush the opposite direction for a second and it is instantly untangled. Now anytime I do my hair, it looks like I just walked out of the salon. My hair was sleek shiny and full of body without even using any products. All I put was a little light hold hairspray and it looked great all day. I have been using it ever since and get a ton of compliments on my hair now. I wouldn't really recommend it to anyone with really short hair only because the barrel is about 2 inches wide but shoulder length and beyond, this would work just fine. I wish someone would have come out with this a long time ago. A salon blowout at home, easy and under $50 bucks, you can't beat it. Very very happy with this product :)

  198. I love this hair dryer!! I have short, thinning hair, so I did not notice any of the problems that other users said they were having. My hair dried very quickly and the dryer was not heavy, possibly because I wasn't holding it as long as someone with longer hair. I used the original \\"Infiniti\\" with the spin comb for years and thought it was fine, until I used the \\"Infiniti\\" spin brush - the brush attachment is much better, in my opinion. Even though my hair is short and doesn't go all the way around the brush, I still find that I get more volume and lift from the spin brush than from any other method I have tried. I am a hopeless klutz trying to hold a regular blow dryer and separate brush, but I don't seem to find the two buttons for forward and reverse spin to be confusing. I do have to use a curling iron to add curl to my hair, but I get much better results by using the iron after using the \\"Infiniti spin brush,\\" than by using the curling iron alone. I can appreciate the problems other users are having, but if you have short or thin, or fine hair, this might just be the product for you!

  201. My old hot-air curling iron broke and so I searched for quite awhile to find a suitable replacement. After reading the reviews on the Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, I decided to buy it. I do like it but I think they need a few more sizes (smaller sizes) to get more diversity out of it. As it is now, it's kind of a one-note product. You can get a good blow-out but if you have long hair, you might find that you don't get very good volume without putting a lot of product in your hair first.<br /><br />Side note: If your hair is super wet, this brush does not work very well. You want mildly damp hair. I recommend wrapping your hair in a towel for a few minutes before using.

This product is amazing.<br />It is not for getting those curls and ringlets that you can achieve better with a curling iron or hot rollers, but it provides the polished, blow dryed look for easy going styles and casual work hair dos.<br />It takes barely 10 minutes for me to do my hair and the result is better than what I would achieve with 40 minutes with a blow dryer. The hair is also softer and shinier. The product says that there is minimal heat damage, Id still use a heat protectant though as the strands become pretty hot during styling. It does add volume like it claims, and it does curl the ends of the hair beautifully. To make the style stay, I use styling mousse before styling - for special occassions. Otherwise using just the heat protectant and the spin brush is enough for a ten hour work day!<br />I will give it 4 stars and not 5 because I think it would be better if the instrument came wtih various sizes for the thickness o the brush.<br />Another problem is the cool setting : it does throw out somewhat cooler air on cool setting, but the brush itself is so hot and takes so long to cool down, that the hair doesnt really 'set'. The air thrown out on cool setting oculd have been colder... but thats alright, I make do with turning the device off altogether and waiting.

  216. I compared a lot of air brushes like this one when my old one broke down a few months ago. I was hesitant about buying the Infinitipro because of the rotating function since I was afraid it wouldn't work well, but I was wrong. I've had this product for a bit over a month and it is great! I have thin hair in tight ringlets and it takes me about 15 minutes to style my hair with the Infinitipro. The rotating function takes a bit to get used to but once you know how to control the rotation direction with ease it is very easy to do your hair. My arm doesn't get tired anymore while trying to rotate the brush myself. My hair length is slightly lower than my shoulders but the big brush still does a good job styling it. It does not have a lot of power like a regular blow dryer, so it might not work well with very thick hair, but the high setting on mine is enough for my hair.<br /><br />Your hair needs to be almost dry, but not completely dry, for the product to work well. Since the high setting is not too hot it is easy to handle the brush without burning your fingers, and it has not damaged my hair. I really like the bristles in the brush because they are not the stiff plastic ones and actually resemble a regular round brush. So far, I love this product, and they only hesitation I still have is about the life of the product. I hope that it does not die on me on the next year, but so far it is working perfectly.
  217. After using the [[ASIN:B000JUV816 Conair SD6IS Ion Shine 1875-Watt Hair Dryer with Three Attachments]], a non-rotating \\"styler\\" blow dryer for several weeks at a friend's house, I decided to purchase one as I found the attached comb made blow drying quick, with results like I had used a separate brush and blow dryer (something I have never been able to manage). I extensively read both amazon and beauty website's reviews of different options and finally decided to purchase this Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, even though it was slightly more expensive and not exactly what I had been using.<br /><br />THE PROS:<br />-Orders of magnitude easier to use than a separate brush and blow dryer, with comparable results<br />-Shinier, smooth hair, especially when using the cool shot afterwards<br />-Relatively inexpensive for a hair dryer<br /><br />THE CONS:<br />-It is, as other reviewers mentioned, a bit hard to grip as it is rather large. However, I did not find this to be a problem. For those with rheumatoid arthritis, carpel tunnel, or small hands, however, it may be an issue.<br />-It is difficult, even after repeated use, to figure out which buttons make the brush turn which direction, especially if you switch back and forth between hands as you do different sides. Often, it is a matter of trial and error, which can get frustrating<br />-It does dry hair more slowly than a straight non-rotating styler brush<br />-There are no removable brush attachments and I find that the bristles do not penetrate my hair enough to really grab onto it and give you the grip you need to style<br />-It is a bit of an awkward size to do bangs<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE:<br />For me, I primarily want my blow dryer to more or less dry my hair straight with no frizz and I believe a straight styler such as the [[ASIN:B001330XFA Infiniti by Conair SD8R Tourmaline Ceramic Styler, Black]] does a much better, quicker job of that for a lower price. As I was debating selling it, however, my cousin visited me and used it. On her short hair, it worked wonders. It sculpted it nicely, made it glossy and smooth, and gave it that just-got-out-of-the-hairdresser's look and so I ended up giving it to her. I would say that if what you are going for is simply drying it straight, go with the non-rotating styler but if you have shorter hair or a style that involves a lot of sculpting of various layers, go with this one.sculpted it nicely, made it glossy and smooth, and gave it that just-got-out-of-the-hairdresser's look and so I ended up giving it to her. I would say that if what you are going for is simply drying it straight, go with the non-rotating styler but if you have shorter hair or a style that involves a lot of sculpting of various layers, go with this one.

  225. I have long, thick hair, and it used to take me about 20 minutes to blow-dry it, then straighten or curl, depending on how I wanted it styled. The Infinitipro cuts that time in half. While it's drying my hair, it curls the ends and straightens the roots and middle section of my hair. Plus, the ions make everything look sleek and shiny without having to add any product. It took me a few times to get used to using it, but even the first time still worked great. NOTE: make sure you divide your hair in sections, just like at a salon. I pin all my hair up on the top of my head and just leave a few sections at the bottom, then keep letting out sections until I get to the very crown of my head. Then I flip my head upside-down and dry/curl for a minute that way, which adds volume. Definitely recommend it!!

  229. This actually works. Im a klutz when it comes to using both a brush and blowdryer...so this was a great answer. My hair is also long and thick so I was thrilled that it didnt pull out my hair or getting stuck in brush. It does a good job...not perfect but more than I expected.

  231. I have EXTREMELY curly hair (it looks like an Irish dancer wig) and over half a year ago I stopped chemically straightening my hair for the first time in years... Which I didn't think about very much until I decided to get a very short A-line!<br />I always dried my hair in braids, even when it was &#34;straightened&#34; to be more normal-person curly, because that was the best way I could prevent frizz and end up with dry hair that was easily flat-ironed.<br />I tried the normal round brush and hair dryer method on many occasions for over a decade, and I'm just not coordinated enough for it or strong/patient enough to hold them up for the amount of time it takes trying to style my thick hair. But when I chopped off all my hair unthinkingly, I couldn't put it in braids or any kind of ponytail, so by the time it dried it was defying gravity and just could not be flat-ironed nicely. (And the cut I got was NOT made for curly girlies like me.) Then I found this product when I was desperately searching for a solution to my accidental high-maintenance nightmare hair.<br />This may give nice flowing bounce to hair that is naturally straight or long, but I have never straightened my hair so easily in my life!! I LOVE this thing. Now I can not only have short hair with layers, but I can dry my hair in no time, and I don't even have to touch my flat-iron anymore. It's much more gentle on my hair and definitely takes a lot less time than any method I (or a hair-stylist) has used for me before.<br /><br />My advice for use:<br /> --DO let your hair air dry most of the way before you use this styler<br /> --DO use the low setting unless you really need the high setting to set your style (less damage & fly aways)<br /> --DO NOT keep your finger on the spin buttons the whole time, your hair will still dry nicely wrapped around the unmoving brush<br /> --DO make sure your hair is BELOW the top of the bristles, using the top of the brush is NOT how this was designed to work<br /><br />If you notice your *Spin* is starting to lose its gusto in the middle of styling, it's probably because the little motor is overworking itself. And by overworking, I mean overheating. This is why I recommend using just the low setting and not over-doing the rotate function. Rotate works best for getting your hair into the bristles of the brush and catching tricky layers. The longer or more textured the hair you want to style is, the more likely you will have to manually rotate. (I am very sorry to say that this is not an actual magical hair dryer.)<br />This device is limited, like all modern tech, in its capacity to do work for you. You don't get to hold it in a static position and end up with fabulous hair with no effort at all. However, I believe this is the only cord I have ever encountered and not tangled, because it has a fantastic pivot base on the styler. So while you are required to still do some wrist-work, you don't have to fight a cord every time you move, and the dryer works fantastically without the spin function being on, so you only have to hold one thing. It might not live up to the perfect picture of convenience Conair adverts may lead you to believe it is, but in my opinion it does enough to be worth the money.<br />In 4 months, my spin in going strong (I don't push it, of course) but if I do ever kill the motor I will continue using this product without auto-rotate.r />If you notice your *Spin* is starting to lose its gusto in the middle of styling, it's probably because the little motor is overworking itself. And by overworking, I mean overheating. This is why I recommend using just the low setting and not over-doing the rotate function. Rotate works best for getting your hair into the bristles of the brush and catching tricky layers. The longer or more textured the hair you want to style is, the more likely you will have to manually rotate. (I am very sorry to say that this is not an actual magical hair dryer.)<br />This device is limited, like all modern tech, in its capacity to do work for you. You don't get to hold it in a static position and end up with fabulous hair with no effort at all. However, I believe this is the only cord I have ever encountered and not tangled, because it has a fantastic pivot base on the styler. So while you are required to still do some wrist-work, you don't have to fight a cord every time you move, and the dryer works fantastically without the spin function being on, so you only have to hold one thing. It might not live up to the perfect picture of convenience Conair adverts may lead you to believe it is, but in my opinion it does enough to be worth the money.<br />In 4 months, my spin in going strong (I don't push it, of course) but if I do ever kill the motor I will continue using this product without auto-rotate.

  233. Exactly as described. Is so easy to use and i get compliments about my hair all the time. No more wasting money on a blow dry at the salon, i can do it myself at home now in half the time!
  234. [[ASIN:B004INUWX0 Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, Black]] I love this!   235. I have shoulder length stick straight coarse and no layers asian hair, and I LOVE this product. It's my first time using a spin air brush and after about 10 minutes I figured it out. I start off with wet towel dried hair, apply a bit of volumizing mousse or heat protectant, then I blow dry my hair with my head upside down by bending from the waist. I get it to the point of slightly damp hair and then section my hair with flat pins. I use the spin brush on the low setting because on the high setting the brush dries my hair too quickly before I can get the volume into it. Plus, on the high setting the end of the barrel gets too high for my hands to guide the brush where I want it. I find that it helps to hold the brush at the roots for 10 second then unwind it without tugging. Let the section you just worked on to cool and don't mess with it otherwise it will undo the volume you just worked into it. When I'm finished I work a bit of shine serum into my hair, a little bit goes a long way. I went to showoff my work to my husband and he said it looks like I just went to a salon. I have to say that I would LOVE this product even more if my hair was layered; because with a blunt straight across haircut the ends tend to flip out due to the weight of my hair. I highly recommend this product to people who like the blow out salon effect. This along with my travel blow dryer will be my go to tools for when I'm traveling. Won't leave the house without it. ***NOTE*** if the effect doesn't give you the shine you want, you might want to use a defrizzing and moisturing product before blow drying and then maybe spraying a shine serum into your hair after using the spin brush. My hair looks like I'm ready for a Pantene swing your hair around commercial.
  236. product came as described. my hair is too curly for the product and takes a lot more time to style it.
  237. After a month of use, this styler has earned a mixed recommendation for this reviewer. Despite the advertised 50% less frizz, there was no significantly less frizz from normal blow drying. The rotating action tends to be too fast and can easily tangle up hair. Despite drying the bulk of one's hair, it does not dry the roots very well, thus there can still be a need to use a regular blow dryer. Overall, this reviewer would not rate the Infinitipro styler as being much better than a round brush and blow dryer, especially if one has curly hair.

  260. The spinning hot air brush is my favorite styling tool. Love the results. Finally, a solution for people like me, who has trouble wielding both a brush and a hair dryer at the same time. This tool gave me the sleek look I wanted, especially with the many layers I have which tends to make things more difficult. I really liked how the brush was designed with the many bristles, which grab the hair securely and pulling it taunt. One aspect that can be improved is the gap at the top of the brush. My hair tends to get caught whenever I take up a big chunk of hair. So be very careful in sectioning off your hair when you put the rotating brush on it. Another tip for users is to start at the root and continue to move the brush towards the end while its head rotated. If you keep the brush in the same place, hair can easily get tangled, which can be remedied by hitting the reverse button. Also, the brush doesn't offer a lot of heat to dry overly wet hair. Like many have suggested, you can first dry you hair with a regular hair dryer, but sometimes I like to allow my hair to air-dry before using the Infinitipro.

  284. First let me say that I really love the way it polishes my hair and adds lift and curve. Looks like a salon finish. Now a few \\"minus\\" issues...first of all it states that it is a 2\\" barrel, but it is really 3\\" because of the brushes, which means if you have short hair, or have short layers, it will not work for you unless your aim is to remove the curl. You need to have enough length in order to wrap around the barrel. My hair is straight, fine textured and cut in a chin length bob, so it works pretty well. It also has two buttons to change the direction of the brush. This is confusing when you change from one side of your head to the other, it seems to be counter-intuitive. The buttons are not marked and are too close together, so it's easy to make a mistake. Also, you should start from the bottom and work upward, going over the lower levels after working a higher level will give you knots. You should, of course, section your hair before you start. The main problem is the weight, it doesn't seem like 1.8 lbs is a big deal until you start holding your hand up in the air in one position for extended periods of times, makes for a lot of muscle fatigue. I would be happier with a smaller barrel (or interchangeable sized barrels) and a lighter weight. But even with the negatives, I like the way my hair looks, and it doesn't take that long to go from wet to dry and out the door.

First and foremost - it doesn't heat up enough. It doesn't heat up enough at ALL to create the *oomph* this size styler could give you. You can put this immediately away, after use - with no issues. It's not hot. It's warm. Secondly, the bristles should be stiffer. The soft bristles just kinda get smooshed by your own hair. I had such high hopes for this item.   291. I was so excited when I saw the TV ad for this Spin Air Rotating Styler and I ordered it immediately. I looked forward to my first use and washed my hair in preparation. The styler has warm, hot or cool air which just blows and then has 2 buttons to press for rotation forward or backward. The buttons are close together and it's very easy to hit one when you want the other. The bristles are very soft and they are not firm enough to catch my hair into the brush. There is no way that I could use this styler to go from wet to dry... It would take hours. I had to dry my hair at least 75% with my old dryer and brush before I could even use the styler. It did NOT add volume. I have long, heavy hair, so maybe this would work for someone with less hair. The results were not what I hoped or expected so I am returning the styler.
  292. I have shoulder length hair & I love it!<br /><br />If you have difficulty using a blow dryer & a brush, this is perfect.<br /><br />Also great if you have tendonitis or carpal tunnel in your wrists. The constant turning of the brush is not necessary with this.<br /><br />I will buy another just to make sure I have a spare!
  293. After reading the good reviews on this roller brush, I took a chance on it. My hair is rather thin and fine, and right now it is over processed and dry. Getting it to look healthy is very difficult. However this rotating brush really gives my hair a great finish! It is shiny and sleek and ends up looking like a pro has been working on it. I like that the heat is not as intense thereby helping my hair out, and I do not have a problem with tangling or knotting as long as I remember to section off my hair. Great product.

  309. I love the idea of this product. I have longer length slightly wavy hair. It makes my hair look very smooth and not frizzy. HOWEVER, there is \\"cap\\" at the very top of the product where my hair gets stuck in the seam/crack where the cap meets the shaft. When the product is spinning, my hair gets spun into the seam and pulls my hair and breaks it off. There needs to be no cap -- it should be one continuous piece, Also, you lose a lot of hair using this product -- you can see it in the brush after every use. I agree with others that the heat settings need to be improved. It gets too hot to use, I had to return it.

  311. I have long, thick wavy hair that requires LOTS of product year-round to tame frizz. This styler is the only way I have ever been able to blow dry my hair straight and frizz free. The process is very simple: First I either let my hair air dry to around 80% or dry it with a traditional dryer until it is 80% dry. Then, I apply a heat protector (Biosilk), use the styler, and finish with a little bit of Aveda universal styling cream to tame any flyaways. I was afraid the styler might knot my hair, but it never has in the month I've been using it. My only complaint is that, on rainy days, my hair will start to curl again. However, my hair does this even if I have used my chi flat Iron on the highest setting, so I think that's just my hair. This also makes my hair look way better than with a flat iron; it gives more volume and body like when my stylist uses a round brush to blow it out!

  328. I am so thrilled with this hairstyler! I was hesitant to pay the money that it cost but, wow, am I glad I did! My hair is cut in a medium length angled bob. Before I bought this I would wash my hair then blow it dry. I'd try to use a round brush as I dried my hair but it wasn't easy and I usually gave up. Then I'd use a curling iron or hot rollers to give my hair body and style it under at the ends.<br /> Now all I use is this styler and it only takes me a few minutes. You simply turn it on and hot air (medium or high heat, or cool) blows out through vents in the brush. Lift up a section of your hair and hold the styler at your roots. Slowly pull the brush through to the ends of your hair as you push the 'spin' button. Do this with each section and your finished.<br /> After just 7 or 8 minutes my hair is dry, styled, and full of body. If you're trying to decide if you should buy this or not I recommend you do. I could be happier.

  345. Ok ladies, here it is. I have natural wavy/curly hair, long and thick. Blowouts at a SALON take at least 45 minutes for me, so I'm not an easy sell. When I got this item I was hopeful yet dubious. GLORY! The thing works!! I let my hair get almost 90% dry before using it. This is key. Then clip my hair up, pull out a section and move through my whole head. Amazing results. My hair is shiny, full-bodied and swingy after using it, even more than a salon blow-out. The reverse motion really does prevent hair getting stuck or tangled. I have not even once gotten stuck, and like I said I have thick LONG hair. One hint: I start the spinning right at the root and slowly move down to the ends, then let it curl all the way up to my head. This makes sure I have the smoothing effect all the way to the roots. It's great. The cold shot function seems kind of pointless to me, but maybe it works for thinner hair. My only complaint is I see no way to clean the bristles at some point down the road. But I happily give this item 5 stars. Give it go, long haired, wavy girls -- it works.

  348. I'm trying to grow my hair out from very short, and it's now just below chin length. This Spin Brush has saved my sanity more than once. I just air dry my hair, and when it's almost dry just spritz on a heat protection spray and start with the Spin Brush. Sometimes I section, and sometimes I don't, and personally I don't see that much difference in adding that extra step.   352. I wasn't sure that I'd like this styler and was so pleasantly surprised at just how much I do like it. My hair is long, wavy and a little on the dry side, so I wash it every other day. I love this just as much for the days I don't wash my hair because it adds a luster along with smoothing out the \\"bed head\\". If you're on the fence about this, let me just say two things: the barrel is 2\\" around, so if you have really short hair - you'll probably need a smaller (skinnier) barrel (1\\")to get the full effects of this styling tool; and if your hair is thick and/or curly and wavy like mine, invest in some pelican or butterfly clips and start from the underside of your hair moving up piece by piece until you reach the top layer. You'll get smoother and straighter results that way and won't overwork the top layer (where the damage shows the most).

  360. This rotating styler has its uses, but it isn't for everyone. It's probably best for hair that's not too long and not too short. And you have to know that if you start with very wet hair, you're in for a long session with your Infinitipro Spin Air.<br /><br />The good news is that it's pretty hard to tangle your hair with it. You do need some eye-hand coordination to make sure you're spinning it in the right direction, and if you plan to end with dry hair, you'll probably want to air-dry a while first or else start with a conventional dryer. The Infinitipro seems to leave hair shiny and it certainly adds volume to my hair, which I like.<br /><br />But here are some things I don't understand:<br /><br />Why is it so big? It's 13 inches long and the handle has a circumference of 7 inches. My bathroom is quite small and this thing takes up WAY more room than I can spare. Your mileage may vary.<br /><br />Why don't they offer a smaller brush head? The brush is 6 inches around, and lots of people have hair shorter than that.<br /><br />If you're looking for an all-purpose hairdryer/styler, this probably won't be the one. But if you're in the market for its particular skills--and have room to store it--then you may be happy with it because what it does, it does well.<br /><br />Linda Bulger, 2011

  364. I have naturally curly hair that is very hard to straighten and to smooth. This Conair brush straightens my hair and smooths the cuticle while it is drying it. That's not all. I also had to follow it with an airbrush to smooth the cuticle. Not anymore. I do follow it with a flat iron. I always did that because my hair is too fluffy and curvy without it. The flat iron gives a look that I like.
  365. I absolutely love this product. My hair looks SO much healthier since I have started using it. My split ends have vanished and my hair looks more volumous and shiny. My hair stays tame up to 2 days after using it. I have long hair (down to my mid-back), I let my hair air-dry for 10 minutes, then dried my roots with a normal hair dryer for about 5 minutes, and then spent about 30 minutes with the actual Spin Air Brush. It was time well spent! Things you should know: 1. For best looking hair start by brushing through your hair, making sure there are no tangles, and applying a heat protectant/shine serum which will protect your hair from heat damage and tame the stray hairs, also add a mousse if you are looking for more volume/hold. I end by lightly spraying finishing spray (adds shine and light hold). 2. The air-flow is super weak. The air-flow on \\"high\\" is just enough to give it some shape- it will not dry your hair completely (or even close to completely). For best results, start with a regular hair dryer and work your fingers through your hair while you use it allowing your roots to dry completely. The rest of your hair can remain damp/slightly wet. Then section your hair and use the Spin Air Brush on one 2 inch section of hair at a time. It goes fairly quickly since your hair isn't too wet, and this will keep it from getting tangled and provide the most volume. 3. The brush does not have to spin, although it works much better when it does in my opinion. If you want the volumous look you can spin your hair up around the brush, hold it in place for approximately 30 seconds- 1 minute, and then reverse roll to release your hair. This will create a loose curl. If you just let it spin without holding the hair in place it will still give you some added volume, and the ends of your hair will roll under/out, but you will not have the va-va-voom effect like the model in the ad (fair warning). I definitely think that this product was worth the money. I have been getting so many compliments on my hair since I started using it! The benefits go beyond just the day you use it too, it really seems to have \\"healed\\" my damaged hair. I highly recommend it.
  366. I really like this hair brush, it makes my hair shiny and gives it a great shape.<br />It does not pull or yank hair out, and is easy to use. Saves so much wrist action and arm pain trying to get a style.<br />Highly recommended for shortish to longer hair. I have short bangs and sides in front and longer in back,<br />and you will quickly learn how to engage the roller for each length.<br />I am so pleased I found something that actually IMPROVES the result and lightens a previous chore.<br />It looks bigger than you think, but do not let it scare you, works really well.<br />Note, it does not roll when choosing the cold air selection, use low or high warm for the mechanism to engage.
  367. Don't get me wrong it is well contructed, but it just does not dry my wet thick wavy long hair. The only way this item could work for me if if I were to dry my hair 90% with a blow dryer than used this to style it. Unfortunately that would defeat the point. Sending mine back. Probably will work very well on fine medium length hair.

  369. I was pleasantly surprised by this product. I read all the reviews and decided to take a chance. It's not at all difficult to use and I got good results on my first try. I do not find it heavy or hard to hold. It does a good job on my chin-length, fine hair, but I will agree that it would not work for shorter hair, and Like some other reviewers, I would prefer a smaller brush. I have to finish my style with my smaller brush and dryer to get the volume I want. Overall, this is a good product and leaves my hair very shiny. For longer hair it would be perfect. If the brush was smaller I'd give it five stars.

I give it 3 stars because it was over all an okay product and in the end, it did dry my hair but that's pretty much it.
  372. I have very thick, curly hair (shoulder length). I have tried many styling products, but nothing really worked well - usually leaving my hair a bit frizzy. Using a flat iron removed the curls but left my hair flat. This rotating styler works great. I have no problem with it tangling in my hair. My hair actually looks better after a few hours and still looks good the next day. It is very easy to use and it didn't take long to get used to using the rotating brush. My daughter likes using it without rotating (she has much longer hair). With her longer hair, the rotating action tends to wind up her hair. But the styler works great on her hair without rotating. It give her smooth, full curls. It does get a bit tiring when using it, but maybe that is because my hair is so thick. I have started drying my hair a bit more with the regular dryer before using the rotating styler. But the result is wonderful. My hair is much more smooth, with a fuller look. Not flat like with a flat iron. This styler isn't perfect, but it is alot better than any other drying tool I have used. It would be nicer if the handle was a bit smaller around and if there was one higher heat setting (it has 2 heat settings and 1 cool setting). But overall I am pleased with this purchase.

I prefer using this brush over my \\"iron\\". Worth the money.

  387. I've had this spin brush for about a month and use it everyday. I think it's a great product as long as you understand what, I think, is it's intended purpose. First, I have very curly hair and there is no way this could replace my hair dryer. I don't think it's intended to. I think the hot air is just enough to blow heat through the brush to style the hair. Second, I think it's intended for medium to long hair. Mine is a chin length, layered bob with medium length layers and it's long enough, but the barrel is just too large for short hair or short layers. I blow dry my hair first with my regular styling hair dryer which has a brush on it - in my case to staighten as I dry. Then, I use the spin brush to add volume and lift which I could, only, get before with a round brush in one hand and the hair dryer in the other. I, always, felt like I needed a third hand. The spin brush does this very well and much easier. The best part about it is it spins in both directions. As you move from side to side or back to front, you don't have to be a contourtionist. Simply, press the other button and it spins the other way. This is fabulous feature. All in all, this is a great tool for adding lift, volume and slight curl to medium and long hair.

  394. I bought this for myself with Christmas money. I had read several reviews on this product and was intrigued. It is fairly easy to use once you figure out which way to make the brush spin. My six yr old daughter will actually let me use this on her hair too. She runs away when she sees me using the flat iron. The rotation actually tickles if you bump your ear, she is not afraid of being burnt by this. After I use the air brush, my hair has body for most of the day. I don't have body very long if I use a flat iron. I can't say for sure if it actually helps smooth my hair, but a neighbor commented that it looked pretty smooth. It is mostly straight, but in the back it goes wild. as a new mom I don't have the time to mess with my hair, which was half down my back until my baby was about 3 months. I used to meticulously section my hair and round brush it. I bought this hoping to achieve the same look as round brushing while drying. I feel that it is a success.<br /><br />The key is to let your hair air dry as much as possible. It still will take as much time maybe 5 or so min less, to get the round brush effect, but you don't have to break your wrists or worry about whether or not you are gathering the hair on the back of your head.<br /><br />Additionally, I find that using a flat iron is quick but my hair greases up fast with that, and my hair really needs to be dry to do that. So that process is no bueno, but this product will give you tons of volume, and your hair will grease at the same rate as if you had only used a hair dryer.<br /> I also don't section my hair as much any more, I use like 4 clips instead of 8-12, Its not perfect, but I at least look like I tried.<br /><br />I recommend this and think it would make a great gift for any girl/woman in your life who you've ever seen wear her hair in more than one style in a week.

It took only a couple of tries to get the motion down....don't grab too much hair, and pull away from your head when you start to feel resistance.   419. Don't believe everything you see on TV. When a product claims to be too good to be true, it usually is. That said, I went ahead and purchased this product yesterday at Target. Target's price ($59) was WAY more than Amazon, but I needed it \\"NOW!\\" and didn't want to wait. I woke up 10 minutes earlier than usual this morning and after I allowed my chin length hair to dry a little, I tackled my head with the spin brush. I was surprised that it hadn't taken me long to figure out which direction to spin the brush. If you are used to drying your hair with a round brush and a hand held dryer, this will be a snap for you to pick up. My hair is smooth and shiny and I don't have the flyaways that normally erupt. I was also able to tame down that natural dip/wave in the back of my head, something I couldn't do with a round brush and blowdryer, no matter how hard I tried. All in all, I think this is a pretty great product that makes it easy to get salon results at home. However, I don't think it's claims of super volume ring true. Maybe it's the length of my hair or my lack of experience, but I don't see the volume that I was expecting. It's been 2 hours since I did it and by now, I would be thinking of shaving my head. Not so this morning. It's still nice and neat and smooth. The only thing I wish it would have is a button to lock the brush in the spinning motion. I could see how operating this would be difficult if you had arthritis or shoulder/back/neck problems. You have to continuously hold the \\"on\\" button down with your thumb. By the time my hair was styled, my hand was starting to ache.

  423. When I came across this Conair product on Youtube I was intrigued. I watched reviews of so many people. Some of them loved it, some said it was so..so. Before this I owned Revo styler(I hope thats what it was called) & my experience with it was bad, it tangled in my hair real bad. So when I saw Conair Infiniti-Pro Spin Air Brush, I was skeptical. But lots of reviews said, it won't get tangled in your hair.<br />So, finally after long time of thinking & rethinking I purchased this from Amazon(as Conair is not available in India).<br /><br />At First Glance:<br />When I received my styler, the packaging was practical(company's packaging I mean). Big enough to hold the machine as well as small manual, nothing exaggerate. Box was quite tightly packed, so no broken parts. Actual machine is quite sturdy, not at all flimsy. Plastic material used was also quite good along with the bristles which are soft. One thing I loved about this product is that it got pretty good plug with that tester. At first I was very scared to put the plug in socket,as in India we don't use this kinda plug.But luckily, one plug point near my dressing table is suitable for this kind. Tester feature is also nice, I mean you won't accidentally blow your house apart,if there is any problem with styler.<br /><br />Experience with Styler:<br />When I got the product, I gave it a test run before actually using it on full head. As I am righty, doing my left side of hair was easy. Bangs was easy too. I can see the volume immediately. But when I was doing my right side of hair section, the spinning rotation got out of hand & the heated part of brush touched my skin just below my ear. It got burned, not really painful but anyone can see the scar. I am not going hold that against the styler as it was my first time with the product & I learned my lesson well.<br /><br />Next day, I washed my hair & according to instruction dried my hair 70-80% ,then put on some heat protectant & sectioned off the hair to dry my hair spin air style(YAY!!). It was quite hot on low setting for me(I don't use high heat on my hair ever & its a start of summer here in India,so pretty hot already). Dried my hair nicely without any trouble from dryer part of the machine. But I can't say the same for rotating part of the machine. It didn't tangle, but spinning used to stop suddenly in between & suddenly it started. At first I thought I am not pressing the spin button properly, but it wasn't that. Spinning stopped whenever it felt like to. Kinda annoying. Otherwise, it was good. But I paid about $69(incl. shipping), so I expected much more better. But at least its not as bad as that Revo styler.<br /><br />Amazon Shipping:<br />When I purchased this product, Amazon said I'll be getting this by 11th April(approximately 1 month after ordering). But it was a pleasant surprise when I got it on 31st March. Thumbs up for that. But I have to say, Amazon packed this in a way too big box. I mean, inside the box it was literally the machine in original packing on one side & some air filled bags on the other side.At least they should have put the machine's original box in the middle & put those air filled bags around for safety of the product.<br /><br />In short:<br /><br />Pros:1. Good quality material<br />2.Not much of a weight<br />3.Heating is sufficient<br />4.Nice plug with great testing feature<br />5.No need to learn how to juggle with Hair dryer & round hair brush.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1.Spinning stops suddenly during styling<br />2.Shipping is a quite nightmare for the pocket(for India)<br /><br />I hope to find the solution for this spinning problem I am facing as soon as possible. If I get it soon,I'll update my review here as well as my blog.<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />I can't really find any kind of an answer to my spinning problem,I even wrote to Conair directly,they said I should try one more time before seeking any refund or replacement. I did try with all the instructions followed to the last sentence. But still same issue. I am sending this back so that I can get a replacement for it. I like this product, its much better than traditional hair dryer & round brush exercise that my arms get when I try to use them.<br /><br />NEW UPDATE:<br />Amazon replaced it without much of a trouble. New one is quite good. Still stops,when fallen hair stands are stuck in the rotating part of the brush,but not as frequently as before. I increased a star because of that. I should increase one more for Amazon's AMAZING service. But this is a product review,so I am not going to. But Good Work Amazon.

I would buy it again as my hair does get straighter faster than if I used just a blow dryer and brush. My hair type is semi thick and course with curls and/or waves and frizz.

And it totally does!<br /><br />I had tried using round brushes before, and I hated it! The results may look nice, but it was a full upper-body workout trying to use the brush in my long, thick hair. I just turn it on and pull the rotating brush through my hair, and the end results look like I have way more talent than I actually do.
