  436. I am so happy I bought this product! For me it is a game changer. I have long, thick, coarse hair that is cut in long layers. My hair has a tight curl underneath, by the nape of my neck, and gradually gets wavy towards the front. Very odd. My hair is prone to frizz and the Houston climate makes it worse. I have never been very good with a hairdryer (inept is the word) and the only way for my hair to look great was by visiting the salon for a blow out. Not anymore.<br />The Conair Spin Brush has changed my life. I am now able to style my hair so that it looks soft and smooth with just the right amount of curl at the ends and tons of volume.<br />The brush does have a learning curve. It took a few go's before I was able to fully manipulate the brush without getting my hair stuck, as well as learning the buttons. By my 4th blow-dry I was doing well. My results are best when my hair is 85-90% dry and when I work in small-to medium sections. It took me a few tries to realize that the brush works better when my hair is more dry than damp. Initially my hair was getting stuck in the very top of the brush where 2 pieces of plastic meet, not in the brush itself. I realized that I was working with too large of sections of hair. The spin buttons also take some time to learn. If not for the learning curve, I would have given 5 stars. If I could, I would rate at 4.5 stars.<br />Its a bold statement, but for my hair texture and style, the Conair Spin Brush has improved the quality of my life. It really is worth every penny. My hair now looks finished, it looks styled. The blowout easily lasts 3 days (although the curls do fall).<br />I strongly recommend for anyone who is looking for soft, smooth hair, with volume.

  452. Seriously, the INFINITIPRO SPIN AIR ROTATING STYLER may be the best styling tool ever! The INFINITIPRO SPIN AIR ROTATING STYLER is a dryer, curler, and brush all in one. The brush head rotates and heats up as hot air blows through the styler, creating silky smoothness, brilliant shine, and significant volume. I have below chin length, very thick, wavy hair, and this little beauty gave me the soft, sleek, shiny look I have been craving. And it really did increase my volume! The INFINITIPRO SPIN AIR ROTATING STYLER also shortened my styling time and required very little product to finish off the look. I couldn't be happier with this little device!<br /><br />Now, there are a few tricks to using the INFINITIPRO SPIN AIR ROTATING STYLER, but they only took about 10 minutes to figure out.<br /><br />1. Read the instructions. If you have long hair or thick hair (like mine), Conair recommends that you use your regular blow dryer first. Get about 80% of the moisture out. Then use this tool to finish the drying and add the style you want.<br />2. It is not necessarily intuitive, but to get the rotation of the brush head correct, look at the position of your tool and how you are holding it. If you want the brush to rotate and curl your hair under, use whatever button is on top. If you want to curl your hair up, use the button that is on the bottom. Note the button you want to use will change as use change your grip. Just remember to curl under use the top, to curl up use the bottom. This has worked perfectly for me.<br />3. Make sure you start at the top of the hair and work down. This gives you gorgeous volume.<br /><br />Now, about broken hairs: personally, I have not seen any more that when I use a round brush and the blow dryer. Don't jerk or pull on your hair, and let the brush run through to the end. I've used the device for several weeks now, and have had nary a tangle or a knot.<br /><br />Overall, I am extremely pleased with the INFINITIPRO SPIN AIR ROTATING STYLER. My hair looks and feels great, it takes considerably less time to dry and style my hair, and keeps one hand free. For a Kindergarten mom, the look, the time savings, and the convenience are all priceless.feels great, it takes considerably less time to dry and style my hair, and keeps one hand free. For a Kindergarten mom, the look, the time savings, and the convenience are all priceless.

I have been using a Hot Tools 1\\" hot air brush to \\"straighten\\" my hair for a long time and I lose a lot of hair that way. NOT with this one. The bristles even feel good against your forehead when you do your bangs. Another tip: since it rotates two directions, depending on which button you press, when you're holding it up and getting ready to place your hair on the bristles, run the button you think is the correct direction against your other hand to see if it's rotating the right way you want to go. Otherwise it's a mess. This could even be good for kids hair, providing an adult does it. It's VERY GENTLE.

  479. [[VIDEOID:cd76d03c6dc6fe225472b09c02c0c01d]]Let me start by saying when I bought this I never intended it to dry my hair. It's 500 watts, that's not a hair dryer. After reading the reviews and watching a bunch of videos I was torn between this and the Babyliss. In the end I bought both. After testing over a month I am glad I kept the Infiniti as I will not go back to drying with a roundbrush . It would earn 5 stars for more watts.<br /><br />I have blond, curly, wavy, thick strand hair, thick hair. It was a grown out bob past my shoulders until I cut it again recently. I don't want to say coarse, but it can be. I round brush my hair because it makes it smooth and soft. It gets real tiring and it seems like these days I fight with the brush more than I used to especially with the gel and rubber handles they add now. I have very babied healthy hair, I use Joico shampoo, conditioner, re-constructor, and I think the other one is moisture recovery.<br /><br />Since I wrote my original review, not a lot has changed except I have been rotating back and forth between the two different products.<br />I don't recall if both make the anti-static claim, but my initial experience was the exact opposite, but after a few uses I forgot all about the claim and my original annoyance. The 2&#34; brush and the whole product in general is big. It is best that you watch the videos for a reference. It's not heavy or annoying to me.<br /><br />There is a learning curve and I can see how someone might suck their hair up in this as it has a pedal on the gas instead of the brake user malfunction. Also you can get your hair stuck between the end cap and barrel that I can best describe as flossing though there is no apparent gap there. It only happened once, but I was sidelined for a bit as I carefully rescued my hair. While mastering this product I initially sectioned my hair as when you work on one area it can pull hair from another twisting that piece around and around into a knot. Update: I have actually quit sectioning my hair and just drop a line down while pinning the rest up. I do get those twists, but am usually working too fast as I move across each section to cause any annoyance. I also tend to use my free hand as a guide similar like a shield over the rotating bristles and I &#34;revisit&#34; sections I have done.<br /><br />I just don't want to bore you with all my learning curves and what routine works for me. I more just wanted to share the video I am posting so you can form your own opinions.<br />On the first couple of uses I got impatient and aided with with my blow dryer on low. But I found out if I towel dry my hair well then flip the towel over to wrap it while I do my makeup it is just about right when I am ready to use it. An occasional blow dryer blast if I'm impatient.<br />Basically I like the feel of round brush blow dried hair as it feels softer and smoother.<br />I still do a quick sweep with the straight iron. I like the volume this provides, but still want my hair the way I like it.<br /><br />Since I cut my hair again I would like to add for others, if you have really short hair, then this brush will be likely be too big.<br />If you have short fine hair, I do not think this product would work because I'm pretty sure it is the thickness of my strands allowing them to catch on the bristles. I think fine hair would slip through.<br /><br />Observations I have made about the Infinity and the Babyliss (see video)<br />Appearance wise I don't see a lot of differences as you can see in the pictures. To correct some older reviews in case they are out of date. They both have a metal barrel. The switch on the Babyliss has an indented switch with one notch, the Infinity has no indents and 3 notches. On the Babyliss the front bottom of the handle has a 3 dimensional design with its name and logo to the left side of the front handle and the Infiniti has its name and logo in the middle. The back bottom right of the Babyliss is printed with information about watts and volts and notably is stamped Glendale, AZ. The Infinity is blank. The bottom of both have a plastic grill, the Babyliss is chrome colored while the Infinity is black. On the left side of the bottom of the handle the Babyliss is blank, but the Infinity is printed with information about watts and volts and again like the Babyliss is stamped Glendale, AZ. The printing is not exact, but you get the idea.<br />Both have cool, low, high, and off settings. They do not rotate when setting is off or on cool. Both have a nice thick, long swivel cord. They have different plug styles. Each cord has a label with a barcode. The Babyliss says: 74108 27045 and the Infiniti says 74108 24635. I ran back to check because I had not tested sound etc. The Infinity sounds a tad higher in pitch. I think it might rotate a tad faster, but it may be the sound making my opinion biased.<br /><br />If you made it this far. I know this review is a total yawn. Comment if you have any questions!ith information about watts and volts and notably is stamped Glendale, AZ. The Infinity is blank. The bottom of both have a plastic grill, the Babyliss is chrome colored while the Infinity is black. On the left side of the bottom of the handle the Babyliss is blank, but the Infinity is printed with information about watts and volts and again like the Babyliss is stamped Glendale, AZ. The printing is not exact, but you get the idea.<br />Both have cool, low, high, and off settings. They do not rotate when setting is off or on cool. Both have a nice thick, long swivel cord. They have different plug styles. Each cord has a label with a barcode. The Babyliss says: 74108 27045 and the Infiniti says 74108 24635. I ran back to check because I had not tested sound etc. The Infinity sounds a tad higher in pitch. I think it might rotate a tad faster, but it may be the sound making my opinion biased.<br /><br />If you made it this far. I know this review is a total yawn. Comment if you have any questions!

Painful!!! And it seemed to take forever to dry. I'm going to donate mine to a friend who has coarse hair that she needs to get thinned out, lol. Yikes, Conair. This one's a loser.

  488. I bought this Air Rotating Styler because of the rave reviews and am so happy with my purchase. My only complaint is cleaning the styler is difficult because the brush is not removable. I would recommend the option of a smaller brush for shorter hair. And speed of use without fatigue and time.

So I tried this after reading these reviews & InStyle magazine and watching the video demo. I can actually style it as demonstrated! My almost-shoulder length hair is soft, smooth and I can control the volume and flip. Smooth even on this terribly rainy day. I look and feel so much better. Will be perfect for travel. (I recommend the Conair carbon smooth brushes, too, for daily touch ups.)

I do not need a bunch of different tech tools.   492. When I saw this Infinitipro Spin Air Brush on tv, I instantly wanted it. A way to round brush my hair without having to hold a blow dryer and a round brush WHILE rotating the round brush at the same time? Count me in! When I round brush my hair the traditional way, I love how much volume and bounce I get. Also, I love when I get that curl at the bottom of my hair. When I finally broke down and bought the Infinitipro Spin Air Brush I used it and was less than impressed. I used it while my hair was wet and it took just as long to dry my hair as normal round brushing. A plus was that it was a lot easier, but easier is not always better. One of the drawbacks was that I didn't get volume. My hair was shinier and felt nice, but it was flat and limp even when using volumizing mousse. I then tried it on dry hair. It worked a bit better, but it definitely doesn't get hot enough. If it got hotter it would curl the bottom of the hair. No volume, no curl at the bottom of my hair. So If you want volume and curl at the bottom, this product is not for you. If you just want your hair shinier and straight then you'll love this product.
  493. I thought that this Spin Dryer would be great for traveling. I have long hair and all it did was get tangled in my hair. I returned it almost immediately.
  494. The one I got did not heat up, but Amazon provided an easy return with a refund. Look for something else, even if your hair is fine like mine.
  495. The concept is great but the design isn't so. The brush itself should be a one-piece item with the rotating feature at the base of the brush into the barrel but the brush rotates around the base which is stationary at the top and bottom of the brush which gets hair caught in between. And even on high heat, it's not really that hot so it took a lot longer to style my hair.
  496. The heat is not strong enough to style thick and curly hair, so if you have a hard to style hair that can only be styled with hair dryer and flat iron, then don't waste your money on this, it won't style your hair at all.<br />To me this thing is like a regular brush. Either way, I stopped using it. It was a waste of money.

However, the construction is cheap and the motor overheated then blew a fuse only after one month of 3ce/week use. I always made sure to keep it clean and use the cover provided, yet I am so disappointed that it didn't last more than a month.   505. I purchased this yesterday and today I went in my bathroom and got rid of the rest of my styling appliances....I wont be needing them anymore.<br /><br />I used to own a Conair stying brush that didnt rotate and went through 2 of them before that style was discontinued and I didnt like the one they replaced it with...the head was too small and the bristles too hard. I tried other styling appliances but I was never totally satisfied with them. I knew the first time I saw the InfinitiPro Rotating Styler that my problems were over.<br /><br />Yes, its on the large size and yes, its not meant for really short hair. But I have medium length hair so its works fine. It does exactly what I expected it to do...dry my hair, gently shape it and do no damage. I don't find it unwieldy, but maybe that's because I am used to similar appliances. As for the cord, I don't have a problem with the length. I do like the brush cover....great idea!<br /><br />I start out sitting on the toilet with my head upside down and start drying from underneath. I have been doing this for years and it helps to add fullness. The brush gets to my scalp and smooths the hair from end to end. Then when my hair is mostly damp, I right my head and, starting with the top, take sections and finish drying. Make sure not to do TOO much at a time...it can slow down the brush and might wear on the motor. It feels just like when my stylist uses a brush and blow dryer on my hair. I never could get that procedure down.....now I don't have to. It didn't take me long to get used to the unit and to the directions of the brush. I didn't have a problem with my hair getting caught, either....just make sure before you put your hair against the brush that its moving in the right direction. My hair is smooth, shiny and feels great! The only thing I can think of that might be considered a downside is that you cant remove the brush to wash it. Still, I only use it on clean hair and its easy to remove the hair after I finish.<br /><br />I got my styler on sale but I think its worth whatever you pay for it.<br /><br />UPDATE 12/23 - I bumped into my stylist while Christmas shopping today and she raved about how my hair looked. I had just washed it and used the InfinityPro to dry and style it. I figure if my stylist liked how it looked, the appliance must be doing the job. But, in any event, I am VERY satisfied with it....it really makes my hair look like I just left the salon. I hope it NEVER dies or, if it does, that Conair never stops making it! :D
  506. This item makes round brush drying much easier. Especially for people with long hair. It's still not as good as a salon round brush blow dry from a stylist who can see the back of your head, but it certainly beats holding a brush in one hand and a blow dryer in the other!

  510. I have been a hairstylist for 34 years. I recently had hand surgery and have had to manage my hair one-handed. I used it for the first time today and was able to make my hair smooth and full. I was thoroughly impressed. I've come across many tools and products over the years and this one is one of my new favorites. My daughter used it today also. She has chin-length, straight hair with some fringe. It turned out full instead of flat. She loves it too. I have layered chin-length hair. I was able to pull out the wave and give it the direction I wanted. I used a blow-out spray instead of heavy product, which made dry time much quicker. Can't wait to use both hands!
  511. I tried my spin brush for the first time today and was very pleased. I honestly wasn't expecting too much, but decided to give it a try anyway... and I'm so glad I did!! I was able to dry and style my hair in literally about 4 minutes!! Now I do have very fine hair, so I'm not sure how well it would dry with thicker hair, but for me I didn't do any drying at all before grabbing the spin brush. It was very easy to use, and seems to be impossible to tangle your hair. You don't even really have to spend any time gathering the section you want to work on... the brush naturally grabs it for you while it's spinning. I love that you can control the spin easily too. You can spin either way with just a push of a button and you can stop and go as you please. My hair is just above chin length and the brush size worked well for my purposes, which is to get more volume and smooth mostly. It certainly didn't make my hair curly, but that's not what I was going for. I really couldn't be happier and this will save me so much time in the morning!!
  512. I have an inverted bob,short hair in the back to about 3\\" below my chin in the front. This brush is absolutely amazing. This brush is a great combination of the Revo and the Revlon round brush hairdryer.<br /><br />The brush turns in high and low speed, it does not turn when the cool air is on. The brush also turns in both directions. Watch some of the videos on Youtube for some great tips for use.

  517. I have very thick wavy (often frizzy) hair. Lazy about styling, I usually wash it, go to sleep with it wet, wake up to it still damp, put it in a bun and by the end of the day it will be dry and wavy in a less frizz/more controlled way...not great...but not terrible. I got this product on a whim. I let my hair air dry for about an hour (it's REALLY thick) and then couldn't wait any more to try this gadget out. All I can say is it is absolute magic. My hair never dried so fast or styled so easily. It is super smooth, shiny, and full of body. I have to admit I was a bit panicked the first time the brush crept up to my scalp. I imagined it getting tangled and burning me. But it's really impossible to get your hair tangled. The brush is so soft that you can always just gently pull it out or use the button that spins the brush in the opposite direction. Super easy. Don't panic. Also, my hair is so thick that I worried if these soft bristles could grab it but they do an excellent job. I couldn't be happier with the product.

  519. I was very excited to get this. I figured it would save me time by combining the blow drying AND styling. This was a far bigger pain than it was worth in my opinion. First, let me say that I have long, wavy, thick hair. I started by washing my hair and letting it dry halfway (I knew if I did this when it was straight-out-of-the-shower-wet that I would be at it for hours) The brush is big. A little bit cumbersome. Getting used to the spins was a little tough for me. For those that say \\"It can't get tangled!\\" are lying. You can DEFINITELY get your hair tangled in this if you aren't paying attention. For me, it was just ok. You can't take big pieces, and you have to run the brush over the same spot many times. And you can't always have it spinning (or you will tangle it) I ended up returning it, it was just too much work. For the same amount of time, find yourself a really nice round brush. I think this would probably be a good product for thinner, shoulder length and shorter hair.
  520. I bought one and liked the idea of this styler: Hair dryer AND rotating styling brush in one tool. It's great for people with arthritis in their fingers. The diameter of the brush was too large for my hair to curl around it, so the ends didn't curl under; they stood straight out! I returned the one I bought because it made a tinny ringing sound and I was concerned it was defective. If Conair made this with a 1.25-1.5&#34; barrel, or if they put a cover over the barrel to curl the hair around the barrel, it would be a great tool. If your hair is not layered and is cut below your chin, this styler should work fine for you. Conair, I hope you see this review and make a smaller rotating styler.

I don't think you would want to purchase this if your hair was much shorter than mine. I still use a hand held dryer to get my hair to the point that it is damp-dry before I use this infiniti styler. I would highly recommend that you practice styling with this as I did to achieve the look you want.   537. I have fine to medium hair (shoulder length) and I bought this styler because I cannot master the technique of using a round brush while blow drying. I dry my hair with my hairdryer first (about 80-90% dry) or let it air dry and then use the rotating styler to smooth out my hair, give it volume and curl the ends the way I want them. This product allows me to come the closest I ever have to achieving the look my stylist does with a round brush! My hair does not get tangled in it (and if it does a little, it is easy to untangle) It takes a while to get \\"the hang\\" of using it and making the brush rotate the way you intend, but I really like the results and the ease of use. Other folks have said that they can get the same results with a curling iron, but I don't think that for my hairstyle that I can. Also, I travel a lot and I can immediately pack this product after using it (which I can't do with a hot curling iron). I just can't give it 5 stars because it really isn't powerful enough to dry your hair. And, I did find it more difficult to use with wet hair.

  539. I'm very excited about this product. I just bought it last night and can't believe the great results. I've been wondering if there is something that can tame my wavy, coarse, thick, tending to be frizzy hair. I've never gotten good results blow drying and styling at home. My hair is a lot of work to tame and it seemed only the salon could smooth it out and make it look good after 40 minutes of blowing and round brushing. Well, I have to say, I think I've found the home hair styling tool I've been looking for!<br /><br />Here are some tips: Semi-dry your hair so it's not completely wet. And be sure to comb out any tangles.<br />When I first started the rotating brush, it actually grabbed my hair and started to tangle and pull it! Yikes! But wait - I gave it a few more tries and figured out how it works. It just takes some practice. The brush rotates in two directions and you have to figure out which way to go. And I think it helps to hold it under the brush at the bottom and coax it along for creating a flip or curl under on the ends. And tension helps too as you pull it down your hair. I can see that the more I do it the better I will get. But the rotating brush makes all the difference. It really does help smooth out the hair shaft and my hair looks full with body but not frizzy and out of control.<br /><br />I think this is a great tool to get that salon look at home. Give it a try!

  548. I actually bought from Ulta beauty supply which was an impulse buy. But I love it so much I wanted to write a review since I often rely on user reviews when purchasing products.<br /><br />First off I have shoulder length hair that is cut into an inverted bob that is pretty damaged from bleaching and heat styling. My hair is thick and dry but not coarse. Usually I style with a round brush and dryer and follow with a straightener where needed.<br /><br />I found this pretty effective at drying my hair, completely. I've read some reviews that it's not meant to completely dry your hair but I was able to go from semi-wet hair (I always let mine air dry to some extent to prevent too much heat damage).<br /><br />Was pretty easy to use, the brush was able to sweep through my hair to smooth without getting tangled or pulling. I do wish the brush was a little smaller since I have shorter hair, or that there was an option to change out brush attachments. Also it doesn't make sense to me that you cannot use the spin mode on the \\"cool\\" setting. It was a little tiring holding down the spin button but nothing I couldn't get used to.<br /><br />Overall my hair dried in about the same time but was significantly shinier and smoother and did not need a straightener. I definitely like using this over a round brush and dryer because it is easier, and was able to perfectly dry the back of my hair and my roots which was always a challenge.<br /><br />I would recommend this product to anyone with shoulder length hair or longer. I can't see this product being effective for coarse/curly hair, or shorter hair.
  549. The best brush ever!!!! My hair is fluffy and shiny every time I use my brush, I makes my hair look like I just got it done by a professional hair styler. It makes my life so easy now that I have a short hair. I wish I had got it sooner!!!!
  550. Since I purchased this product I have yet to have a bad hair day, and for those uncoordinated people (like myself) its one of the best hairstyling products I have ever used to give an at home blowout. I have fine, straight, just-past shoulder length, layered hair that goes frizzy when normally just styled with a blow dryer because it is so fine and thin, even though I have a lot of it. And I live in the humid southeast. But since practicing with this tool, I have had a lot of people tell me what great hairdays I have.<br /><br />So, here is my process learnt through elimination and experimentation:<br />Towel dry, and then like other reviewers have mentioned comb it out straight. Then I put a volumizing mousse at the roots and give it a rough dry with an ionizing blowdryer. The spin brush is not as hot as a regular dryer so to use it on damp hair (rather than full wet) is a lot easier and faster.<br />Then I take each section, spin it dry, wrap it around a velcro roller and duck clip it, working my way from the front to the back. It takes about 10 min. And finally when that is done, one final blast with super hot air from the blowdryer to set each roller. After removing the rollers, a quick spray with hairspray and viola! GREAT. HAIR. PERIOD. Shiny, not frizzy, super soft with lots of movement, and just plain fantastic.<br /><br />My only complaint is that the bristles seem to flatten over time with use, and hair does get caught in the spinner if the section is too wide, so just watch out!
  551. Best new product for hair since the invention of conditioner. I loved it so much I bought one for each of my girlfriends for Christmas.
  552. How did I live all those years without it? Got one for all the girls in my family for Christmas.
  553. I am disappointed because I was really looking forward to having a salon style blowout. I do a better job with my round brush and blow dryer. I also feel like it is damaging the ends of my hair. Bummer, I was hoping it was all the reviews said it would be.

I am not sure it works in reality. I may have to return this.

  574. I have never been good at trying to hold a round brush in one hand, the hair dryer in the other hand, and trying not to get the brush tangled in my hair all at the same time. This device combines the round brush and hair dryer all in one. It has three temperature settings: a low and high setting with heat and a cool setting. It has a button at the top which controls the direction you want the Spin Styler to turn. The bristles of the brush are anti-static which is really great for fine hair which tends to flyaway. This hair tool makes it much easier to achieve great-looking hair.
  575. Best hairdryer/spinning brush I have ever used. Very reasonably priced and extremely easy to use. It puts out enough heat to dry my hair quickly without burning my scalp. Impossible to tangle hair as I tried to see if it would. It has two separate buttons that spin in opposite directions that are located close together. Works best on wet hair, but has several heat settings including cool. Will work on 2 1/2 inch bangs is made for use on longer hair. Leaves hair smooth and gets rid of the frizzies on my curly hair and if you get close to the scalp it will add a very noticeable amount of volume to your style.
  576. Product not good for curling or giving body. If you just want to straighten it works great, but makes hair pretty limp.
  577. I watched a few YouTube reviews by women with hair as close to mine as I could find before I decided to try this product. The ladies in the videos made it look so easy that I decided to give it a try and here are my results:<br /><br />First off, my hair is half way down my back, very thick and wavy. The texture of my hair is coarse and tends to be frizzy before styled.<br /><br />Personally I am very pleased with the spin brush using it on fully wet hair. However, when I followed the directions and air dried my hair 80 - 90% (as recommended) I got frizz and poofy hair that required a straightener to smooth down into a style that I felt was presentable.<br /><br />Normally it takes me an hour to style my hair after it air dries using my Chi Flat Iron and tons of product. This was a one step process that took my hair from completely wet to styled in around 20 - 25 minutes which I found very impressive. I used a few sprays of hair strengthener, a thermal protector and a drop of smoothing serum to assure that I got the best results on both the wet and mostly dry hair methods.<br /><br />My concern is with the completely wet styling method. Hair is at its weakest when wet and the styler could snap the hair off during styling and to be honest with you I did notice a few strands of hair in the spin brush after styling.<br /><br />I have only had my spin brush a short time, and I love the time saving that the wet method allows me but would love to hear from someone who has used the styler long term about hair breakage and damage.

  649. I can't say enough about this Spin Air! I have been using this for a little more than a month. I went to you tube to view how others were using it since the directions aren't too explanatory. I gave it a try and was really pleased with the results. It does take a little time to get used to controlling it.<br /> I usually dry my roots some, with my hair dryer. Then I let hair air dry till it is about 70% dry and then use the spin brush to finish drying and set the style. I separate my hair into sections with clips. Using smaller sections, no wider than the brush helps, to maintain control of styling.<br />I had shoulder length hair when I first bought this brush. My hair is thinner, straighter on top and sides, but thicker, curlier in the back. I was able to use this brush for a blowout, and was I ever ecstatic. It was the first time I ever got a great blowout at home, that gave me the look I get from the hair salon. I was so impressed.<br />Now, this past week, I had my hair cut an inch or so shorter, to barely at top of shoulder, so it's more of a bob. It does a great job, looks just like I went to the salon.<br />Also, it makes my hair so shiny and soft. I can style my hair in about 10 minutes. Really great for doing a quick touch up.<br />Now, because my hair is so thick in the back, when I put this on low speed, it sorta 'drags' and doesn't spin as well, but the higher speed does just fine. Definitely very happy with this product. Hope this helps anyone trying to make a decision. And, I found Amazon to have the best price.

Well, now I air dry if time permits to about 20% damp, get out the infiniti pro and go to work. In just a few minutes, my hair is dry, smooth, curved and shiny. At first I got it tangled a lot and thought I would have to give up. Then I discovered that holding the ends of the hair straight out from my head with my fingertips, use the IP on the underside of the hair strand, gradually moving down to the ends, it dries faster, smoother and painlessly with no tangles. I really like this tool.

  832. I love everything about this gadget, except it doesn't get hot enough so it doesn't hold a curl as well as it could. Also, it doesn't do a great job grabbing the hair and holding on as it spins. You have to use your other hand constantly pushing against the bristles to force the hair to stay around the barrel. I ended up returning it because of these two issues. Other than that, is an awesome concept! Especially the multidirectional rotating barrel. I cannot find that feature in any other rotating barrel blow dryer, which means I'm stuck waiting until I find a design that does so before I repurchase one. FYI, I have short to medium hair. The multidirectional barrel is critical because what happens if you don't have this feature is it's very awkward to use on both side of your head. Without the ability to switch directions, if you're flipping the hair upward at the bottom of your hair on one side with the rotating barrel, when you switch to the other side, it curls the hair under instead of over. make sense? Therefore the multidirectional rotating barrel is the most critical feature on this type of gadget. The first company, other than the Conair Infiniti, that comes up with this feature, that also grips hair well enough and gets hot enough, I'll be the first person in line to buy it!!!!
  833. This product has worked great so far. I'm a black woman with thick natural hair and not once has it gotten tangled or quick working. It dries fast and my hair is shinier and softer than using a regular hair dryer.
  834. Okay, here's what you need to know about me to understand what a big deal this 5-star review is:<br /><br />1) I have crap hair. Seriously. I know women always say they have crap hair, but I really do. My mom had baby-fine, very curly hair, and my dad had baby-fine very straight hair. So I have baby-fine hair that is curly underneath and straight on top. Even my stylist says that I have the most \\"challenging\\" hair she's ever worked with. (\\"Challenging\\" is her nice way of not saying \\"crappy\\".) Even my husband, who loves me very much, says he thinks I'm beautiful but he understands why I get frustrated with my hair. Seriously, it's a complete mess.<br /><br />2) I'm 46 years old. That means I've been dealing with this crappy hair with more than three decades. I have tried everything: every product, every dryer, curler, straightener, brush, every cut -- with bangs, without, long, short, etc. You name it. I've tried it to make my hair less crappy. I have some skin in the game, and I'm no rookie.<br /><br />3) As much as I have struggled with my hair, I am lazy at heart, and I DREAM of having hair I don't have to spend ridiculous amounts of time on just to make it look kind of normal. What I want, more than anything, is something that will be easy, and make my hair look like it's not a frizzy ball of crap. Any successes I have had were minimal at best, barring a product or two that at least helped me tame the beast.<br /><br />So. Now we come to the Infinitipro styler. Oh. My. GOD, does my hair look fantastic right now.<br /><br />I just got this thing a couple of days ago, and I cannot believe how fantastic it is. Friends, this is a revelation. I seriously can't believe it. I was sure the bristles would be too soft and would make my hair flyaway and staticky. Nope. I was sure that it would take forever to dry my hair with this thing. Nope, it took me less time than my dryer and brush -- by a long shot. Now, the one caveat is that I did use my blow dryer to blow most of the moisture out of my hair first. But barring that, the Infinitipro dried my hair in about half of the time that I generally take in the styling phase. My hair looks glossy, it is doing what I want it to do, and I didn't have to struggle with a dryer and a brush at the same time. I haven't used the spin function yet because I've wanted my hair straight, but I think I will probably try that this weekend for a look with more volume.<br /><br />I would recommend the Infinitipro to anyone with fine hair, especially someone with shoulder-length hair like mine. I just can't say enough about it. I even canceled a haircut appointment I had for today because my hair looks so good right now that I'm able to think about growing it longer for the first time in years. So, who knows, maybe it will even save me money on haircuts in the long run? :-)

  842. Now, don't get confused... Unless your hair is short or thin or way above the shoulder, you won't be able to take it from wet to dry with this in less than an hour. Mine is mid-back, layered and I've been dying to have more volume/bouncyness without spending a lot of time with a hairdryer and a round brush. So here is my routine to get the shine, the bounce and minimize the damage. Wash no more than 2-3 times a week - there is no &#34;eek&#34; factor here, I promise... Read on... To get best results with your new Styler, start with a deep cleanse by adding 2-3 tbsp baking soda to your usual amount of shampoo. Mine is Shiseido Tsubaki Head Spa shampoo. After that, apply rich conditioner to ends only - nape to ends - Nexxus humectress ultimate moisture deep conditioning treatment or Giovanni Ultra Sleek Conditioner. Rinse, wrap your hair in a super absorbent microfiber towel. Once you feel enough moisture has been removed, unrap and apply a light mist of My Amazing Blow Dry Secret Quick Dry Shake 'N Spray (yes, it will make you spend less time with your beloved hairdryer!). Blow dry your hair until almost dry. Add a very small drop of Kim Vo Perfect Polish Dry Serum (no greasies, I promise! $55 retail?! Don't think so! Check your local TJ Maxx to score it for $9.99!) and go for it with the styler. I did not find the spin function super handy for my longer hair gets tangled up a bit, but it might work for shorter hair. The key is to wrap your hair around the brush and then hold it, just like you would with a a curling iron. Carefully release and repeat on other sections of the hair. Follow with a hairspray. Don't get scared of the routine - remember, you only do it 2-3 times a week, because you just got your Styler! Here is the trick: next morning you may easily refresh your bouncy hairstyle by spraying your hair with some restyling mist - such as Shiseido Styling Mist (mine is in a blue-ish bottle, around $10) and go at it again with the Styler. Repeat every morning (about a 5 minute routine to refresh your hair!) until you feel the need to wash. Your hairstyle will be as good as new. Very pleased with my purchase. Damage reduced, my hair is bouncy, shiny, beautiful hair - wishing you the same! :)about a 5 minute routine to refresh your hair!) until you feel the need to wash. Your hairstyle will be as good as new. Very pleased with my purchase. Damage reduced, my hair is bouncy, shiny, beautiful hair - wishing you the same! :)

If you rotate the wrong way your hair will get caught up and it feels like it is pulling your hair out. It does get easier after the first few times, but I still occasionally get it going the wrong direction because you really can't see the buttons when you are using the device.

  865. I have extremely thick wavy, frizzy, shoulder length hair which I usually blow dry, flat iron and then use a curling iron to lift the roots. In all it's about a 45 min process. With this wonderful invention I'm done in about 15-20 minutes and it's the closest to a salon blow dry I've ever managed on my own. It smooths my hair so beautifully I am cutting back on my usual combination of 3 smoothing products. I'm changing to just one heat protective serum. It's so easy to use I'm surprised by the reviews saying it is difficult. If you aren't comfortable using styling tools, perhaps you shouldn't review them...just sayin =) A few salient points: 1. I have thick, wavy hair so that's all I can comment on. 2. Partially dry your hair before using this. It is best for styling and it will be much faster if you just turn your head upside down and either blow the roots for a couple of minutes or shake your hair out and let it air dry a bit. 3. Be sure and section your hair. Pin it up and start with the bottom sections first. Go all the way around your head drying 2 or 3 inch sections...this tool can handle a good bit of hair at once. Then pull down another row and so on until you get to the crown. I blow dry the crown up for volume. This sounds long but it goes really fast. High heat will get the job done in a couple of passes if your hair isn't too wet. 4. You can finish with a flat iron but you probably won't need to after a bit of practice. This is great! Much healthier for your hair. I find this leaves me with a more natural bouncy style and not that weird overly straight look the flat iron can create. 5. This is not for short hair. It's a really big round brush and if you wouldn't use that size brush with a blow dryer it doesn't really make sense to use this product. Maybe they will come out with a smaller brush for shorter hair. But I've had short hair and it's so easy to blow dry I don't know why you need something like this. 6. If your hairis like mine, you are going to feel like the gods of small electronics are smiling on you (finally!) Modern technology tames Mother Nature! For my type of hair...this is the best product in decades!
  866. I have long, naturally curly, very thick hair. Doing my hair in the morning was taking entirely too long. Blow drying takes forever, and makes my hair frizzy and then I had to straighten or curl which took even longer. When I saw this I thought all my problems were going to be solved! I could not wait!<br /><br />Good Points:<br />Made my hair very soft! It added a good amount of volume to my hair and didn't make hair frizzy or unhealthy.<br />Bad Points<br />The first few times I tried using it, my hair kept getting tangled and the rotate buttons are very touchy. Because my hair kept getting tangled, I had to do it in smaller sections which took a little longer than expected. I also had to keep taking breaks because it was hurting my arm. It really didn't feel too heavy, until I got about 10 sections in.<br /><br />All in all, it took me a lot longer to get ready, and I don't see myself using this in my daily routine. It will probably end up in the back of my bathroom cabinets and be forgotten.
  867. On their website, Conair states its InfinitiPro Spin Air Rotating Syler as uses ion technology and less heat to create shiny hair without frizz or damage. Bascially it's a hair dryer with a round brush attached that spins. It can be used with or without the spin. It eliminates the need for using a round brush when blow drying. I admit i was intimidated when I got it out of the box. It is big! It has settings for low, high, and cool. It also has 2 buttons to spin the brush while blow drying. The first time I used it, I had a hard time figuring out which direction to spin the brush in to curl the hair lightly under. I used the low heat setting because I have fine hair. I found it easiest to use if I clipped up section of my hair so I could focus on one section at at time. By the third time I used it, I felt confident and it gave me shiny, smooth hair with volume. I love how it reduced my fly aways. If you are looking for a way to achieve a smooth blow out without the trouble of using a brush and blow dryer, try the Conair Spin Brush to see if it works for you.

It did not work very well on my daughter's hair either as her hair is quite curly and you could hardly tell the difference, she is better off using a flat iron to get the frizz out.   882. I've had this product for two years and feel really good about giving it a four-star review. Of course, this is based on my preferences (I hate doing my hair!) and hair type (long, thin hair).<br /><br />It takes longer to dry my hair than with a blow dryer. It does not smooth my hair as well as the two-inch ceramic curling iron I'd use otherwise. HOWEVER, my hair looks smoother than with the dryer alone and it takes less effort (and perhaps less time) than both blow drying and curling/straightening. Since I am pretty lazy when it comes to my hair, this is a great middle-ground product for me.<br /><br />There is a learning curve to this machine. But, read the directions and pay attention to what you're doing. I've been doing it long enough now that it's very intuitive to me to switch the rotate button when I flip my wrist over or move to the other side of my head. I never get it tangled anymore but, if it starts to, I have no problem remembering to just LET GO of the button, hit the other direction quickly and problem solved. Easy enough if you allow yourself time to get used to it and don't panic (I panicked the first few times, didn't let go of the button, made it worse, cursed at the machine...when it was really all my fault for not paying attention!)<br /><br />Also, you might have to find out how it works best for you and your hair type. I'm sure someone with very thick hair would have a different experience than I. For me, after I shower I put in any hair product I want and brush my hair straight. It air dries a bit while I do my makeup, pick out my clothes, put in my contacts, etc. My hair is the last thing that I do and it's about 50% dry before I start with this appliance. Then, I flip my head upside down dry my hair with this (mostly from the backside, but also the front--remembering to switch directions when I move from one to the other!). When it feels pretty much dry I flip my hair back over and inevitably discover that the roots are a bit damp still. That's perfect because I work in right at the roots without the brush rotating to finish off the last bit for a few seconds while adding a little lift at the roots. Then I use the rotating brush again to flip the ends under (or out, if I'm feeling spunky) and I'm all done.<br /><br />I'd give it a five-star review if it could dry my hair just a little faster. I'm not sure how much oompf than can fit into the inside of a brush but if they came out with a model that promised a little more speed, I'd try it out.That's perfect because I work in right at the roots without the brush rotating to finish off the last bit for a few seconds while adding a little lift at the roots. Then I use the rotating brush again to flip the ends under (or out, if I'm feeling spunky) and I'm all done.<br /><br />I'd give it a five-star review if it could dry my hair just a little faster. I'm not sure how much oompf than can fit into the inside of a brush but if they came out with a model that promised a little more speed, I'd try it out.

  915. I bought this because sometimes I wake up with 'buzzing' wrists and fingers (c-p sufferers will know what I mean). Add my inherent inability to hold a brush, and a hairdryer at the same time, and you have a recipe for really straight hair. This rotating styler does EXACTLY what I want it to do - I dry my hair most of the way, then use this to curl and dry my hair the rest of the way. It rotates all on its own and my hair looks like I know what I'm doing.<br />This is my second one, the first one lasted over a year (I think I taxed the motor by using too much hair at one time, getting some of my hair caught near the handle as it rotated). I liked it so well I replaced it with the exact same thing. Worth every penny.
  916. I am 55 years old and have had VERY fine (\\"baby\\" fine), poker straight and thin hair my entire life. No product (and trust me, I've tried them all) was every able to make any difference. Even when a professional dried my hair, it looked good (ish) for an hour max and then it just became limp and straight. I recently changed hair stylist and the woman I now go to is great with color and cut and HER styling actually did give my hair some volume that DID last so I actually asked her if I could make an appointment and pay her to teach me how to get volume. She said it wasn't necessary and that I probably do what others with the same hair type as mine do. And she was right. I had thought that the only was to get volume was to flip my head over and dry it by pulling the hair away from the root and THEN trying to somehow maintain that volume. She said that I needed to get a thicker brush (ironically a 2 inch one-same size as the one on this styler) and section my hair and rotate the brush while never pulling it from the root. It had never occurred to me that sectioning it would make that much of a difference since I just don't have enough TO section. I also thought that while her suggestions made sense, I could never hold a hair dryer in one hand and use the other to continually rotate the brush but this styler solved that. All I have to do is hold it at the root and let the automatic rotator do it's job. I can see (or imagine) that anyone with thick or curly hair might run the risk of having the brush tangle or grab at the hair but since mine is so fine, that hasn't happened. Others who are not pleased with it say it doesn't dry it fast enough-not a problem with me at all. My hair will dry on it's own within 10 minutes. And I don't have a frizz problem-again not enough hair TO frizz and, again, my hair is just too fine to have ever had that be an issue. Finally, some didn't like it because they clearly have been using other styling devices that seem to do abetter job in their opinion. Other than a hair dryer, I have never used another \\"tool\\". Part of that is because what would I use? A flat iron? That's the last thing I need-straighter hair. And frankly, I'm just not willing to spend anymore than 5-10 minutes on any styling technique. My hair is already dry by then. SO, it was kind of ironic that a week after my hairdresser had given me these tips, I actually found a device that would do the one thing I was unable to do-again, drying with one hand and continually rotate with the other and that's the beauty of this for me. I guess my hair type and newly learned tips make this the perfect styler for my type of hair. The grass is always greener on the other side. My 2 closest friends are both of Greek heritage and both have THICK curly hair that frizzes in humid weather and they spend huge amounts of time with flat irons and get semi-monthly keratin (is that what it is called?)- a chemical straightener. While I don't envy how much time they have to spend on their hair, I would kill for their curls and thick hair while they would love to spend far less time and money on theirs as I do on mine. I am not going to make any claim that my hair has suddenly become so incredibly and vastly different in volume but this styler has given me more than anything I have ever used before. It also makes getting the hair in the back much easier to style. SO, if your hair is like mine here are the 2 most important things-keep the brush at the root the entire time and don't pull it . I literally smash it against my scalp and let the rotator do it's think. The second tip is that once you have finished with the section, don't pull the styler out at all to unwind your hair. Let it cool for 15-30 seconds and then use your hands to unwind the \\"curl\\" and and just place it on your head. And THEN just spray the h_ll out of it! UPDATE-In 2015, I bought the 1 and 1/2\\" model that was not available when I first purchased this. Andwhat a difference half an inch makes (speaking of hair stylers-don't read anything more into that comment). I've grown my hair longer since I purchased the 2\\" model and it's now shoulder length (maybe a little longer). It's still fine and straight but the 1 and 1/2\\" one does a MUCH better job in styling it. You can actually create somewhat of a curl although it doesn't last all that long in my hair but in addition to being smaller in diameter, it's also about an inch shorter in length (the brush from the top to the bottom) which makes it easier to section smaller...sections? And then dry those. I remember reading the other reviews when I bought the 2\\" one and people who wanted to use it as a styler felt it didn't do the job very well. I think the smaller version will address that.
  917. Expensive tool for doing almost nothing. If you wish to spend long time into doing your hair and still not getting a good result go ahead and waste your time and money on this. I regret this purchase. If you have pretty short hair it might work for you.
  918. Doesn't do anything except tangle my hair. I use a round brush and my hair dryer, which seem to work much better than this &#34;2-in-1&#34; tool that just hurts my head.
  919. Not good for fine, medium length hair. Used it once and put it in a drawer, never to be used again.
  920. This rotating styler is very easy to use. After blow drying my shampooed hair to slightly damp, I use the rotating styler to add a slight curl and volume to my shoulder length hair.

I am not exactly impressed but it will do for now. I have naturally straight hair that keeps its shape therefore the styling properties of this rotating styler doesn't do much for me. It does make the hair slightly shinier but then again, nothing impressive. Not sure how the brush cleaning will go in the future, it looks like one of those hard to clean ones.   943. I love this thing. I bought one at Walgreens years ago when they were twice as much, and loved it. It's almost impossible for me to use a round brush with one hand and blow-dry with the other. This does the job one-handed. My old one eventually slowed and then stopped turning at all, so I was thrilled to find them on Amazon for half the price. The new one spins very fast, but if my hair gets stuck in it, I just reverse the direction and it untangles. The only downsides are that they are prone to breaking, like anything with moving parts, and your hair will be smoother if the hot air is hitting it from above instead of below, so this might leave it frizzier than if you used a blow-dryer. I used my old one for four years, but since I work at home and am out of school, I don't do my hair as often anymore, so it probably got about what would be two years' worth of use for most people. For that reason, I'm going to save up for a backup one for when the new one breaks, which I assume it will. I love it that much, that I'm willing to spend money on it a third time even though I know they don't last that long.

  989. I received this in on Tuesday but did not get a chance to try it until today. First off, the reviews that state this is heavy I would love to know what they think is light. My hands didn't hurt and neither did my wrists. You do not have to rotate it, the barrel does it for you. As for the size I didn't have any problems with it. In fact the size made it easier to control. I have shoulder length hair and this worked great on it. I sectioned my hair and it did a better job then a hair dryer and flat iron. I threw my flat iron out after using this because my hair had volume to it unlike the flat iron which of course leaves your hair FLAT! I would throw the hair dryer out too but my husband uses it. As one had already stated don't be thrown by the soft bristles. They do work! The controls are easy to navigate. Once you start using it you become adapted to which button to push. As for the high and low setting, I had to use the high setting. I first tried the low but the bristles didn't spin too good but I have thick hair. When I did my bangs I was able to use the low setting because my hair isn't as thick in that area. What I noticed with this is that you don't feel the heat too much until you have the bristles spinning and I am not talking about heat that will make you sweat using it. Then you feel the heat being distributed through out. The biggest pro for me was I did not see smoke one time from my hair!! Not once. Unlike the flat iron which I would see smoke a few times and I'm talking about using it on the low setting. The only reason I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 is because at the top of the brush where the cap is (not the plastic cover that goes over it)there is a small gap that goes around it and a couple of times I felt a strand of hair get caught up in it. But all I had to do was push the other button to go in reverse and it came right out. The weren't kidding when they said you can't get your hair caught up in this. However, the end result was beautiful,smooth, silky hair with VOLUME. Before I purchased this I had some serious doubts but then I remembered that if I didn't like it I could send it back. And of course I bought it through Amazon!!

  1000. Well, when I first got this rotating styler, I was so pleased. My fine/frizzy & wavy/curly hair looked so great and smooth after using it--like I had just stepped out of a salon. I would dry my hair with my normal hair dryer until it was 85% dry and then finish off with this rotating styler. I loved it so much, I almost immediately bought one for my adult daughter (she has the same hair type as me). After a few weeks of use, it didn't seem to be working as well as it did initially. After three weeks, I noticed my hair was looking a little rough & it seemed like I was losing more hair than normal, so I took a break from using it. Perhaps for people with strong healthy hair this dryer would not be an issue, but unfortunately for my thin/fragile hair, it was a big mistake. My hair looks AWFUL now--dried out, damaged and I've lost a fair amount due to breakage. At my previous hair appointment, my hairdresser had remarked about how healthy my hair looked--that was about two weeks before I bought this styler. At my next appointment, I don't think she'll be saying anything other than, \\"What in the world happened?\\" :( I just hope it can be fixed. So this is my warning advisory for this product: If you have really healthy and strong hair, this dryer will probably be okay--you may even think it's absolutely wonderful (I sure did at first). However, if you have hair that is on the fragile side and prone to heat and styling damage, be VERY cautious about using this styler. Don't use it every single day--take a few days off in between and assess if your hair is getting damaged. I am really upset at myself for trading two weeks of awesome looking hair for the damaged mess that is on top of my head now. Absolutely not worth it. :(

My hair has never tangled around the brush because as soon as I feel a bit of resistance, I start turning it the opposite direction. I am extremely happy with this purchase!

This might work very well for a lot of people but it does not work well for me.<br /><br />My hair is:<br /><br />&#62;Very long - past my rib cage<br />&#62;Fairly dry/damaged as I've bleached it a lot in the past (I am blonde)<br /><br />i need to take care of my hair & baby it so it doesn't all break off & split on me.<br />this unwieldy thing can be a bit of a challenge to use & in the process you may damage your hair trying to learn how to use it. be careful.<br /><br />If you have naturally healthy & strong hair, this product will probably help you a lot. But for me, it was really just a pain in the butt to use & it further damaged my already damaged hair.<br /><br />They say you're supposed to use this on 80% dry hair. Basically you still have to use your blow dryer to get it that way so the Conair Spin Air doesn't eliminate the need for that tool.<br /><br />As my hair is very long, it snagged a lot & pulled and tangled - not a good thing when i'm trying to prevent more breakage. Seems like a flat iron is more gentle than this thing as you're just gliding it through your hair, not pulling & tugging & yanking<br /><br />IF YOU HAVE CARPAL TUNNEL or wrist problems- this is not the tool for you. My wrist hurt really badly & i had to put on my brace halfway through.<br /><br />just doesn't seem worth it as the Conair spin doesn't get your hair completely dry unless you keep going over and over the same area, which is damaging, & still doesn't eliminate the need for a blow dryer. and unless you go over & over every section of your head with this thing a million times, it's not going to completely dry your hair.<br /><br />also took a really really long time for me to do - 30 minutes. i coulda blow dried my hair & curled it with a curling iron in that time :( it would have looked better too<br /><br />mixed feelings about this thing. my results weren't great. i'd say avoid it if your hair is any sort of damaged or if it's long & damaged. but go for it if it's healthy & short

  1076. I have medium textured relaxed hair that I recently cut short. This tool is great for drying and slightly styling my hair (my hair is currently to short to get full curl from the dryer) my spin brush routine: wash an condition my hair, apply a styling cream/heat protector and air dry until hair is 60% dry. Next (very important unless you want to snag or tangle your hair) i section my hair with clips an take small subsection being careful to not make sections longer than the dryer barrel. I place the barrel over the section as if to flip my hair out and spin to smooth my hair roots then place the brush under the section to straighten the full shaft of my hair. I continue around my head until its all dry and super shiny. I finish by applying a light frizz serum and wrap my hair to help lessen the volume (because my hair is chin length)<br />Overall this is a great product, it makes my hair soft and bouncy I also experience less hair breakage than flat ironing. I wish the barrel could be ordered smaller and I do experience shagging from time to time when rushing to finish my hair.

Everyone raved how their hair looked as good as a salon blowout. &#34;Sure,&#34; I thought. &#34;But they probably already know how to use a hair dryer.&#34;<br /><br />I bought one anyway figuring I could return it if it was a total bust.<br /><br />Boy...was I wrong.<br /><br />After just ONE use, I am completely in love with my hair. Shiny, just enough curl on the end to keep it from being stick-straight. I might even stop in to show off to my stylist!<br /><br />Be aware that the rotating part takes some getting used to...I still manage to get it going in the wrong direction most of the time, but my hair still looked great. Also be aware that you might want to use a regular hair dryer to take your hair from wet to damp. This puts out a good air flow but it's 500 watts and doing the initial dry with a regular dryer speeded up the process.<br /><br />It will probably take a half-dozen times to get to the point where I don't have to fiddle with the controls. Seems pretty intuitive.<br /><br />Best of all, I am loving my hair again.

  1114. Several issues.<br /><br />1) The rotation function is difficult to use. Its VERY easy to get your hair tangled. Which is dangerous. A few times my finger accidently pushed the rotation and started to tangle my hair.<br /><br />2) The hair dryer barely blows air on the high setting (and its not hot) and most of it is coming out of the tip. I put my hand to the barrel and the heat is not evenly distributed.<br /><br />3) The desciption says \\"3 heat settings and 2 speeds for versatile styling\\". Dont be fooled. There are 2 settings Low, High, and a Cool function. The Low/High setting controls the flow of air and the rotating speed simultaneously. I would have liked to use high air and slow rotation until I got used to using the rotation setting.<br /><br />4) The brush bristles are soft, which makes it hard to grab the hair. I dont have thick hair at all. My hair is very soft and generally straight. I had to take very small sections of hair and help the brush grab the hair.<br /><br />Because of the low air/heat and the small sections, it took forever to dry my hair! My arm was more tired than if I used a conventional dryer and brush.<br /><br />The idea is great, but the execution is poor.

It's easy to operate and doesn't tangle your hair.   1137. I will start by saying that as I write this, my right hand is so sore and I can't feel my pinky.....I saw the commercial for the spin air and thought \\"there goes conair again with a good idea but likely a poorly constructed product.\\" I have never been a fan of Conair products. The products have never worked on my hair. I've got VERY thick and long hair. I read other reviews and didnt's see an absolute consensus so i felt it was one of those products i had to try for myself. Flat irons make my hair too flat with no body and blow drying takes forever, gets tiring and can burn my scalp. I bought this item today and gave it a whirl on VERY damp hair. The spin air spins to the left and right and has a separate button for each...pressing the correct one is going to take some practice before i instinctively know which is which. At first try, I found there is definitely a learning curve. My hair got stuck, was pulled by the rotator and I thought my head was going to pop off at one point. You can't just let the piece of hair whirl onto the rotator and leave it there to make your hair gorgeous. I had to keep the spin air moving up and down, otherwise, my hair rolled up on the brush, and got stuck. On my VERY damp hair, this thing is not going to save me any time compared to blow drying. I waited for my hair to air dry, and gave this another go on dry hair...On my dry hair, things were better. The process went much faster. I didn't find it went much faster than blow drying nevertheless.<br /><br />To sum this up:<br />PROS: It is kind of a fun concept; The hottest setting on the spin air is just warm enough and doesn't burn my scalp like the hottest setting on a typical blow dryer does; the spin air definitely added volume; the end result was no better or worst than using an old fashioned blow dryer and brush; a pro for traveling since the spin air might take up less space in a typical carryon bag then a blow dryer and a brush.<br /><br />CONS: not the easiest tool to use; the handle is thick and my hand felt very sore after use; this would not be the best tool for short hair; hair gets stuck, pulled and tangled and have to repeatedly go over the hair to fix the damage; it is an expensive product in my opinion; the cord is too short so i had to find an extension cord....<br /><br />In conclusion, I don't know yet if I will return this product based on its first performance, but I also dont think I would recommend it to a friend. If you have the money sitting around to shell out on this to try it out, then it might be worth trying and holding onto if the results are to your liking. This won't forever replace my flat iron or blow dryer.<br /><br />___________________________________________________________________<br /><br />UPDATE: I bought this product about 3 years ago and after a few months of barely good results, I stopped using this product and dumped it in the back of my closet and about a year ago, I threw it in the garbage.handle is thick and my hand felt very sore after use; this would not be the best tool for short hair; hair gets stuck, pulled and tangled and have to repeatedly go over the hair to fix the damage; it is an expensive product in my opinion; the cord is too short so i had to find an extension cord....<br /><br />In conclusion, I don't know yet if I will return this product based on its first performance, but I also dont think I would recommend it to a friend. If you have the money sitting around to shell out on this to try it out, then it might be worth trying and holding onto if the results are to your liking. This won't forever replace my flat iron or blow dryer.<br /><br />___________________________________________________________________<br /><br />UPDATE: I bought this product about 3 years ago and after a few months of barely good results, I stopped using this product and dumped it in the back of my closet and about a year ago, I threw it in the garbage.

  1139. Ok, I've never written a review for a product before, and trust me, have made many an Amazon purchase. I love this contraption. I have fine hair (but tons of em...) that has absolutely NO body on its own. If I blow out my hair, using a large, round brush, using the heat then cool method, I have body and bounce that lasts all day... otherwise, flat right away. To do this, I have had to clip up sections of hair at a time, to keep the top hair off of the section I am working on, working my way to the top. It's not easy to get the ends to stay around the brush, it takes forever, and it's difficult to spin while drying. Enter the Infiniti Spin Air Rotating Styler! This thing does a fantastic job! It takes a bit longer than a high power blow dryer does, but I must confess that most times I use both... which, in my opinion, is genius =). I hold the spinner in one hand, and my standard blow dryer in the other. My hair dries extra quick, and allows me to set in my style with my blow dryer's cool button. My hair is full of bounce and shine, and holds its body all day long. The ends are smooth, eliminating the need to use a straightener. I noticed some complaints about this thing weighing a lot, but honestly, it weighs quite a bit less than my blow dryer... maybe I'm just tougher than some??? I would give it a full 5 star rating if the spinning feature worked on the cool setting...Anyway, I love, love, love this thing. Would buy it again in a heart beat.
  1140. I am not absolutely positive how I feel about the Spin Air.<br /><br />My first impression was \\"OMG it's huge, awkward and is going to tangle my hair into a mess!\\"<br /><br />That being said, it definitely IS a huge device which if you need to use for a length of time (if you have really long or thick hair) it gets to be very awkward and your arm gets tired and achey, as well as your hands. It is very thick/fat and uncomfortable to use after a while.<br /><br />If your hair is really long (mine is past the bra strap) you have much greater tendency to tangle if you are not absolutely precise and accurate with your movements, positioning and control of the brush .. not to mention you have to precisely control the spinning by pressing/holding the button in. It is definitely a task and something to get used to. Getting the back of your hair without tangling or running into other issues, when it is long, is definitely a challenge.<br /><br />Once you get the hang of it, the results are pretty good (they'd better be for all the effort involved!!!) BUT I can get the same results with less hassle, in less time, just by using my regular brush and hair dryer. With the Spin air, you DO still get fly aways if you do not use the right styling products and techniques. This device is not a cure-all.<br /><br />The Spin Air takes longer to dry your hair as well. It did for me anyway, but again my hair is longer.<br /><br />For the price, I cannot justify it's worthiness. I mean, it is a neat idea, but it is expensive as an added \\"tool\\" when we already use a hair dryer to begin with. This isn't something I could/would use everyday in place of my dryer and brush .. it is not easier, it is not a time saver and it provides no better results.<br /><br />If you're the type of person who likes extra gadgets to use every now and then and you don't mind spending this amount of money, then sure, go for it. But, if you're looking for a total replacement to your dryer and brush, do not buy this... or at least not at full price. I think the Spin Air should be around the $20-30 price range at most. That is just my opinion, but I don't see anything amazing in it's ability or in it build quality to justify the current price.<br /><br />I also would never recommend this for anyone with shorter than chin length hair - the round brush head is just wayy too big to be useful.s... or at least not at full price. I think the Spin Air should be around the $20-30 price range at most. That is just my opinion, but I don't see anything amazing in it's ability or in it build quality to justify the current price.<br /><br />I also would never recommend this for anyone with shorter than chin length hair - the round brush head is just wayy too big to be useful.
  1141. I have an older Conair ceramic-barrel brush type dryer that doesn't spin, and have used that for quite awhile. So I'm comparing the Infinitipro with that. This one wins, hands down. My old one is heavier, hotter (think \\"pain\\"), and harder to use than this gadget. These can work without a tremendous amount of heat, so no more OUCH-ing here and less hair damage, plus the cool-down button is always a plus to set the curl. I'm also finding the added volume lasts longer... no idea why. Your hair should be just a little damp when you use this -- possibly a problem for people with thick hair, but you can always do a light regular blow-drying first. (I've never thought of these as my primary blow-dryer anyway -- merely styling tools. I can get away with towel- and air-drying for 15 minutes before using this.) There's no tangling hazard with this. The whole brush is quite soft, too -- no hard teeth poking out. It works like my older one EXCEPT you get that nice little tug when you press the Spin button that pulls the unit closer to your scalp (again, without burning it). I was pleased with the results at the very first use, after thinking it would take some getting used to. Also the placement of the air filter on the Infinitipro makes it less likely to be blocked by your hand, which is a hazard with my older one. And the brush section fits in a nice little sleeve that protects it from dust and crud. (Even better is that I got $20 off this with a \\"Beauty\\" discount that came through my Kindle With Special Offers. That thing has practically paid for itself with the great discounts it gives.)

I get the best results if I section off my hair and style it a small section at a time. Generally I towel dry my hair after my shower, get dressed, do make-up and then style my hair. I read reviews that it wasn't hot enough for dry frizzy curly hair like mine but I gave the brush the benefit of the doubt.. Plus I really wanted it to work because I cannot for the life of me use a blow dryer and round brush. I just don't know how to style my own hair unless its getting an iron and flattening it. I actually have a Conair flat iron and it's awesome but it always leaves me hair smelling burnt and I hate that. This brush worked on the bottom half of my hair. It came out great after I put a bit of serum in it.. But when it came to the top half it just looks horrible. I tried brushing it through several times and it just does not come out right at all. So yeah just like the other girls said.. If you have that dry frizzy hair it's not worth buying. I just hope I am able to get my brothers money back for buying this. Just a little side note.. I have the typical Hispanic hair. Again it works.. but it does not work wonders for my hair. Which is why I'm disappointed. I'm going to have to stick to my flat iron.. =[
  1150. This is a nice brush but I don't use it....it is too thick for me to hold onto....It does everything it says it does but not for chin length hair.
  1151. My hair type: a little below the chin in front, tapering up to a tight stack in the back. Very fine, wavy, & colored. With a predominant curl cowlick in the back.<br />Even with a few minor flaws, it still deserves 5 stars!<br /><br />Pros:<br />Great volume<br />Great shine<br />Brushes as it styles saving time<br />Super easy to use<br />Love that it does the work, rotating<br />Cord length is good<br />Completely straightened my wavy hair (little difficult with the cowlick in back)<br />Not too hot, that your scalp get over heated<br />Minimal chance of burning yourself, much safer than a straigtening or curling iron<br />Doesn't heat the room up too much, First time I didn't really break a sweat styling my hair, I usually cook when using a blow dryer in an already steamy bathroom.<br />Great for flipping ends in or out.<br />Very easy to use, much easier than a round brush and blow dryer.<br />Can be used 1-handed, if needed, especially medium short hair.<br />Frustration-free hair styling<br /><br />Cons:<br />Needs more power to dry hair quicker (this will most likely not replace you blow drier). The \\"high\\" is more like a medium) I did use it to completely dry my towel dried hair, but it did seem to tale longer than it should, but not horrible. It was also definitely work to over come my cowlick in the back. I recommend hitting your hair with a regular blow dryer first, then when it's almost dry going in with this.<br /><br />Not the best for really short (<3-4\\") hair (had a little challenge with the bottom of my \\"stack\\" where the stylist went in the trimmer, the barrel is pretty big, but it is doable.<br /><br />Little lag, wants to get that one last spin in after you release the button to stop the rotation, this can cause it to over tighten, on short hair, the hair just slips, on longer hair it causes pulling, allowing your wrist to rotate, reduces the pulling, or just tap the reverse button.<br /><br />If you over load it, hair may spill off the side and potentially tangle up, especially longer (greater than chin length) hair.<br /><br />Other notes:<br />Does not rotate on cool<br />The cap protects the bristles, but doesn't cover the end. it snaps in place, but can can slip down.<br /><br />This is perfect for:<br />Short to medium hair lengths (haven't tried long hair)<br />Elderly or people with difficulty using styling tools due to arthritis, shoulder mobility, or needing to style with only 1 hand
