  1164. I bought this product with serious trepidation, since I have spent so much money over a long lifetime on hair gadgets that disappointed. So, I viewed the purchase as acknowledged gamble. (BTW- I gambled more than I needed to, since it was much more expensive in the store where I found it than on amazon, so buy on amazon.) Also, I am extremely clumsy and uncoordinated, so any product that requires the least amount of mechanical understanding or physical dexterity usually confounds me. I guess I am a good person to test these things, since if I can use them anyone can unless they have a specific physical disability challenge. It really is fairly simple to use. I just needed to remember to first get brush roller around hair before pressing the twirling button. Pushing the twirling directions before you use will show you which way you want to use it. Most people should be set after that. In my case, occasionally when I change sides or positions, I have to re-check to make sure it twirls in the right direction, but even when it I erred, it's not a major setback, you just go to the right direction.<br />I found I could dry my hair faster, and make it look more smooth, shiny, and styled than when i struggled with a blow dryer in one hand and a brush in the other. It also has more body, but in a smooth styled way, not just pumped up frizz.I have fairly fine hair, so I don't know how it would work for those of you blessed with thick hair and lots of natural body, but I don't spend a lot of time worrying about you guys ;-). If you have an excellent hair dresser, as I do, you probably won't look as good as when you walk out of the salon, but you will look a lot closer to that than you did before. I feel as though i can now walk out of the house with hair that is actually styled, not simply blow dried.

It works better if you use on slightly damp hair to finish styling, or as a quick fix to redo your hair.<br /><br />Since the original one I bought left with the kids I bought myself another one when I missed using my old one. You can curl your hair, brush it straight, and it's easy enough to use one handed even if it is a bit bulky.<br /><br />There is a cold air setting that you can use to set your style. The brush doesn't rotate when it's on cool. The brush will rotate both ways with a click of a button for smoothing down your hair or rolling up to curl. The settings are high, low, and cool. Under the brush head are the buttons to control which way you want the brush to spin.<br /><br />The brush is very soft and grabs the hair easily for you to style. I usually brush down to smooth and pick up the hair, then while it's spinning I click the button over and it will spin the other way wrapping my hair into a large curl from the bottom up. I then click the cool button to set the curl and then I'm ready for the next section.<br /><br />This is a very nice rotating styling brush, works very well on my hair and I would buy another if this one ever breaks.

  1191. This brush is amazing. I was hesitant because the bad reviews scared me. One point I read regularly was about the difficulty that of use. I believe it's best to have a few practice sessions to get used to the brush. Also, there are MANY videos demonstrating using this brush on youtube by normal, everyday people. So watch the videos and do some practicing...both when your hair is dry and when your hair is wet. Some complained it was heavy. I did not find that the case at all. I found it lighter than my hair dryer (and I have a small dryer). I think the hardest part is getting used to the rotation buttons. In the beginning it was confusing and easy to run the brush in the opposite direction that I wanted or got it gets tangled in my hair. But this is truly not the brushes fault. It's just a matter of practice!!! Another complaint is that this brush does not work well for short hair. If your hair is super short I could see this being the case but there are also people doing youtube videos with short hair. During your practice sessions take time and go really slow so you can learn it.<br /><br />When I've used this brush everyone asks me if I just got my hair done. Here is how I use it. First I blow dry my hair so it is maybe 60% dry. (Practice different levels of wetness to see what works for you). Then I use a hair clip and make the back of my hair one big section, clip the rest on the top of my head. Dry the back of my hair. Next I do another section. I pull the next layer to dry by creating a section starting at my temples and running my fingers around to the back. So I clip the hair higher up closer to the crown of my head. So I have the back hair dry and now I'm working with this middle section. I like working with small sections at a time maybe 1-3 inches wide of hair on the brush. The smaller the section, the easier to work with. Then I unclip the rest of the hair at the top of my head and dry that. Hope you found this review helpful. I think using really good shampoo and conditioner are key as well. My hair gets tangled super easily so I use a detangler too. Have not yet used the heat proof spray they recommend.
  1192. This brush I bought to to take to the US at first used an adapter that didn't make it work so thought it would have to go back .But now have found out how to use it properly .It is quite different to the british version .But I'm sure it will work well when I get to use it in America

  1203. My hair is...we'll say a \\"layered bob\\" (?). I have bangs, long sides that angle from long in the front to short in the back. My hair is similar in length of the video reviewer except for the sides. Layers run from 2½\\" to 6\\". When I first used it I just dried my whole head bone dry with the roller in constant rotation mode and it made my hair very shiny, but also very limp and straight. I like my hair wavy, and flippy in the back. So after experimenting, this is what I discovered works for my hair and makes it full, wavy and still nice and shiny:<br /><br />-I use it on towel dried hair (though I hear most say they recommend nearly dry hair - very damp works for me)<br />-For the back flip, I hold the top layers up and start with the bottom layers and work up while using the next tip<br />-I don't keep it in \\"roll/rotate mode\\". I roll it so that it catches the hair and then let go of the button and just hold it (that seems to create curl instead of straightening this way)<br />-I don't do it until everything is bone dry, but nearly dry - it seems to allow for bounce and curl that way.<br />-I also don't use the brush on all my hair through and through, I just focus on areas that need attention, lift, and curl and my hair still comes out pretty evenly dry in the end - just not bone dry, still has some moisture...and I don't find it loosing style as it dries fully.<br /><br />Takes 5-15 minutes depending on how cooperative my hair it that day.<br /><br />I LOVE this device and am so glad I took the chance and bought it! I only give it a four star because I do think that, even though this works for me, a 1½ barrel would be ideal. Maybe other additional barrel sizes would be better for others, too. I hope they're listening! :)
  1204. This hair dryer is just okay. I wish it got a little bit hotter and blew air out more forcefully because it takes awhile to dry your hair. I researched heated styling brushes, and decided on this one because it was ionic and rotated. I chose the right one for my hair. I have between wavy and curly hair, medium length.<br />Pros: The rotating brush turns in either, depending on which button you push on the handle, and it easily styles your hair. On high setting it dries pretty quickly. It is easy to hod and handle. It has 3 settings. It can be used with or without rotating the brush. It heats up immediately, just like a hairdryer, not like a curling iron.<br />Cons: The brush does not rotate when on cool setting, only when on low or high heat settings. It would be even better if the brush could be detached and had a thinner brush attachment to make tighter curls.<br />Overall, however, after only a few days I love how my hair looks, and it maintains the look all day. Also, I am already noticing that it is not as dry as when I used the hairdryer.
  1209. It was great at first, however the brushes wear out in a matter of weeks and you don't get the same results you started with. They need to have additional brush heads that are interchangeable for this hair styler. I HAVE GONE THROUGH TWO AND I HAVE VERY FINE HAIR. WILL NOT BUY AGAIN.

Also, it doesn't create enough heat, so I need to use a regular blow dryer in parallel to actually dry my hair. The end result is not great, the hair at the top end of the brush gets all twisted and tangled, and there is no volume. I bought a rotative brush in Europe and I couldn't believe what a big difference it made. Of course I can't use it here because of the voltage differences. Why the producers in US can't come with a better product, hard to understand. Anyway, back to the old brush and dryer :( Unless you have thin, short hair (in which case the brushes would be too big) don't waste your money.

  1278. I absolutely love this hair appliance! I have long, fine hair that does not look good if I let it air dry. I used the styler on wet hair even though a lot of reviews said not to; I figured why not? While it did take at least twice as long to completely dry my hair with just the styler, my hair looked great. It was also so much easier being able to do this with one hand instead of wrestling with 2 different things and constantly switching hands. I loved how soft and shiny this made my hair look. I didn't get the volume that some people might have gotten but that's probably because I used zero product. I also loved that it didn't break off little pieces of my hair while I used it. The rotating part took some getting used to. I didn't realize that you have to apply some resistance or it will roll your hair right up to your scalp, my bad! Like many other reviewers said, it's impossible to tangle your hair up in this thing though. My hair tangles just putting my jacket on so this was a welcome change. My hair is very fine and I didn't have a problem with it staying in the bristles. Overall, I would highly recommend this product. It may not be a time saver but it's definitely a wrist saver and a healthier alternative to a blow dryer/round brush combo.

  1289. I have medical problems which makes using my hands difficult. I drop things alot...I was especially dropping my round brush hair dryer while trying to give some form of style to my hair. As I cannot hold things for very long especially a blow dryer, I have learned to wash my hair the night before leaving it towel dried but wet and I put it in a pony tail on the top of my head...in the morning my hair is just damp enough when I take it down that I do not have to use a BLOW dryer on it but I am able to hold onto the spinning brush dryer MUCH better since I am not trying to use my wrists to get my hair onto the round spinning brush dryer. It takes me a minimum amount of time, with a minimum amount of pain to my hands and wrists and if I can take it slow, I almost never drop the dryer anymore and I have success with my hair looking great...however...I did not like my hair the very first time after styling with this spinning brush....it took practice...and experimenting you might want to do when you may not be going out or somewhere important. It would be helpful if the brush came if other sizes as well...and hopefully soon it will come in other sizes. Using the above method...my hair never has been damaged by this spinning air brush.<br /><br />Another problem I did hate about this product and I do believe the designers could fix with almost no problem...you have to be careful when drying your hair with how much hair you allow on the spinning wheel. If hair is too near the end of the spinning brush it will get caught in the edge of the endcap and pull and entangle your hair and this is also where if you allow too much hair on the spinning brush it will roll off the end twining(sp?) your hair into tangles. At the other end of the spinning brush is an area where the spinning brush is attached to the handle... if you allow too much hair on the spinning brush and it get close to the bottom part of the spinning brush...your hair will get tangled and pulled alot.<br /><br />This is a great product for me because I have problems using my wrist and hands. It DOES need a few tweeks in the design but it is allowing me to live a more normal life even with my medical problems and not have to have hair that looks like a frizzy mop.

  1291. I've been waiting for this product to come out in the USA ever since I saw it in the UK and borrowed one from a friend. What a great idea! I have long, layered, highlighted hair that will frizz in places if I don't blowdry carefully and/or use a large barrel curling iron or straightener. With this dryer I can leave it to airdry for a bit, then just finish it off piece by piece and it doesn't get snarled up in the brush. Also, I can give it a quick re-dry the next day if I don't need to wash it all over again. It is not a quick dryer, it is a styling tool, so you should not expect a fast flow of air as some others have commented although notice the UK version does actually have a stronger airflow, but this is true of all 110v. hairdryers so I am not as disappointed as I might otherwise be. That being said, it doesn't seem to impact the smoothing and volume-increasing impact of the styler. 4 stars! I'd give it 5 if the barrel was ceramic and the bristles were natural. Pretty good value for $40 and Prime shipping, though!

  1296. I gave the product four stars because you can't really use it if you're hair is dry. It presumably ( I have not tried) only works on damp hair.   1297. Round brush + hair dryer. I recently came into ownership of what is possibly one of the best inventions for hair styling in the last ten years. All those years spent trying to round brush your own hair so you could look like you walked out of a salon? Wasted once you try this gadget. It does it for you!<br />As a cosmetologist myself, I can vouch that round brush styling is a craft that takes a while to master. Now, you don't even have to try -- just partially dry your hair using your regular hair dryer. Before it is completely dry, start using the spin dryer on sections of hair until you have finished your hair. Easy peezi. You may have seen this on TV before, and - yes - it works EXACTLY as advertised.<br />One caveat is that because the barrel is equivalent to a 2&#34; round brush (that's a big one) it works best on medium to long hair. I love it for my hair, which is just above shoulder length. It doesn't work for the back of my head, since I have an A-line cut with shorter layers in the back with longer length in the front. That said, I use this tool every single time I dry my hair now. It adds volume and curl that sticks around until the next shampoo.<br />This retails for $59.99, but you can find it on sale at Walgreens every now and then for $49.99 or at Amazon for around $39.99.<br />Thank you, Conair, for coming up with this handy tool! Now... if you can just make a smaller size in this, say... 1.25&#34;?
  1298. After I get my hair cut its usually impossible to replicate what my hair stylist had done at the salon. The whole blow dryer + round brush thing is impossible for me to do at home! My hair is shoulder length and thick and this brush styles my hair with no fuss and my hair feels light and smooth similar to a beauty shop visit. I prefer to towel dry my hair before use as the brush runs through the hair with more ease. I would definitely recommend this brush to anyone who likes styling longer hair at home.

  1310. I love this thing! It's honestly probably one of the best purchases that I've ever made, and it was so much cheaper than some of my other hair tools. I have wasted so much on high-end blow dryers, flat irons, and curling irons/wands, and none of them made my hair look as good as this.<br /><br />The flat irons made my hair look unnaturally straight and lifeless, the curling irons left clamp marks, and the curling wand left me looking like I had been electrocuted. I also just could never master using the blow dryer with a round brush, so I gave up on that pretty quickly. I used all top-rated products, so I know this just shows how hopeless I am when it comes to styling my hair.<br /><br />Finally, someone on a forum suggested that I try a hot air brush. I never knew such a thing existed, but I was definitely happy to try. I figured that I would be one of those people writing about how their hair got all tangled up in it, and after I thought about it for awhile, I figured that it would probably end up being another useless purchase.<br /><br />Surprisingly, I was so wrong. I almost cried when I saw how good this makes my hair look. I'm finally getting the flipped-under ends that I've always wanted, and my hair is full of body and without frizz. I can't believe that I didn't know this existed...I could have been enjoying my hair so much more if I had known.<br /><br />I'm also hoping that this will cause less damage over time than my flat iron did, since most stylists say that flat irons and curling irons tend to be worse for your hair. I am a little bit worried about the rotating brush pulling some of my hair out over time, but I haven't seen any evidence of that yet.<br /><br />I've only used this thing twice so I am by no means an expert yet, and I still get my hair caught up in it when I try to do too much hair at once. If I don't try to rush it and use smaller sections, it works beautifully and my hair doesn't tangle in it at all. Also, I am still getting just a little bit of frizz at my crown, but I'm sure that's my lack of skill (I had the same problem with my flat irons, too).<br /><br />Oh, and I do pre-dry my hair with another blow dryer, and then I use this when my hair is about 80% dry.<br /><br />The bottom line: I love this styling tool, and I wish that I had found it a lot sooner. If I can use it without getting my hair in a huge knot, anyone can - because trust me, I'm a disaster when it comes to styling. I actually bought my first one at Wal-Mart, but I bought two more here on Amazon to use as backups so that I will hopefully never have to be without one.ing just a little bit of frizz at my crown, but I'm sure that's my lack of skill (I had the same problem with my flat irons, too).<br /><br />Oh, and I do pre-dry my hair with another blow dryer, and then I use this when my hair is about 80% dry.<br /><br />The bottom line: I love this styling tool, and I wish that I had found it a lot sooner. If I can use it without getting my hair in a huge knot, anyone can - because trust me, I'm a disaster when it comes to styling.   1320. My frizzy hair is now silky and shiny thanks to this miracle device! I've wanted this hair since 1963 and I FINALLY got it! I have a couple of tips for users. Before I use the Spin Air Styler, I do a quick and rough blow dry on my hair with a regular blow dryer to the barely damp stage. This dries it much faster than the Spin Air Styler. But the great thing is, the pre-blow-dry doesn't take more than about 90 seconds because I blow dry it WITHOUT MAKING ANY ATTEMPT WHATSOEVER TO SMOOTH IT OR STYLE IT. I don't even use a hairbrush. At that stage my barely damp hair looks frizzy and wild, but the Spin Air Styler takes out EVERY BIT of that, and leaves my hair silky and smooth, with plenty of body and turned under at the ends. My hair is shoulder length and is layered. I also discovered that since this device doesn't grab or tangle your hair, I don't have to section it off and style one clump at a time. I just start with the device underneath my hair and against the base of my skull and keep moving it up, letting it work in one position for a count of about 15 before moving it up to the next position. The whole process takes only 12 to 15 minutes. At the end, I allow the last clump of hair I did to cool for about 15 seconds before I touch it. After that, I don't even brush it with my hairbrush. I just run my fingers through it and it falls right into place and looks soft and natural and young. Oops - I'm 58! I've been using it for 6 months and have never had any static cling in my hair -- I assume the ionization thing prevents that.
  1321. This is the greatest hair stying tool I have ever owned. I normally have very short hair, but I am growing my hair out for my wedding. The longer my hair gets, the harder it is to style with a hairdryer and have it actually stay the way I styled it. This little tool cut my prep time in half and my hair looks better than when it takes me a long, long time. I won't say I didn't lose a couple strands of hair while getting used to it, but my hair tangled far less than it does in a regular brush, which is just unheard of. It has high/low/cool settings (that you can't accidentally switch between) and easy-to-master buttons to rotate the brush. The motor doesn't seem overly powerful for rotation and I was afraid of burning the motor out or getting my hair caught in the rotating brush.   1332. I just bought this as a gift for my mother, but she didn't like the rotating part and I was going to return it....but I was curious to see how it would do in drying my hair. I have long and SUPER thick hair, very course and can be frizzy, wavy, straight, and curly all in one. I usually use the Conair Hair dryer that has a brush attachment to blowdry my hair and then I follow up with the Chi flatiron or the Instyler if i want a little softer curl. I was skeptical that this would work for my type of hair because I usually need a brush with very stiff bristles to pull the hair straight and this brush has soft bendable bristles. There is a learning curve to using the rotating part, but I figured it out quickly and it became very easy after that. What I really loved is that it saves your wrists and there is minimal arm movement, which is wonderful for me since I have alot of shoulder and wrist pain. I find it works best if you have damp hair, NOT wet hair. And drying it in thinner sections will help too. I was concerned that it wasn't drying the roots of my hair so I figured out that if I run the dryer through the length of my hair and then rotate the section of hair to my roots and then hold it there for a few seconds and then pull back out straight it works really well. The heat of the dyer, even on the high setting is a low wattage, so holding it to your roots for 10 seconds or more won't feel super hot and is enough to dry the roots without feeling like your burning your head. It definitely provides volume and curl and movement which I really love! And I noticed that my hair felt really light, like it was bouncy and had really nice movement, this is great since my hair always has a heavy feeling to it since it's so thick and it never feels light and bouncy when I dry it with my other hair dryer. I did have to take off a star since the drying time was like 15+ min more than my normal styling time, I think because the wattage is so much lower, my other hair dryer is1875 watts and this is I believe only 500, but it definitely provides that salon blow out bouncy moveable hair look, so if you don't mind the extra time then go for it!!!

  1351. I really like this brush. I have long, wavy-curly, thick hair that is a pain if I want to style it with a regular brush and blow dryer. I never did it because it takes so long and it's so hard to do, so I have been just blow drying my hair on winter. However, my hair looked all dried up after(doll hair look). I used this brush yesterday for the first time and it really does the job. It took me about an hour to do my whole hair, and I had to blow dry it first for about 5min, so it wasn't soaking wet. It's really great, but you have to work on your technique. I had to find a way to not only style the tips of my hair, but all the way up, because my hair is long and tends to get frizzy on the top. My tip is to get a section of hair, style the tips first, and when it's dry on the bottom, hold the section, hold the brush close to the root and spin in until the middle, and then stop spinning. This way, you make the root straighter too. Don't spin the brush from the root all the way until the end, it will just make a mess and wont work. I still have to find ways to make it better, but for a first time, it was def worth it. This brush gives a shiny and soft look to the hair, which doesn't happen if you just blow dry it (if you have curly/wavy hair). It looks so artificial when I blow dry it, but this brush just makes it look smooth and shiny. Definitely worth the investment!

  1361. At the start of this year, I decided to get my hair cut short! For the first time, since I was a child, I had chin-length hair. It was a great change but I had no idea what to do with it! I asked the hair styler who cut my hair what I should do, and he said to use a metallic brush and blow dryer to dry and seal the hair. I just nodded along but there's no way I can hold a hair dryer AND spin a round-brush at the same time!! Any of you ladies have this problem too?<br /><br />So I did my research... and thank god I stumbled upon this product. After watching what seems every youtube video demo and review I absolutely HAD to have it. When I first used it, I was ecstatic. If you ask my boyfriend, he'll tell you that I was squealing with every section that I dried and styled, because I was LOVING how it turned out. I looked like I had a beautiful salon BLOW-OUT in only 20 Mins. After having used this tool for a month, this is what I've learned about it.<br /><br />>>> PROS:<br /><br />- It's not very loud. Now, I'm aware that \\"loud\\" is a relative term, but I know it's not that loud, because my boyfriend just needs to raise the volume on the tv by a few notches to hear over it. Unlike my hair dryer, he just has to suffer for a few minutes and get an apology after.<br /><br />- There is a cool option to seal the hair! Note: The head does not swivel on this option, but I don't think it needs to in order to be effective.<br /><br />- The swiveling brush really is TANGLE-FREE. At least, I know it is for me (AND MANY of the women who have demo'd the dryer on youtube.) However, your hair can get tangled if you don't use it properly, and I will elaborate more on this in the CONS section below.<br /><br />- The item includes a nifty cover for the brush-head. It's made out of durable plastic and really protects the bristles from bending or scratching.<br /><br />- Ease of use! In the past month, I have learned to use this thing with my eyes closed.<br /><br />- It has a Ceramic plate! I am a firm believer in the power of negative ions to protect hair follicles and seal in moisture. If you haven't learned about the science, I urge you to look it up. You'll appreciate this tool even more.<br /><br />>>> CONS:<br /><br />- Although, the bristle head brush IS tangle-free, if used improperly your hair can get tangled! If you try grab too much hair on the swiveling brush, then the 'overflow' of hair can get twisted around and get stuck. It took me a little while to figure out why this kept happening, but once I learned about that issue, the rest was GRAVY. :)<br /><br />- The tool itself is pretty big. DO NOT be alarmed at how large this tool is. I don't believe the technology exists that can make this dryer work as well as it does with a turning brush. At least, not for the current price of this tool. Even though, it's a long and big, it's surprisingly NOT heavy at all and will be really easy to use.<br /><br />[[ FINAL THOUGHTS ]]<br /><br />I love, love, love this tool! It may sound corny and over-the-top, but it really has changed my lifestyle for the better. I mean... In LESS THAN HALF the time it would take for me to TRY and use a dryer and brush, I can have a salon-style, blow-out with lifted roots and bouncy volume and shine. The price may seem pretty hefty, but my new look is PRICELESS. .... And the time you'll save will be priceless too.ate! I am a firm believer in the power of negative ions to protect hair follicles and seal in moisture. If you haven't learned about the science, I urge you to look it up. You'll appreciate this tool even more.<br /><br />>>> CONS:<br /><br />- Although, the bristle head brush IS tangle-free, if used improperly your hair can get tangled! If you try grab too much hair on the swiveling brush, then the 'overflow' of hair can get twisted around and get stuck. It took me a little while to figure out why this kept happening, but once I learned about that issue, the rest was GRAVY. :)<br /><br />- The tool itself is pretty big. DO NOT be alarmed at how large this tool is. I don't believe the technology exists that can make this dryer work as well as it does with a turning brush. At least, not for the current price of this tool. Even though, it's a long and big, it's surprisingly NOT heavy at all and will be really easy to use.<br /><br />[[ FINAL THOUGHTS ]]<br /><br />I love, love, love this tool! It may sound corny and over-the-top, but it really has changed my lifestyle for the better. I mean... In LESS THAN HALF the time it would take for me to TRY and use a dryer and brush, I can have a salon-style, blow-out with lifted roots and bouncy volume and shine. The price may seem pretty hefty, but my new look is PRICELESS. .... And the time you'll save will be priceless too.

  1363. I loved this rotary brush, have thick hair and it works well, though to smooth the roots of the hair is not the best option but rather helps shine and shape to the ends of the hair.

  1367. LOVE IT!!!!!!!! SOOOOO much easier than using a round brush and blow dryer. I only got tangled a few times and rotating it in the opposite direction freed it immediately. I have super thick hair, usually takes around an hour to fully blow dry and round brush my hair. Before I bought it the reviews said that if you have thick hair it needs to be almost completely dry, so i let mine air dry for a bit but it was still pretty saturated the first time I used it.

I can't curl my hair, perfect my makeup and blowdrying my hair always leads to a frizzy mess since the round brush and I never grew to like each other.<br />I saw a girl at the gym using once of these bad boys a while ago and honestly thought &#34;what the hell is THAT?&#34; but never thought about it again, until my awesome MIL gifted this for me for my birthday. I was really excited! I tried and I love. Even my guy noticed it and said my hair seemed smoother and shinier! I love this thing. It was a great gift and i'd recommend it for my styling-challenged ladies out there.

  1375. Easy to get great hair. Best when use with almost dry hair. Great for morning touch ups, even on dry hair.
  1376. If you've ever used a regular hot air brush, you just have to remember not to roll the brush yourself because it will do that for you. Also you need to keep it at a position where you can readily access the buttons that rotate the barrel with your finger. It really does save you a lot of effort and time. The only thing I would like to change is the handle's size, if it were smaller and lighter it would make it even easier to use. But other than that, it definitely works, if you want natural looking body for your hair, this is the tool to use. Ideal for medium to long hair due to the 2 inch barrel.
  1377. I used this product yesterday and it does work well, but still not as well as a blow dryer and round brush since my hair is medium length.   1378. First of all, read the review by Dominique W (dated March, 2011). Her review is right on the money. Only difference for me is that I do 'pre-dry' my hair, especially the roots. My hair is very fine and I don't have to use a flat iron. Honestly, when I opened the box, my first thought was, 'Uh-oh, big mistake'. The brush itself is huge, and the bristles are SO soft. My hair is barely shoulder length with shorter layers. I didn't think there was any possible way the large brush would be able to wrap around my fairly short hair. Bottom line, it works exactly as advertised. I was able to get lots of volume at the roots, and the rest of my hair was smooth as silk. The rotating brush takes a little getting used to, but even if you push the wrong button, it just unwinds from your hair. I've never even come close to getting it tangled. This is, in my opinion, a gigantic leap forward in self-styling your hair. I couldn't be happier and I actually enjoy working with my hair (a task I have always dreaded). Highly recommend.
  1379. as per my wife this is the best rotating styler she got and worth every penny. so happy with it so far.
  1380. Absolutely fantastic! I have very long, naturally kept hair that usually gets put into a braid or updo because I'm not sure what else to do with it. I wash my hair the evening before, towel dry lightly, and put my hair into a topknot so I can use this in the AM. It leaves my waist-length strands smooth, shiny, and styled. Would recommend for anyone with thick, wavy hair looking for a way to keep it in check with minimal heat.

  1390. I bought this product after reading both good and mediocre reviews. I figured, eh, it's not super expensive - I'll give it a whirl. SOOOO GLAD I DID! Omg. Volume! Totally gives you that BAM just-walked-out-of-the-salon look.<br /><br />Personal facts: I have very thick hair that's somewhere between medium to coarse and it's in a chin length bob.<br /><br />What you need to know before buying: If you think of this as a tool to replace your flat iron and NOT a tool to replace your hair dryer then you will be pleasantly satisfied. I usually towel dry my hair, run some serum through it (Bed Head blow dry lotion) and flip my hair upside down and give it a few minutes of blow time with my hair dryer until it's not quite all the way dry. THEN I bust out the conair inifiniti pro, section my hair into lower level, mid level and upper level and do my thing. It is phenomenal! It does not give me that limp, lifeless look that my flat iron is notorious for.<br /><br />I read reviews that complained about the drying, the size of the handle, the power of the blow, etc. I feel like it's like complaining about your fridge not also being a dishwasher or giving your smartphone a bad rating because it doesn't also make your coffee. It gives you way more volume than an iron, takes the frustration of using both hands to manage a round brush and a dryer simultaneously, and is incredibly easy to use! Best $30 I've spent in a while.

When it comes to the rest of my hair though I am still working out the kinks. The rotation is one speed and if my hair is still pretty wet it struggles to rotate, once it's dry it tangles and breaks my hair or it gets caught in the brush. The barrel of the dryer has vents (obviously) so when I wrap my hair around it and hold to style curls it creates ridges in my hair. I have used it mostly without the rotation, but it isn't strong enough to dry moderately wet hair. For use I suggest small sections of towel dried hair.

  1398. I had the non rotating version of this (from another brand) in my shopping cart for a long time but just never quite clicked that CHECK OUT button - it just felt too gimmicky. But recently, having had it with my blah flat straight hair to the point where I was contemplating hara-kiri of the hairy-kind SPIRAL PERM(!), I decided to finally try this as a last ditch attempt. Known for OCD like last minute re-checking of other reviews right before buying a heavily researched item, I upped the ante with the switcheroo to add 'self rotating' to the blow dry brush gimmick. Going for broke here, what's the worse thing that could happen right? (Conjures 'Exorcist'-like head spinning image from the powerful rotating action)<br />My first impression of said product was that is was too big, like an instrument of torture, like it can't be held with one hand comfortably (I say 'like' a lot)...and that it reminded me of ...ehem. Aanyhoo, upon first examination I felt dubious that its rotating bristles won't rip apart every single hair follicle that I am (at this stage in life) desperately trying to save like some endangered specie. Then to add to my chagrin, the first time I turned it on and pressed rotate button - it did not.<br />Thankfully, reading the instructions (duh) revealed that the cool setting disabled the rotate feature. I was intrigued why so, but I guess it didn't feel the need to divulge the catastrophic repercussions of allowing rotate while in cool mode. Sure enough, changing setting to the warm activated the rotating brush. Whew! I know at this point you're wondering, 'when will she tell us if the product actually works or not?!'<br />Patience, this is definitely a product that you don't want to use on your hair the first time you turn it on. You have to keep it a safe distance from your or another person's hair (... or a hairy pet/person) the first time you experiment with its various settings since you don't know if the heat will be comfortable foryou and that you can control the rotation first. Its common sense really, but they don't have these 'Too Dumb to live Darwin Awards' for nothing.<br />Long story short - IT WORKS end of review...<br />Haha, I kid! Long story long, once I mastered the gumption to actually use said product on my hair (90% dry), the bristle that I though should've had those ball tips thingy actually didn't irritate my scalp at all - it was very soft. My first use actually yielded the result I wanted - which was noticeable body and shine, and it was easy to style my hair Jennifer Aniston-ish (without the ex-hubby baggage/angst weighing it down).<br />It takes getting used to picking the right rotation direction when using on the back of your head (like trying to write on glass window so person on the other side can read it correctly - its just annoying that it just doesn't read your mind and know which way to rotate, you actually have to think a little in the beginning)<br />It does pull the hair a little (and sometimes I tend to press it harder when I want it to stop instead of releasing - but that may just be a user lack-of-coordination defect.) It doesn't tangle your hair but just remember to not panic when it start getting tight which means you have to release the rotate button ( and not do like I do &#62;_&#60;). I also find it helpful to put my other hand on top of my hair as it's being rotated kind of like as a guide, it may just be a psychological thing on my part ...and definitely use the cool setting to finish for that shiny salon blow dried look.<br />For my hair type for sure I can say it will replace my hair straightener, it'd something I can use everyday provided I allocate ample time for hair prep. Like another reviewer said, it doesn't shorten the prep time much, just makes it easier to get that salon blow dried look with less products and tools.
  1399. Was afraid I'd get all tangled up in the spin. It's fairly easy to master, but doesn't dry very well. You still need to blow dry before you use it, and when you do spin your hair, the bristles get so soft they can't shape the hair very tight. But overall, it does beat the manual brush.

  1404. I have never used a hot air brush in my life. I just assumed I was only able to have the salon quality blow out when I had my hair done or if I blow dried my hair then curled it. I just don't have the skill to use a round brush and hair dryer as I end up with the weird waves around the roots. I know other ladies know what I'm talking about. I stumbled across this Conair hot air brush as well as the [[ASIN:B0056GDG90 John Frieda JFHA5 Hot Air Brush, 1.5 inch]]. Being that both were ranked as #1 and #2, I was torn which one to get. I ended up trying both side by side but first I'll start with the pros/cons of this one. I literally did one side of my head with the Conair and one with the John Freida cuz I'm crazy like that. lol<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Rotating brush takes the wrist-work out of the curling process<br />- The High blow dry setting works very well and dries hair...but is very difficult to use the rotation on this setting<br />- Large barrel for long hair<br />- Cool to touch<br />- The concept is very cool and might be a 5 star product on different hair but it was hugely disappointing for me.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- If using the rotating brush on High it easily gets out of control. My hair didn't tangle but it spins so darn fast that you can't just let it rotate as the hair is brushed over it instead of getting wound up around itself.<br />- Keeping it on low with the rotating is really the only way to be able to manage it.<br />- Curls don't hold<br />- The blow dryer part of this is not that great, compounded with only *really* being able to use and style on the low setting- it would be faster for me to blow dry with a real hair dryer then curl or flat iron. That just defeats the purpose<br />- I have just past shoulder length hair that is sort of fine but very thick (if that makes sense). It's naturally wavy (not curly) but the bristles just couldn't really get through to lower layers. They were soft but almost too soft- when I'd get the curl I wanted,it would pretty much get brushed back out. I couldn't define the layers how I felt I should be able to.<br />- To take different sections of hair, I had to put the whole contraption down so my hair was carefully sectioned off so as not to have lower layers get tangled. This was a giant pain in the rear considering this should be a one-handed operation.<br />- I couldn't for the life of me get the back of my head. I tried rotating the brush both ways and even without rotating. I finally gave up.<br />- Didn't truly smooth my hair the way I was expecting. I even had my fancy Bumble & Bumble products so this should have been a given but it really just ended up looking like a bad blow out with only the ends curled instead of the layers that I actually have. I tried both directions on the rotating brush and it just didn't look right.<br />- I tried on two separate occasions to use this before work and gave up because it was taking so long.<br /><br />My verdict between the two brushes is the John Frieda. I will write a separate review on the appropriate page but the summary of it:<br />- Even though the John Frieda brush doesn't rotate, it gets hot enough to provide the true salon quality curls/waves of a traditional blow out.<br />- The JF brush truly eliminated frizz as well as those weird waves from bad drying.<br />- The hair dryer part of this actually works. Easily half the time of the Conair.<br />- The brush is a little more rigid on the JF so it doesn't brush your curls out and it allows you to have better defined curls and layers.<br />- After trying for 30+ minutes on one side of my head to get the Conair to work (or master how it's supposed to work), I ended up going back over it and fixing it with the JF Brush. Thankfully, it was salvageable. lol

  1414. Like everyone else, I love how my hair looks from the salon. But I could never achieve that look when at home. Why? Because I don't have an extra arm coming out of my back using the techniques that my hairdresser uses.<br /><br />I saw this at my local drugstore. For the most part, they were favorable, so I thought I would give it a try.<br /><br />This product has made a huge difference in styling my hair. I cannot believe how much body and lift I achieve. For the record, I have color-treated hair that goes a bit past my shoulders. I used to blow dry it, and then use a flat-iron to &#34;style&#34; it. Well, the flat iron flattens hair, and I could never get the poofiness and lift that the salon gives me. I also worried about the damage done to my hair with the intense heat from the flat iron.<br /><br />This spin styler does not take much learning how to use. You can make it go in two different directions, so you are in charge. My hair has gotten tangled a couple of times, but you just take your finger off the spin button and gently release it. It is especially really nice to be able to do the back of my hair. You put your styling products into your hair when towel-dryed and then just start. It takes a while to finish all of my hair, but I figure it is less than my previous regimen of blow-drying and flat ironing. And it looks a whole heck of a lot better!<br /><br />I have RSD in my right arm, and I have to say that this styler allows me to work on my hair quickly so that I don't have to keep my arm up too long.<br /><br />I would highly recommend this styler to anyone who needs to keep down on the frizzies and wants some good lift in their hair.

  1423. Before buying this sprain brush I did my research on similar products and found this one to be the most popular and also had the best reviews. My first time using it I was somewhat puzzled on how to really work it. I read the instructions and even watched youtube videos on how to get a full explanation on how to properly use the product. I did manage to tangle my hair up the first couple of times but after trying many different ways to reach my comfort level I got the hang of it. So far I have managed to use it everyday and have not yet gotten bored of it. I ultimately love this product because it leaves my hair full of volume and does not leave it flat out straight like a flat iron. The only thing that I would complain about it that you have to really get the hang of it without getting your hair all tangled up But if you do just turn it off and un-wind your hair from it. Overall I really enjoy this product and would recommend it to anyone who has thick wavy hair like mine. It really makes a difference from a traditional flat iron.
  1424. Drys my hair fast, makes my hair shiny and gives it soft silky body. Have it for over a year and still love this tool.
  1425. This was the absolute best tool that I have ever used. I bought this as a spare, because my other one is so old and I could not live without it.   1427. This is a miracle tool for hair. My hair is long and had no body but just hung straight before I bought this rotating styler---now it has body and curl and I look like I just walked out of the hair salon after I use it. Just couldn't live without it now! My routine is to towel dry my hair, blow dry it just until it is damp wet, then start using the rotating styler. I do use a hair oil and a heat protectent before I blow dry. It only takes me about 10 minutes from start to finish with the styler and it gives me soft, natural looking wavy curls---just the way I like to wear my hair. It takes a couple of times to get the hang of it with the brush rotating in both directions, but it doesn't take long to realize how much better your hair looks using this styling tool. Can't imagine anyone not liking this whether they have long or medium hair---not sure about short hair---the brush may be too big for short hair. Even though it is a bit pricey, it is well worth the money!

  1441. My process: I use my favorite sleek serum and comb into my towel dried wet hair. I section off my hair at the crown and then begin with the sides.   1442. After reading these reviews, I had to try this styling brush. I have medium length, curly (in areas), over processed, fragile hair. Let me first say, I bought a new curling iron about 2 months ago( to try to get the 'beachy' curls'. This iron got hotter than my previous irons and was not ceramic coated and it SCORCHED the ends of my hair. So after a trim and repeated massive conditioning, it's beginning to recover. I saw this styling brush and thought if I could cut out curling irons and flat irons, it would be great for my hair. After I got this styling tool, I couldn't wait to try it out. The first time I used it, I did as suggested in the reviews and dried my hair about 90% with my regular blow dryer. Then I finished it with the Infinity Pro. Just as the previous reviews stated, it took some getting use to. I'm fairly good with hair, but I hit the wrong direction repeatedly, got it tangled a few times, but I could see that with some practice, this could be the drying tool that could just what I needed and it was DEFINITELY easier than using the traditional blow dryer and round brush and less tiring on your arms. I've used it about four times now and each time I use it, it gets easier and the results get better. Everyone's hair is different, but I've found that my hair needs to be much more damp (than the recommended 90 % dry) in order to get the curls blown from the roots out. I'm very glad I purchased this item and would recommend to a friend. Just be patient and work with it until you get used to the correct procedure for your hair type. The brush is very large (2 full inches) and I don't see that it could work on short hair or very long hair. If you are totally uncoordinated, this may not be the styling tool for you. I'm very pleased with the Infinity Pro.

  1470. I stood at the store for a good 20 minutes debating between this product and the InStyler (which is what I was originally planning to get). After seeing the mostly glowing reviews here, I decided to give the Conair a try. Bonus: it was half the price too. I have thick, wavy hair cut into long layers with the overall length just past my shoulders. Every time I get it cut I always say that I can't ever get it to look that good again. Just blow drying it makes it big and poofy. Unfortunately, I'm terrible with styling tools. I don't have the dexterity to handle a round brush with a dryer so getting my hair to lay down and look smooth is almost impossible. Enter the Conair Spin Air. I was a little scared at first with the rotating brush. I was imagining having to cut it out of my hair. I used it on dry hair as a means of smoothing and straightening. It. was. AWESOME!<br /><br />It takes a bit of practice and patience to get the hang of the rotation buttons and changing brush direction as you switch hands/angles and getting used to the automatic pull of the brush. My hair never came close to getting tangled though. In fact, as the tension between the hair and brush increases, the rotation slows and will actually stop if it has to pull too hard. A nice little safety feature that made me comfortable that my hair would not get caught. My hair came out looking soft, shiny, and not poofy! I have yet to use it on damp hair, but I can't wait to see if it works as well.<br /><br />One tip: this thing gets hot so using a heat protecting product is not a bad idea.<br /><br />Overall, I am extremely happy with this dryer/brush. With more practice, I'm sure it will take me no time to style my hair.

  1498. I am very happy with the way this spin styler works. The bristles are softer and the spin not so fast that it tears the hair.   1501. I read a lot of mixed reviews about this and decided to be optimistic. I have average-thick (caucasian brown) shoulder length hair with loose curls. The handle IS big, but i haven't found that to be a problem. If you style your hair a lot, especially with a round brush, you get the hang of this quickly but the different spin directions are a little confusing. I can get straighter hair with a brush and blow dry, but this gives a smoother shinier finish with bouncy waves that lasts longer. it's better if you rough dry with the blow dryer first, then section it off. Spin each section both ways--under and flipped--for best results. I like it with the Aquage straightening products.<br />Cons-wish the bristles were a bit stiffer. Also, sometimes hair gets caught in the space between the handle and the spinning part.<br /><br />9 mos later: As my hair gets longer, just past shoulders now, this gets harder to use. The bristles just aren't stiff enough to mimic a blow out. They just curl the ends. Not changing original rating, though, because it worked so well on my hair when it was shorter.

  1509. I absolutely love the Infinitpro Spin Air Rotating Styler! It is the best! It's so much easier than struggling with a round brush and blow dryer. I spend a lot of time in high-humidity locations and this wonder tool has simplified my life (and kept me from taking another shower after sweltering away trying to style my hair). Instead of planning my outings around a professinal blow dry - I just whip out my Infiniti Pro. Now of course that isn't to say it's a good as going to a pro but - wow! I just rough dry my hair to about 90% dry (this tool isn't a blow dryer - it's a styling tool)and run it through my hair. Watch Jonathan's video to get an idea of how to use it. The brush spins in both directions so you can't get it stuck in your hair! Separate your hair into small sections - I have fine hair and lots of it - so about 2 inch sections max and spin away! It's light enough that you don't need a carpenter's forearms to use it! My hair is just past my shoulders and it takes me about 10-15 minutes to style it. You can also use it to smooth your hair - you don't need to use the spinner if you just want to \\"calm down\\" your hair. Use the cold button and you get even more curl... I'm telliing you - this thing is the best! One problem - the second one I bought - yes - I have two - quit spinning after one use. I'm not sure what happened but I returned it and ordered another one! All I can say is - if you want to save time and look great - GET ONE!
  1510. I enjoyed using this styler while it worked, but it only lasted ten months. It still turns on, but it's much weaker and the brush barely turns. I never dropped it or mishandled it, just took it out to use it one day and it had stopped working properly. I didn't even use it frequently, only occasionally when I wanted a different look from my usual curly hair. For the price, I would have expected to be able to use it for a couple of years.
  1511. This is my third hot air styling brush, and I was very excited by the spin feature hoping it would give an effect similar to hot rollers. As other reviewers have noted, the wattage (and thus air pressure) is lacking. Definitely doesn't dry the hair -- hair needs to be almost entirely dry before using this brush. And when using the spin feature, I can only use it on the lower half of my shoulder-length hair to avoid tangles (which prevent the brush from spinning at all). Because I'm not able to use the brush at the scalp while spinning, it does not volumize as I'd hoped. If you have chin length hair or shorter, I'm sure this wouldn't be a problem for you.<br /><br />The three star rating is for it's smoothing ability -- my hair is quite a bit softer with less frizz after I use the brush, and does look like a salon blow out in that respect (just without the bounce and volume).<br /><br />Net net: I would have returned this product had my cleaner not accidentally disposed of the packaging...
  1512. I had such high hopes for the Infinity Pro - after a friend of mine recommended I get one to ease the pain of growing out my hair. I have a low forehead and I need volume - especially as my hair is getting longer now. As soon as I tried it one of the spin buttons seemed a bit sticky and it did not spin nearly as fast as in the tutorials - however I persevered and thought it might just need some warming up. My hair looked great! It was very good at adding shine and volume - I good heaps of comments at my seeming profession blow-dry job. It really helped when shaping the back of the hair, and curling the tips inward. On the second go however the spinning was more temperamental and by the third had completely stopped! I could see no reason for this happening (completely clean and free of hair). Desperate for my hair to look nice I then tried to use it without the spin function. Spurting and crackling sounds started and then a part within looked to be glowing red and alight accompanied by the smell of burning plastic. This was really scary as it was so close to my face. Thank goodness I was not electrocuted or burnt.<br /><br />I am sending it back for a replacement - fingers crossed!<br /><br />EDIT: So Amazon sent me a replacement and I didn't even need to send back the faulty item, which I was really impressed by. At first I was so happy- the brush instantly spun much quicker than the first brush did - but alas halfway through styling my hair the brush completely stopped spinning. Hopefully I can get a full refund. I am really disappointed! Obviously very poor quality- why have I been sent 2 faulty items??

You choose which way it spins by pushing a button. I definitely recommend this product to anyone who uses a large round brush and blow dryer to style their hair.   1583. I stand by my orginal reveiw but please be sure to see my updated comments at the bottom!<br />I will begin this review by mentioning that I am a licensed cosmetologist with over 25 years experience styling hair and an unabashed hair appliance junky. When I walk through a store that sells blow dryers, flat irons, hot rollers I always peruse them. I have at least a dozen flat irons, ten curling irons, 4 sets of hot rollers, hooded dryers both hard top and bonnet style. This does not include the dozens of things I've given away over the years or the things I've bought and didn't like so I returned. The bottom line is there is not a type of hair appliance on the planet I haven't tried and I have never been more impressed by the performance of a hair appliance than I am with this Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler. I've used products similar to this many times but this is far superior to anything I've ever used. That ridiculous waste of money InStyler, which I returned, doesn't do a thing. I colored my hair dark blond for many year and last year I got carried away making it lighter and lighter platinum until I finally fried it to the point of no return. So last January had no choice but to cut off my beautiful long thick wavy hair and what little hair was left was still extremely damaged. I brought my color back to the medium/dark brown I was born with but it was still damaged and so short I couldn't do a thing with it. I began slicking it back in a French twist and wearing clip on hair pieces. This has worked well because my hair always looks good and it's so easy to do, but I missed being able to style my own hair. Using a blow-dryer and flat iron was so much work and the results were always disappointing. When I saw a commercial for this and became curious. I was dubious that the large 2 inch barrel would not work well in my short hair, while my length is nearly to my shoulders because of the damage I had to layer my hair, so it is about five inches around. Also because of the layers my hair has become very curly and gets knotted and frizzy. Not very attractive! In a review I read a when I was thinking about buying this a woman complained about having to still dry her hair most of the way before using this. The fact is your hair should always be about 80% dry before you start to style it. When I'm blow drying a clients hair I use the blow-dryer to take out most of the moisture before I pick up a brush. For my own hair I usually let it air dry. So with my hair damp and I started using the Infinitipro first at the bottom and it easily starts to glide through my hair, no tangles or knotting, just effortlessly gliding. Plus even though the bristles are soft it is easily picking up my hair. I'm psyched but this is the longest part of my hair so I go to the top and that is when I discover you can easily switch directions, I never read the instructions, so now I'm getting really excited because it is light and easy to hold and I don't have to twist my arms in to odd ways to hold he Infinitipro where I need it. Then the most amazing thing happened, as I'm holding it at the top of my Occipital bone the brush starts to pick up hair from below buts it isn't knotting. It's just gliding. If I hold my hand steady it doesn't do this but so If I want to add fullness to one spot, but that gliding and picking up hair is great for smoothing. I was finished in about ten minutes and my hair looked amazing for the first time in a year. I used my flat iron just to make it a bit straighter, it took about three minutes because it was alreasy nice and smooth and it looked fantastic. I almost began to cry with joy that my hair actually looked good for the first time in a year!I went to cosmetology school in high school and in the twenty five years I have done this professionally I have used at least a hundred different hair appliances. I've tried every sold on TV gimmicky product, every type of professional product and every type of drug store product. This product is unique and exceptional so buy it with confidence. Make sure you dry your hair about 80% before using it and be AMAZED at the results!<br /><br />Product Update December 2, 2012:<br />I still love this product and still give it 5 stars but a recent question Amazon asked me to answer about using this is African American hair made me want to update my review. I have moderately thick hair with a loose natural curl but the texture is not coarse. I don't think this product will work well in hair that is coarse in texture, very thick or with extremely tight curl. The bristles are very soft and I find I need to take small sections and on the top I need to softly cup the brush so it will pick up my hair. They probably make the bristles so soft so they don't tangle the hair but I think they could make them a bit firmer without that happening. I also think it would help if they made out a 1 ½ inch brush. For thicker coarse hair I recommend the Conair 2-in-1 Hot Air Brush which I also own and like a lot. I never had any use for the regular bristle brush but the 1 ½ inch brush with the plastic bristles works really well. IMPORTANT NOTE: There are several models of this brush make sure you get the one with at least 1000 watts of power or it won't get hot enough to smooth your hair. It doesn't spin on its own but it's still easy to use if you work section by section and spin the appliance yourself. Take about a one inch section and starting at the scalp pull the brush down the section, then roll the section up let it heat up well, and then pull it down again. Repeat this on the section until you get the smooth result you're looking for. This will give the hair some flip so if you're looking for straight you'll need to finish with a flat iron, but it will only take a quick pass or two. This is also true of your hair is very coarse, you may get better result and have them last longer with a quick pass of a flat iron. I still think it is a good product and does what it says it will do. Once again both of these items are styling products so you need to dry your hair about 80% before using it or it will not work well. Good Luck! One last suggestion, don't waste your time or money on cheap flat irons, buy a Chi, Rusk, Bayless, anything that normally retails for at least $150, you can find them much cheaper on Amazon or even at TJ Maxx or Marshalls. Cheap flat irons don't work nearly as well or as quickly.
  1584. I got this because my inverted bob is growing out. My stylist put in layers and styled it awesome with a blow dryer and round brush however its hard to get the same style doing it myself. I bought this and it works like a dream!
  1585. I have wanted to get an Instyler but settled for this because it's cheaper and looked like it had the same results. Boy, I was wrong! I got my hair straightened the first time I used an Instyler (my cousin's) and finished in 10mins or so. For this Infiniti Pro, my hair was awful even after spending a full 30mins doing it!!! And to think I only straighten the upper layer of my hair, not all of it! Some reviews say it takes practice. Well I didnt buy a product to see results after a month and expect to go out with awful hair that long! And, they didn't specify that this uses a US 110v polarized plug. As I'm not from the US, I had to buy a power converter which cost me the same amount as the Infiniti Pro. With the total I spent, I should have just bought an Instyler from Australia.
  1586. I am really pleased with the Infinitipro Spin air brush. To be honest I am usually a little disappointed with hair appliances. I have relatively short, thick, fine, and curly hair. In the warm months of summer it is just easier to let it curl naturally but in the fall and winter I like a smoother look. I am thrilled with this item. I have always had trouble using a hair dryer and a brush to dry my hair. Rollers are just too time consuming. The spin brush is easy to use especially after using it a couple of times. It gives my hair a lot of volume and also, according to my teenage niece, makes my hair look really shiny. I am almost tempted to buy another one as a back up!
  1587. This product works exactly as it's supposed to when you use it as directed. I have only gotten my hair tangled a few times, and unwinding in the opposit direction has taken care of the snarls. You can only use it for drying slightly damp hair, so I just let mine air dry for a bit while I finish getting ready and then do my hair. It saves me from trying to work a round brush and the hair dryer to style my fine hair.
  1588. I discovered that dryer 6 month before, since that moment I am not dissapointed. Instead, I highly recommend this product to anyone. I already present few of those to my mom, sister, friend.
  1589. I had purchased the Instyler rotation iron over 3 years ago and never liked it. I ended up giving it away. It never did my hair any better than a regular blow dryer with a round brush. I was hesitant to purchase this spin dryer because of my previous experience with the Instyler but I was desperate to lose the frizz and get some body without constantly frying my hair with my straight iron. What a completely different experience this time around! I love this spin brush. I have medium length, fine and frizzy hair that hangs limply. This rotating spin brush has given my hair body, style and makes it almost frizz free. I can even go without using my straightening iron! It is so much easier to use than a blowdryer! My hair isn't completely frizz free, but almost and with how much fuller it is, I'll take the almost! Awesome styling product!
  1590. I've been a longtime devotee of hot air brushes and even though I already have a regular one, I am glad I bought this one. The spinning action helps smooth the hair and curl the hair in or out very quickly. Using this is much easier than wrangling a round brush and a blow dryer with thick hair. I had an easy time learning to use this, even without reading the instructions, and it smoothed my hair so quickly. This would be perfect for smoothing and defining layered hair that is longer than chin length (the barrel is too big for anything shorter than that). Another nice thing about this brush is that it comes with a cover, which is nice for travel and storage. All of my other air brushes have not had covers, so they either snag clothes or get their bristles bent during travel. Overall, I love this brush and will continue to use it.<br /><br />The downside is that the barrel is large, about 2&#34;, so it gives you a really big curl, which can be limiting for shorter hair (a flip out could look weirdly disproportionate). Also, it does pull out some hair when you spin the brush, but this is no more than if you styled it with a round brush and blow dryer. Finally, if you are using this on your ends, you could only flip it in or out, not just have the ends hang straight down. The styling video says you can use this to add volume at the roots, but I haven't tried that yet. I also don't think you could use this to curl the entire length of your hair. Finally, don't expect this to replace your blow dryer-- this is only for styling once your hair is damp or dry.
  1591. I was excited to try this out. It doesn't work las advertised. I have no problem curling my hair with a curling iron or curlers, or with straightening with a flat iron. However, this wouldn't curl or straighten. It wouldn't even curl my ends under or flip them out. My hair just fell limp. The only good thing I can say about it is it seemed to make my hair shiny. Don't waste your money.

  1594. I was afraid that my hair would tangle with the spinning brush...it does not. It does give my hair lift and shine. The only problem that I have found is that it does create static in my hair.   1595. This is a great product. Perfect for those of us who want to blow-out our hair that are not hairstyle savvy in using a separate hairdryer and round brush. I have one problem--the 2\\" barrel does not work on all hair types. I have super straight, thin, fine hair with layers and the large round brush does not grab my hair to create a bend or curl to produce volume my hair so needs and I so desire. I don't understand why the company cannot produce this product with interchangeable round brush sizes such as 2\\", 1-1/2', and 1\\" sizes or offer different size barrels. Not all hair types are the same and this product will work well only with long, thick hair. Unfortunately, I will have to return this product only because of the brush size. I will keep watching to see if Conair will make this same product with different brush sizes that will work with my hair type. I will certainly buy the product and be able to use it. I hope they do!
  1596. For years I had problem for styling my hair using round combs and hair dryers, for handling both of them at the same time and I was never satisfied with the results, I usually spent a lot of time and at the end my hair was not shiny and straight enough! I even sometimes ended in burning my hairs due to a close contact of the hair dryer with my hair :[<br />This product is awesome, I have used it twice since I bought it (last week!) and I couldn't be more happy with the result!<br />The Brush is soft enough so it doesn't damage your hair (a problem that I had with many round combs). You are the one who is controlling the rotating part, so you can stop it when ever you want with releasing a button or change the rotation direction. The warm blow is warm and not hot, so you will have problem if you want to use it for drying wet hairs but with damp hairs it acts perfect and you are sure you won't burn your hairs with this close contact.<br />My only problem is with the connection of the rotating part and the top part, some times my hairs get stuck there and get off, they could have designed this part better.<br />But in total, Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler has become my hair saloon at home!
  1597. I can't say enough good things about this styler. I have long thin straight hair. I tried everything to try and achieve the full body style that I get when the hair dresser blows out my hair. Hot curlers or a large curling iron work a little, but the style goes flat in a few hours. When I style my damp hair with the Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, my hair has a nice wave, lots of body, and the look lasts until the next time I wash my hair. The styler is really easy to use. I dry my hair part way with the regular dryer, section my hair into small sections, and dry it the rest of the way with the styler. It only takes me 15 minutes from start to finish.

  1601. love it love it love it! I get compliments EVERY time I take the time to dry my hair using this amazing dryer. Takes a little getting used to, but even I have learned how to put some great waves in my hair! Highly recommend to everyone who wants to look their best!
  1602. I have a lot of hair. It's just below my shoulders and I love the round brushed look my stylist achieves after each visit with her. I was struggling to do the technique with just my blow drier and my round brush so I began investigating my options. I had read that this styler was hard to use and that it didn't get hot enough for someone with coarse hair, but decided to give it a try. I didn't love it the first time I used it. My hair didn't dry completely as I was styling and it got frizzy even before I finished. So the next time I used it I let my hair air dry until it was about 50% dry, then I sectioned my hair out just like my stylist does and from the nape of my neck began by taking very small sections and went very slowly moving up along my head. I had to take frequent breaks because my arms did get tired and overall it took me about an hour to achieve the lovely curvy blowout I was going for. It does work, you just have to go slowly, use product that is designed for the look that you want and make sure your hair isn't super wet when you start. I definitely recommend this styling product, but it's not going to be a quick blow and go-it does take a little work and a little time.

  1605. Let's get something straight, people. And I'm not just talking about your hair. I have tried just about every single product out there, from 450 degree flat irons that literally fry my hair (and face sometimes), to crazy contraption blow dryers, to weird-looking bristle brushes. If you have long, wavy hair that (on most days) just doesn't want to behave, just buy this brush and do yourself a favor.<br /><br />It took me a while to get the hang of it, but once I figured out how to best work the brush, it was GENIUS. I let my hair dry about 80% and then separated it into sections, turned the heat on high (which you'd be surprised at how hot it gets), and then lowered the heat to finish styling. BAM.

  1618. I LOVE this product! I have very long layered naturally wavy hair. It does take a long time to dry (helps to get most of the dampness out by using a blow dryer or air dry before using styler.   1619. I bought this after my beloved Revo Styler died and found out they weren't available anymore. The barrel of the brush is not as large as the Revo. It is about the size of a jumbo sized roller. The bristles are soft plastic, the more you use it, the softer the feel - it will be interesting to see how long they last.<br /><br />What I love about this is how much it saves on arm/wrist strain when blowing out your hair. I've got naturally fine, curly hair and this does a great job of styling it into big waves. If I want to go totally straight, I follow with a straightener. The hot air that flows through it is also nice and cuts down on drying time when you use another blow dryer (for me, with diffuser) as you get air flow from the inside and out. It is probably best to section out your hair to dry. You don't need to, but when you don't, hair at the end of the brush can get picked up by the bristles and twisted. So far I haven't had any painful accidents, but it does cause more curl in your hair if you don't then go back and brush/roll it out.<br /><br />The handle is large and easy to grasp and the rotation buttons (one for either direction) don't cause much strain in your grip. The cool setting is nice, although I wish it would continue to rotate - the rotation does not work in cool mode and it is a bit cumbersome to change from hot to cool while the brush is rotating in your hair.<br /><br />Overall, so far I'm glad to have another rotating brush that saves me time and energy when getting ready in the morning!

  1654. I didn't think this would do much for my naturally curly hair (sorry, I don't know the internet hair lingo but I am a black woman with soft curly hair). I don't straighten my hair on my own very much because it's usually exhausting, frustrating and I end up burning myself in the process. I have the Instyler and, even though it was somewhat effective, I would still have to flat iron my hair afterwards. The brush is soft yet effective. It does a good job of blow drying my hair so that I don't have to do too much flat-ironing afterwards.   1662. I have slightly wavy Asian hair that is long and layered. My hair sometimes would get caught where the plastic connects at the top (not the bristle area). I have to dry my hair with a blowdryer till almost dry before using the Styler. Overall the product works to an extent and is easier than holding a brush in the other hand, but it takes more time because I think it doesn't blow hard and hot enough in the right direction. It wraps so fast when this happens that you don't even know what happened.<br /><br />They need to put the spin switch somewhere else and make it so you have to turn it on forward or reverse like you do a drill.   1680. Ordered this item after a friend told me she had ordered one and thought I might be interested.<br /><br />I am a busy mom of three boys. I regularly tame my naturally curly, thick hair with Coppola Keratin treatments. Even using the keratin straightening, I still round brush my hair dry and flat iron. With my hair length falling between my shoulders and waist, blow drying my hair tend to heat up the bathroom. So I thought I would try this product to help with that.<br /><br />This brush helps with drying, but can be awkward to hold. I hope I will be able to get used to that. However, if you have any issues with your wrists or hands-carpal tunnel or arthritis, this is NOT a product for you. It does help make the hair fuller and fluffier. I still have to use the hair dryer and round brush when I get close to the crown of my head.<br /><br />The rotating buttons take some getting use to, and it does pull and tangle my hair.<br /><br />All in all I rated it a 3 as it didn't replace my round brush and dryer completely. It does help with drying the hair without heating up the bathroom, so I will be keeping it. Just know that if you are like me, it WILL NOT completely replace these tools for you.
  1681. It dries surprisingly well. I have chemically straightened hair so I have to follow it up with a flat-iron but that's just because of the way my hair responds to the blowdry. It's relatively easy to handle and the exterior casing doesn't heat up to an obscene temperature so it'll be pretty hard to burn yourself when handling it. You have to get used to pressing the right rotation buttons and some of my clipped up hair kept getting caught in the rotation of another piece of hair but I think I'm just gonna have to adjust the way in which I separate my hair while I'm doing. I found that even if just glided the brush down against my hair like any other brush it still did the job of drying my hair, which is really thick. So, overall, pretty good.

  1684. WOW. I hemmed and hawed over this purchase for more than a year. There was no way this nifty little \\"gimmick\\" could handle my long, thick, curly hair. Needless to say, I was wrong. I was getting tired of that flat, stuck to my head look I was getting with the flat irons. This tool makes my hair gorgeous, in about 15-20 minutes...lots of volume, slightly curled ends, and SO much shine. I don't need a single product. I took the advice from other reviews, and I use it on my hair in sections, from bottom to top, with the hair about 90% dry. If you are familiar with the DevaCurl curly hair system, you will know what I mean when I say my hair is a tight Botticelli. It was no match for the Infinitipro.   1685. I had heard about this product and I was skeptical but really wanted this to work. I took the plunge and ordered it to take on a recent trip.
