  1686. I have owner the Revo curling brush for over 10 years. I am a die-hard Revo fan and when mine died I was devastated! But, I finally decided to give this product a shot. The problem is though that the brush is different - there aren't as many bristles, the heat is practically pointless - there is just not enough and - the biggest problem of all - the barrel is just too small. I have naturally wavy/frizzy hair that is crazy fizzy and unkempt when left to naturally dry. When I used to use the Revo, the brush bristles were PERFECT for it. The brush tamed every strand and left my hair feeling shiny, soft and smooth. I would get so many complements on my hair!<br /><br />With this brush, there is just not enough bristles and I do find I get my hair tangled in it somehow?! No idea as there aren't many bristles. I did find if I kept cleaning the thin layer of hair that built up on the bristles, it would grab my hair better, but not by much. Also, my hair doesn't slide through the bristles like with my Revo. As for the hair dryer part of it - COMPLETELY worthless! I found my hair can be no less than 90% dry for me to use this brush on it and even then it takes FOREVER to dry. With my Revo, I would be done ini 10 minutes. With this thing, it's more like 20 minutes and the brush STILL can't dry it enough - I can tell it still feels damp which is your worst nightmare for those of you that have hair like mine. As it dries on my way to work, it ends up curling up. By the time I get to work 20-30 minutes later, my hair is crazy curly. Now if you wanted curly hair, this is your brush. I do not tough. With my Revo, the brush was really fat and it left my hair in these large slight waves. It would be straight but not sickly anemic straight like with a CHI. The Infinitipro needs to be just a bit bigger so your hair doesn't end up curling up on you.<br /><br />Totally hate it. Now, I'm not going to have to shell out the hundred bucks to get a new Revo.

  1688. I bought the Conair Infiniti Pro 3 days ago and I'm in love! My hair is about chin length and is naturally curly, yet thin. The rotating brush is perfect for creating volume at the crown and curling the ends under. I stopped straightening my hair years ago because my hair was breaking from using the flat iron and hair dryer every day. This tool does not make my hair come out when I'm using it like a flat iron always has. It leaves my hair soft, smooth, shiny and with lots of volume which I've never achieved with any other product.<br /><br />There are only two things I would change about this product. It would be more versatile for shorter hairstyles if it had interchangeable heads with different brush sizes. Also, the rotating function does not work in the \\"cool\\" setting, which I would like for it to do. But overall, this product is wonderful for me!

  1702. I never review products, but I felt I had to for this one. I have medium-length, fine, partially curly, frizzy hair. Sounds complicated. It is. I do let it partially air dry while I pack lunches, make breakfast, etc. Then I go back and I do my hair and it is great.<br /><br />I also LOVE this for touchup later in the day. I use it after a work out, or to give a bit more shine and volume later in the day if I am going out again and I've had my hair up.<br /><br />To the Naysayers...<br />1. It takes too long: Nope, not if you hair is partially dry like the directions state.<br />2. The handle is too big: It's no any bigger than a standard hairdryer.<br />3. It won't grip hair: You NEED to use the rotator for it to grip your hair. You don't need to run it the whole time, but in order to get a good grip, you need to run it for a small bit.<br /><br />My advice, read the directions and watch a few videos before you use it. Practice on dry hair. Then you should be set to go!

  1730. This rotating hairdryer and brush all-in-one is fantastic. I find it easy to use (it took a couple tries to get my styling right, though) and it's very effective. I have medium-length hair that is angled longer towards my chin with some longish pieces hanging down around my ears... kind of like a cool shaggy angled and stacked bob. The way I use the brush is I first comb my hair after a shower and the finger-comb mousse throughout. I then rub an anti-frizz serum through. I use two hairclips to pin the top and front section up while I progressively dry (while curling under) my hair, pulling down a higher layer of wet hair after each layer is done. The section at the top of my head I then use the brush to lift and curl straight back. The front section gets lifted and curled under my chin (my part finds itself).<br /><br />I'm not a great hair person and I always had difficulty styling with a blowdryer and round brush.   1738. About my hair:<br />I have owned and used this product for about three months. I style my straight, moderately thick hair in a shoulder length bob. I have used both a hair dryer/round brush combo and a standard hot air curling brush to style my hair. Both methods produced satisfactory results, but my wrists became sore from rotating the brush.<br /><br />About the Infiniti Pro:<br />The Infiniti Pro is a hot air curling brush. Key features include a 500-watt motor, ionic technology, removable air filter, and a bidirectional rotating brush head. Users may choose from cool, low or high heat settings.<br /><br />What I like:<br />- The large, 2-inch barrel gives my hair lift and body. It gently curves the ends of my hair under without curling them. I can achieve more volume by using the rotating brush near the roots. If you want to curl your hair, this may not be the product for you.<br /><br />- The rotating brush saves my wrists. The brush will rotate in either direction, or not at all.<br /><br />- The protective brush cover prevents the soft bristles from becoming smashed an unusable.<br /><br />What I'm not crazy about:<br />- The rotating brush occasionally picks up an adjacent section of hair and twists it into a tangled rope. If I don't catch it in time, I am left with a knotted mess.<br /><br />- The air flow is a little wimpy compared to other hot air brushes I've used. It will eventually dry slightly damp hair, but I'd like a little more \\"oomph\\".<br /><br />- The \\"tangle-free antistatic\\" brush bristles are intended to leave hair smooth and shiny, but that has not been my experience. The bristles are so soft that they bend and do not penetrate the layer of hair. Instead, they smooth the bottom of the hair and leave the top a little frizzy. This requires me to smooth the top layer with a flat iron.<br /><br />Overall:<br />This hot air brush works, but I'm not bowled over. I would probably replace it if I hadn't spent so much money on it. Even though this is not the perfect styler for me, it may work better with other styles or hair types.ot the perfect styler for me, it may work better with other styles or hair types.
  1739. I have medium length hair and this brush makes it perfect. I blow dry for a couple of minutes and then style with this brush and I am done.   1740. I do think this is a very good styling tool BUT it takes time to get the technique down. It is most definitely NOT able to be used with hair that is only towel dried. I must let my hair air dry for awhile or use my old blow dryer as this doesnt have the capacity to spin effectively through my long thick hair when wet. It spins much easier and smoother when almost dry. It does deliver shine and body. Ill happily keep using it. It does save the wrist (not having to use round brush and dryer) I feel that the heat is just enough to get the style done (as I have hair that likes to curl) PS make sure you are sectioning off your hair precisely and only use about 2\\" wide sections (leaving exposed bristles on either side) or when hair dries and expands the stragglers will tangle around and be ripped out. It save me time by 1-allowing me to style faster since im not hurting my wrist. 2- It spins faster than I can with a round brush (Brush Spins are more effective) and 3- Straightens and curls under ends at once. UPDATE* As i do not wash my hair all that often (3xweek) I have had very lil practice with this and already )after 2x use) i am getting very comfortable with it. I can see when i am prolly gonna have a tug on my hair and can stop it before it happens. the trick is (for long hair) to use smaller sections. You might think that this would add to the time it takes to dry and style but it doesn't. without tangling, untangling and brushing again, I can just use smaller sections and save myself that time. Tonight I was to meet a girlfriend for dinner and almost didnt want to wash my hair (even tho it needed it) bc I thought it may take too long to dry and style. Again very long/thick hair and I was washed, dryed, styled and gone in UNDER 30 MINS!!! thats a record for me! When I got to the restaurant sHE said, \\" I just came from the gym, I told you not to get too cute\\" I told her it was this hot brush. And that I had just gotten out of the shower 30 mins ago!!!   1752. Whoever came up with this idea is awesome... I always wanted to blow dry my hair, but it's pretty long and thick. After I bleached it to death, I grew it out and vowed never to use heat on my hair. So I've been air drying it for years, using products to tone down the frizz. What I like about this is I can still pretty much air dry my hair and use it right before my hair is completely dry. For me it took about 15 minutes to get the look I wanted, but it was so easy! I thought there would be tangles everywhere (and it happens) but if you do it piece by piece then you should be fine. And if you do get tangles, just reverse the spin brush and comb it out carefully. I did my hair 8 hours ago and even though it doesn't look how it did when I first finished it, it still looks awesome. So glad I bought this on Amazon instead of in-store, I saved ten bucks!

  1757. I highly recommend this product. I have fine, wavy/curly, blonde hair that I have never managed to straighten with a brush and blow dryer alone. This product has allowed me to easily create a beautiful straight style myself with no frizz for the first time ever. It even looks better, I think, than the salon blow outs I've gotten, because the product gives my hair some body as well as straights it. I have received many compliments on my new straight hair, and I'm loving it!<br /><br />The Infiniti pro does have a large handle, but I have had no problem using it (and I am on the petite side). I watched some online tutorials before I tried it, and this helped me get the hang of it right from the first go. I am terrible at just about everything to do with hair and makeup, and I can style my hair with this with ease. It's also a pretty safe product. The bristles are soft, so your hair doesn't tangle easily in it, and it doesn't get super hot, so you can't really burn yourself (unlike a flat iron or a curling iron). I also think it's more gentle on my hair, since it doesn't get super hot.<br /><br />As many people have mentioned, this product is a *styler* and not a hair dryer, so it's best to quickly blow dry your hair to about 80% dry first, and then use the Infiniti pro to style your hair. Using this method, I can do my collarbone-length hair in about 15 minutes from start to finish.<br /><br />Give this product a try. It really is the best thing that ever happened to my hair!

  1773. I've been using the Conair Spin Brush for a few months now and I really like it! I have long, (falls below my shoulders) fine hair and I wanted something to achieve volume without having to juggle a large round brush and a hair dryer. This product is just the thing! Traditionally, I have also used a large barrel curling iron when I'm done drying, but this product often eliminates the need to use a curling iron because the rotating brush smooths out the hair.<br /><br />I divide my hair into sections and make sure to dry the lower layers first. I start by using the spin brush at the roots without having it spin, and then start the spin as I pull it towards the ends. It takes a few times and then I move on to another section of hair. I get great volume and my shoulders don't ache anymore from holding up the dryer and large round brush while drying towards the ceiling.<br /><br />I'd say it is a few minutes quicker than using both a dryer and a brush, once you get the hang of it. There is a learning curve involved, and I often pushed the spin button the wrong way at first. You hold down one of 2 buttons depending on which way you want the brush to spin. You can either wrap the ends around the brush or just pull it through your hair as you would a large round brush. If you have the heat on high, it spins faster than if you have heat on low. I have gotten my hair tangled, but reversing the spin loosened it up and it's not ever been awfully tangled.<br /><br />If you buy this, be prepared for the learning curve and be patient at first. You'll be spinning without thinkling about it no time! You might even eliminate the curling iron step!
  1774. this product was amazing and it doesn't matter what type of hair you have, I have coarse, it works !

After watching some of the tutorials, I gave it a shot on my own hair. It was very easy to use, and it added tons of volume and shine to my hair. I have fairly thin hair and it hits my shoulders, and this airbrush was absolutely perfect. I also LOVE that it rotates in both directions. I'm so glad that I purchased this. I highly recommend this. It gives a fantastic blow-out. FYI: IT does work best on slightly damp hair not soaking wet hair. I also use a mousse to help hold the volume.

  1779. Firstly, some background. I am a baby boomer, so you can figure out what stage of life my hair is in. I have been coloring my hair for decades with one or another product (mostly fairly benign and natural products) so my very fine, fairly abundant, middle aged hair is very dry. At one time I had a lot of this very fine, very dry hair and when I let it dry naturally (without blow-drying) could achieve a great deal of volume, even when it was very long, especially in humid weather. I was able to blow it straight and keep it that way or let it be curly and voluminous.<br /><br />Over all this time I have bought every hair device known to woman: hot rollers of every type, cold rollers (used jumbos and wrapped my hair in college), curling irons, straightening irons (ceramic expensive ones), bobby pins, sponges, self-gripping and dozens of brushes and blow dryers of every type.<br /><br />Lately, it has been harder and harder to keep my dry, fine hair from either being frizzy or flyaway. My sister-in-law raved about a Conair Infiniti ionic brush blow dryer for thicker, coarser hair. Looking at it, I realized that for my fine, medium length (to my shoulders) hair, it would be far too heavy and cumbersome.<br /><br />Then I saw those spinning hot irons with the brush on tv and thought I might try one but I have a straightening device and did not want to spend money on another one.<br /><br />Enter the Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating styler, ah! The best of all choices: wide brush, rotating or non-rotating, different heat settings, a simple, one handed wand and not too strong or hot. Perfect. It arrived virtually overnight (thanks Amazon, as always) and I liked it instantly.<br /><br />Price, length, weight, thickness, quality - all great. I have small hands and perhaps a smaller device would be better, but it is light enough that I can manipulate it. I love the fact that it can be cleaned easily, comes in a sturdy box for storage and has a great protective cover.<br /><br />If there are any drawbacks, they are that the cord is a bit stiff and the plug kept coming out of the socket until I adjusted my handling of the unit to avoid it. The other thing is that the buttons that activate rotation of the brush are very easily triggered, so you have to be careful, if you don't want them rotating at just a glance of your fingers near them. When they do rotate the brush really grabs hair strongly. If your hair is fine like mine, you need to adjust your grip to avoid it pulling on the hair too much and winding it up too tightly. I finally got the hang of that and it was less of a problem, as I got used to the rotation action.<br /><br />As for my hair, the result was mixed. I did not tame the flyaway in my bangs until I applied my favorite anti-frizz lotion from John Frieda, but this is a very very dry day, so I will reserve judgment accordingly. It did indeed create instant volume and easily turned my hair under. I can see that with a little practice, I will be able to flip my hair up or down, with little problem. So that is positive.<br /><br />On a more typical day (California, high desert), with average humidity, I think the flyaway issue will be less of a problem. As for the rest, with more experience, I believe this will add a useful tool to my arsenal, so I would recommend it, for the price and for the quality of the product.

You can use the tool in three ways: you can either just run it through your hair and dry the hair while smoothing it (without the rotating function), or you can run it through your hair and when you reach the ends you manually wind it around the brush, or you can use the rotating function and have the brush your your hair around it.   1808. ok, it is pretty evident that when a product has over 1400 reviews and 4 stars, it is pretty great. i have fine, mid- length hair, and have a hard time using a round brush and dryer. i've tried a million times, but my hair never comes out like it does at the salon. i like to believe that it's easier to do on someone else than it is on yourself ;) i debated between this one and the john frieda hot air brush. after reading quite a few reviews [on both], i decided to take the leap on this one even though it rotates and may have a higher likelihood of breaking. (i, too, believe that the more parts there are, the higher chance it will break).   1810. I absolutely love the Infiniti Pro Spinning Air Rotating Styling brush. It took me a few times to get used to it. There is one button for flipping your hair up and one button for turning your hair under. I taped a extra small button on the side that turns under so I know which button is the one I need. You can wash your hair and towel dry it and then use the Infiniti brush to style it. I was amazed at how my hair SHINES when I'm done and it eliminates using a heavy blow dryer. I use it to style my hair dry also and my hair shines just the same. You don't have to have the brush spinning if you don't want to, just use like a regular air brush. It has a cool down button also along with 2 heat settings. I can't say enough good about this brush!

My only complaint is that the air blowing through does make the hair a bit frizzier than I would like, but that's a minor inconvenience for a product that can do my hair drying and styling in one step without me having to coordinate a brush and hairdryer.
  1813. I am a 57 year old women with medium length thinning hair due to menopause. I purchased the Rotation Styler hoping it could give me some body in the places on my crown where my hair was thinning.<br />Not only has it really worked well for me, the first day I used it and went into work, my boss asked me how did I get my hair so thick and shiny overnight!!!<br />It is one of the easiest hair tools I have ever used, and for me works better than any I have purchased in years.<br />I would highly recommend this styler to anyone who wants to have thinning hair look so much thicker, so very easy.
  1814. Ditch your round metal brush and get one of these. So much easier to use and so much more effective at producing volume. Added bonus of smoothing my already smooth hair so it looks extra shiny. My hair ends up looking like it does after a professional blows it out after a haircut - no joke.
  1815. I was a bit nervous when I purchased this that I was going to have trouble using it on my long thick hair. My hair falls about mid-way down my back and is layered. It's also quite thick. To use this product, I needed to let my hair dry naturally for an hour as if I did it straight from the shower, it would have been too wet. But it will be perfect for night time showers and morning time styling. I did find that I needed to zap my roots with my regular hair dryer to ensure they were dry enough. Other than that -- this left my hair shiny and smooth WITHOUT additional hair product. I highly recommend it! It won't replace my other tools, but it will save me time int he morning and save me from straightening my hair after blow drying (something I usually do because my hair is frizzy/wavy).

This Infinitpro was so fast, easy, safe I threw my old Revo right in the trash. It made my difficult-to-tame hair look like I just got out of the salon.<br />My hair is, at this point, medium length so I can not say how it would fare with very long or very short hair. The barrel is fairly large and there was NO tangling when using the revolving brush. It dried my hair in a reasonable amount of time on the high heat setting and was never burning hot. It is light enough that I could do my whole head without my arms getting tired. I cannot imagine you would be disappointed by this styler- Conair has perfected the spin.

  1827. Let me say I purchased this 6 months ago, and I have worked in a salon and had to blow out hair (but am not a stylist).<br />My hair is terrible, very thick, long and layered, easy to frizz, and anytime I purchase something from the store/online I'm always disappointed. Not this time! I now have 3 of these (one is the pro titanium but I don't see a difference)<br /><br />To answer some concerns I saw on here before I made my purchase:<br /><br />- The brush is bigger, so if you have very short hair this may not work, it is NOT bigger than the brush I normally use (ceramic) to do my hair<br />- There is no spinning in the \\"cool\\" setting because it SETS volume (just like hot curlers)<br /><br />I started using this right out of the box, and reading one reviewers tip- the top button always curls in, no matter which hand. It does take some getting used to and you will end up pressing the button accidentally. The first time I used this I was going to a party, and I was shocked at how well my hair looked and held- for 3 days!<br /><br />This does not replace a ceramic crush or blow-dryer.I was confused about some reviews stating that they couldn't use this on wet hair. You would NOT use a ceramic brush on wet hair either.<br /><br />I have hair that has a wave, so I usually wash my hair, add product and walk around for a bit. Once my hair is dry I section and start. Sometimes I need to use a blow-dryer on the back, section by section. If you have layers you need to learn to section well, or go back later and pull them out and go over them with the brush. If they are short they don't catch.<br /><br />My hair has actually been very healthy because I don't blow-dry, then ceramic brush, then use a curler etc. All I do is use this, spray some hairspray and it holds the style for a good 3 days, so for me even if this took 15 min longer the style stays for a long time making it 100% worth it!<br /><br />The biggest reason you will never have a salon blow out at home is due to the fact that you need constant tension (pulling) and spinning. It's almost impossible to do unless you have thin hair. This really curls hair in and smooths it. Normally I can't just walk around or my hair will look \\"fluffy\\" after I ceramic brush.<br /><br />I LOVED this product from the get go, but what really stood out? I was going to the American Beauty Show and was sick, I could barely get up that morning and my hair was just frizzy and wavy (I washed and went to bed). I wet my hair with a keratin spray and water then used the brush. I was STUNNED. My hair looked like I spent hours blow drying and styling.. it took 20min.<br /><br />You can use this to refresh a style with dry shampoo, or add more bounce to your hair. I really would recommend you try this a few times and see. This is the only product I have purchased that I actually love to use. Everything else is usually over advertised and does not work on thick hair. My hair is so thick I can't even buy clips at the store (even when they say \\"thick hair\\") because they don't work!

  1843. This product makes my hair look ALIVE! I use it at home and take it with me when I go away from home. My hair has gone from flat, pin-straight flat ironed hair to salon-esque, volumized hair. My hair looks best when the spinbrush is used right after a shower as oppose to shower-sleep-style the next day.<br /><br />HOW TO USE IT: Take a small section of your hair, spin it into the brush up into the direction toward your head. Hold the brush in place for a few seconds, then move brush down to release hair into style--you may have to push the button in the opposite spin direction to release hair if you spin your hair too tight. Your hair should not be sopping wet--it should be air/blower dried, but not completely.<br /><br />PROS: The buttons are easy to figure out. The user is able to catch on to using the spinbrush effectively right away. My hair is very curly, but the spinbrush makes my hair straight with life to it.<br /><br />CONS: Ok, there's a spot at the top of the brush above the bristles where your hair can get caught in an awkward spin pattern. I think it's the only part that I think is directly, definitely burning my hair. It's just not a good spot but it's almost unavoidable to get your hair twirled awkwardly outside the bristles at that part, especially if you are spinning a big section of hair. Also, sometimes I use my straightener minimally to keep my hair nice.<br /><br />This product is a must-have, and a must-use. I bought it to experiment with it out of curiosity. I choose to use it whenever I want my hair straight and stylish. Despite the cons, I rate this product 5 stars, because I do indeed love the product. Give it a try, and you will, too!

Then, this spinning hot air iron thing entered my world. WOW. I got REALLY close to what my hair looked like the last time I left the salon! Now, I still can't get it as smooth as he can as quickly as he can, but I'm still learning how to maximize this thing. I think I'm only going to get better at it. I'm totally shocked that it doesn't tangle and get wrapped in my hair! There were only a couple of times that I snagged something I didn't intend to, and that was because I got button happy and forgot what I was doing and/or spinned it the wrong way. But I still was using it well after only a minute of using it, and by the time I was halfway through my hair I had already learned a lot.<br /><br />1 - I agree with other reviews that your hair needs to be 80%+ dry, otherwise you spend a lot of time just drying the roots.<br />2 - If you keep hold of your hair (don't let go) and turn on the spin, you can hold it at the root of your hair without wrapping your hair around it. This helps to smooth it at the roots. Just make sure the spin is going away from your head, whether you're holding it on the top or the bottom of the section of hair you're working.<br />3 - I'm going to buy a second one to keep in my closet as a backup. You never know when a power surge is going to take out your favorite appliance!<br /><br />I'm just so thrilled!!!

  1905. I definitely love this styling tool. I am not a very coordinated person so trying to use a round brush and a hair dryer is out of the question...someone would get hurt. So, this is a fantastic alternative. You have the control to make the head spin both clockwise and counter clockwise or to not spin at all. I have not ever gotten my hair stuck in the brush because of these controls. If you spin it too tight one way, you can just back it off by spinning it the opposite way. One thing I have noticed is one or two of my hairs can get caught in the seam between the cap at the top and the bristles when the brush is spinning. It's like when your hair gets caught in an elastic and you end up breaking it off in order to get it out. The only way around this dilemma is to use smaller amounts of hair when you spin. Definitely a great purchase for those without the talents to dry your hair the old fashioned way.

  1907. Quite like this product. I have moderately coarse in texture (but not particularly thick in volume) naturally wavy and spongy shoulder length hair. t took me a few tries to get the hang of it, but I set it in on high, and use the rotating movement. After about 5-7 minutes, I can both dry my hair (although it works best with slightly damp hair) and style it. I end up with nice, bouncy (straight if I want it) bob with decent volume and lovely movement. I also get decent shine.<br /><br />The only thing preventing me from giving this product 5 stars is the fact that it's left my hair feeling oily and limp at the end of the day. I don't know why my hair is falling so flat, but it's more flat than just using a hair dryer. I suspect it's because the rotating motion is distributing oil from the scalp down the hair shaft -- in part why it creates shine and smooths. But, by the time I leave work at 5pm, my hair is so flat I've had to resort to putting in a pony tail.<br /><br />I suppose I still need to get the hang of it.

  1914. This thing GRABS your hair if you don't get a narrow enough piece and very literally ties in knots. I'm not exaggerating. KNOTS. My hair is fairly short (chin length) and while I think this does an okay job styling hair, I hesitate to use it because end up having to spend extra time untangling the errible tangles. I wouldn't buy it again.
  1915. When I was researching a new product I was a little skeptical because I wasn't sure the brush would dry my long thick curly hair. I went ahead and ordered it, just because I needed something. When I washed my hair I toweled dried it. Then I separated my hair into small sections. I took my hair dryer with the defuser and just dried my hair for about 5 minutes. I then took the Infinity Pro & started to dry each section, going in one direction then the other until dry. OMG my hair is so shinny and has the volume I like. I love my new Infinity Pro and would recommend it to anyone who wants beautiful hair. Everyday people tell me how beautiful my hair is. If you used the REVO styler in the past that is no longer available you will love this styler. It is so light and the buttons to control the rotations are so well placed. Bravo Conair for creating this product!
  1916. Works okay. Doesn't seem to curl my hair like I hoped it would, like a styling brush and hair dryer. Was hoping to have an extra hand while using it, but it doesn't blow hot air as much as a hair dryer, and creates bad static!!!
  1917. I have been using this for a week and I have been pleased. It takes some getting use to, and it won't look perfect at first. The only negatives I have seen is if you are going too quick and it gets too close to my roots, my hair gets all knotted and tangled in it. Also the air flow is not heavy enough to dry the hair. Mine is long thick hair so I use a hair dryer to dry most of it before using this product. I don't try it completely, just so it is a little damp.
  1918. This is the greatest product I have ever tried. Use to take me up to an hour to blow my hair with a roundbrush and it still looked awful. With the infinitipro spinner it takes 15 min and looks like a professional job plus my hair is super shiny.

  1920. I have been using this rotating styler for about 3 weeks and it works great! I love it! It's a little tricky at first as you need to keep a firm grasp on the handle.   1924. excellent, Iloveit, works great and build body like a pro stylist I use it every time I style my hair, just wash and spin
  1925. I have thinning, fine, medium length, semi frizzy hair. When I first got this tool I was excited because I wanted volume in my hair and I figured this tool would do it. At first it was awkward to use but you get use to it. I'm very lazy when it comes to my hair so I don't use it often.<br /><br />I've had it for over a year but since it doesn't get used frequently I'll estimate that after approximately 10 uses, the speed of the rotating brush went from 100% to about 25% - I mean ssssslllllooooooowwwww but then for no reason at all, it would come back to its original speed then go back to slow - I checked to make sure no hair was tangled and I can't figure out why it slows down.<br /><br />I was pretty unhappy with this air brush until a couple of days ago. The brush has been at its regular speed but alone, the brush does NOTHING for my thin flat hair BUT in conjunction with John Frieda Luxurious Volume Shampoo, Conditioner AND Blow Out Spray I'm happier than I've ever been. The shampoo and conditioner make my hair feel fluffy and soft and the blow out spray helps the Infinity Air Brush helps my roots stand up. The amount of volume I get is astonishing!!! Try it!!
  1926. I gave it as gift for my sister, and she love it. just be careful for it not pulling so hard on your hair
  1927. I can do better myself with a round brush and blow dryer. I got it hoping it would save time in the morning and I could still look like I attempted to do something with my hair. I have thin, medium length hair and still need to blow dry it quite a bit before using it which defeats the purpose. If you leave it wet it is difficult to dry it and curl it. The instructions that came with it even said that blow drying prior might be necessary. I was disappointed by that from the start. It also lessens my ability to get a good curl, because it's now half dried. Not being ceramic is a down side too, because it doesn't style that well.<br /><br />It has A LOT of power. It can take a fair amount of muscle to hold it back from tangling up in my hair. I did not think it would be that difficult to use. It also does wrap your hair in the groove between the brush and handle sometimes, this can be painful.<br /><br />Overall, I don't like it. It didn't meet the expectations I had for it, especially for the price!!! I went back to my ceramic round brush and blow dryer method.

  1931. The InfinitiPro Spin Air Rotating Styler works very well. I have medium length hair and it does not get stuck in my hair while spinning. If it gets tight, just stop spinning and comb it out a little. It spins just like they say it does. If you are wondering if the spin feature is going to work well like on TV, then YES it spins very well both ways. It really does not &#34;curl&#34; my hair like a curling iron would though. It does smooth it while it drys. It does give it some shape and wave (especially if using mousse first.)

  1939. If you want this to replace the original REVO you will be disappointed. If this is your first attempt at round brushing, you may love it.<br /><br />I have long thick wavy/frizzy hair. I was in love with my original REVO back in the day (think gorgeous movie star hair), so I measure all my hair gadgets up to REVO.<br /><br />Infiniti pros: has a cord, doesn't tangle long hair, puts out heat (not even close to enough to replace hair dryer), price, small learning curve<br /><br />Cons: not enough tension to release tough frizz or create big volume.<br /><br />Original REVO pros: creates more tension, which equals better results- smoother hair with more volume than what is achievable with Infiniti<br /><br />Cons: price, tangles easily, cordless (have to charge frequently), not as durable as you would expect for the price<br /><br />Obviously REVO isn't the perfect product based on cons, but it does give the best results.

  1952. I have super fine, frizzy, damaged, awkward hair. It lays flat and limp against my head and no matter how hard I try, I can never get my hair to have any volume or shine without looking flat and greasy.<br /><br />I've only used this spin styler once (I got it in the mail last night) but so far I LOVE IT! My hair is soft, smooth, and shiny! It's laying straight with a touch of curl on the ends and it looks beautiful! The only thing I couldn't do with it (so far, since I've only used it once) was to get any root volume. When I use a blowdryer, I can get root volume by pulling the hair up from the roots and flipping my head upside down. I couldn't quite figure out how to do that with the spin styler, but I'm sure I will with a little practice.<br /><br />If you have frizzy, damaged hair that gets even more wrecked by a blowdryer, I highly recommend the Infinitipro spin air rotating styler. You'll have smoother, softer, shiny hair in less time :)
  1953. It took me a little while to get use to it, but now I really love it. Leaves my hair soft and shiny.
  1954. I'm so excited. I've only tried it out so far but look forward to actually drying my very curling hair with it so that I can straighten my hair and yet leave it with body.   1955. I have long, thick, wavy hair and was looking for a hairdryer that would help relax the waves for a more sleek look. I found that this hairdryer isn't strong enough. I was reluctant to buy it after I read some of the reviews but I thought how bad can it be? If you have 2 hours to dry your hair in the morning before you go to work then it will work. 500 watts is for baby hair or people with very thin hair. I went back to my Conair with 1875 watts using a round brush. It still takes me 30 minutes to dry my hair using this method but it's the best I have at the moment.<br /><br />It's not worth the hassle of returning it but I would rather leave it in plain view in my bathroom as a reminder to never buy a hairdryer that only has 500 watts.<br /><br />If Infiniti would make this same dryer with 1875 watts it would be like building a better mousetrap. They would sell like hotcakes.
